DOC.HEAD: 50,000 Rally Against Federal AIDS Policy
LaserPhoto NY8
DOC.TEXT: Police and organizers of a rally by Haitians and African Americans to protest AIDS policies had expected 10,000 people, but an extra 40,000 flooded Lower Manhattan and coaxed Mayor David Dinkins out as well. ``The FDA is wrong,'' he shouted, attracting a scream of delight from the crowd. ``I predict they're going to reverse themselves.'' The march Friday was in protest of a Food and Drug Administration policy prohibiting anyone who has emigrated from Haiti or certain African countries from giving blood, as a precaution against spreading AIDS. Later, Dinkins' prediction came true as a federal AIDS advisory committee in Washington recommended that the government's ban on blood donations be eased for people who have been screened for the deadly virus. The recommendation, supported by three of the panel's five members, will be considered immediately by the Food and Drug Administration, said Dr. Paul Parkman, the agency's AIDS coordinator. Dr. Joel L. Solomon, director of the FDA's Division of Blood and Blood products, said in a statement that the emigres have been excluded from giving blood because the AIDS-related virus is endemic and is transmitted largely through heterosexual activity in their countries, making it difficult to tell in advance who would and would not have the virus. Before noon Friday, the crowd swelled quickly as protesters gathered in downtown Brooklyn and crossed the Brooklyn Bridge, which was closed for more than two hours. Lt. Raymond O'Donnell, a police spokesman, said the police estimate was 20,000 people at 12:30 p.m. and more than 50,000 an hour later at the scheduled start of a rally at Federal Plaza. ``This is unbelievable,'' he said. Two serious injuries were reported when a motorist caught in the huge crowd got into an argument with some of the demonstrators, said another police spokesman, Sgt. Ed Burns. There were no arrests. A press notice announcing the demonstration stated it was sponsored by a coalition of students, community groups and clergy organizations called the Haitian Enforcement Against Racism. Several people carried a large black coffin through the crowd. Printed on it was ``AIDS is a U.S. government germ warfare.'' Another sign read, ``Scientists Created AIDS to Kill Black Population.'' About 1.6 percent of all AIDS cases in the United States are among Haitians. Many of the Haitian immigrants live in Florida and New York.

DOC.HEAD: Church Reverses Decision Barring Boy With AIDS from Class
DOC.TEXT: The foster mother of an AIDS-infected 5-year-old boy said she bore no grudge against a church that barred the child from Sunday school classes but lifted the ban after it drew criticism. Terry and Walt Rucker said late Friday they ``welcome the opportunity'' to take their son back to Moody Church. ``I think more than anything, I felt disappointment when all this happened,'' Mrs. Rucker said in a telephone interview. ``I don't feel any bitterness.'' Earlier Mrs. Rucker had said, ``This is a Bible-teaching church, and they cannot justify their fears.'' News of the non-denominational evangelical church's original decision broke late Thursday, less than two weeks after the April 8 death of Ryan White, an Indiana teen-ager who fought to end discrimination against AIDS victims. The ban sparked criticism from the American Civil Liberties Union, the Ruckers and AIDS activists, four of whom protested outside the church Friday. At a news conference Friday afternoon, the Rev. Erwin Lutzer _ the church's senior pastor _ announced the ban was lifted. Referring to the child by a fictitious name, Lutzer said, ``We love Joey, and we want Joey back in our Sunday school, and Joey will be back in our Sunday school.'' Lutzer said other children's parents would be told a child with AIDS would be attending Sunday school, ``and they will have the freedom to keep their children'' from the class. ``Our position and our concerns have not changed,'' Lutzer said. ``We have decided to shift the burden of responsibility from us as a church'' to the parents. Rucker said the church's original ban had surprised him, adding, ``We thought with Ryan White, all that had been settled.'' Lutzer said the original ban was intended only ``to give us time to think (the situation) through.'' He said he didn't expect a mass exodus from the class of about 15 children and said the church already welcomes AIDS victims to its sanctuary services. John Hammell, director of the AIDS and Civil Liberties Project of the American Civil Liberties Union of Illinois, said the decision to bar the boy seemed to violate laws prohibiting discrimination against the handicapped. Rucker, a psychologist, and his wife, a nurse, took Joey in when his mother, who also had AIDS, became too sick to care for him. AIDS is caused by a virus transmitted mainly through sexual intercourse, shared hypodermic needles and from infected mothers to their infants before or during birth. It has no known cure.

DOC.HEAD: Advance Squad Deployed in Prince William Sound
DOC.TEXT: An advance crew began work in two environmentally sensitive areas in Prince William Sound, 10 days before Exxon Corp. was to resume its general cleanup of the Exxon Valdez oil spill. The work is aimed at enhancing conditions for commercial fishing and providing protection for wildlife spring migration into the sound, the company said. A ship left Seward on Friday to work on areas that may need attention before the general cleanup resumes May 1 because they may be closed later due to wildlife activity, Exxon spokesman Joe Tucker in Anchorage said. Workers today were spreading absorbent booms in the waters off Knight and Latouche islands, which include sea bird rookeries and areas where seals and sea lions haul out. As other sites needing cleanup are identified by company and federal officials, ``they will initially do manual pickup of oily debris,'' Tucker said. The ship carried nine contract employees, an Exxon supervisor, two boom deployment specialists and observers from the U.S. Coast Guard and the state Department of Environmental Conservation, Tucker said. ``The crews won't necessarily hit the beaches,'' he said. ``This is not the start of the main summer cleanup. This is just an advance squad.'' Hundreds of miles of shoreline in Prince William Sound were fouled when the tanker Exxon Valdez ran aground on a charted reef on March 24, 1989. The reef shredded the tanker's hull, releasing nearly 11 million gallons of North Slope crude oil into the water. It was the nation's biggest oil spill, killing hundreds of otters and thousands of birds and other animals. Exxon said it spent more than $2 billion in last summer's cleanup campaign, hiring over 10,000 workers and leasing more than 1,000 boats for the operation. The oil giant said winter storms scoured clean many of the beaches, and it plans a greatly reduced operation this year.

DOC.HEAD: Columbia Crew Ready to Fly Astronomy Mission Once Discovery Gets Off Ground
DOC.TEXT: The Columbia astronauts are waiting in the shadow of next week's Discovery flight before they are given the go-ahead to fly into space with their astronomy laboratory. While the seven Columbia astronauts have been preparing for their nine-day flight to observe ultraviolet rays and X-rays in deep space, the spotlight has been on Discovery's mission to deploy the $1.5 billion Hubble Space Telescope. That mission was delayed by two weeks but liftoff is scheduled for Tuesday morning. ``We joke around that if they don't get out of the way, we'll run over them,'' said Columbia Commander Vance Brand, whose mission is scheduled for a May 9 blastoff. Discovery is poised on one launch pad at Cape Canaveral, Fla., and Columbia was scheduled Sunday to be rolled out to another pad 1.6 miles away. Two shuttles have not been on separate pads simultaneously since January 1986, when Challenger was moved to the pad while Columbia was awaiting launch. Challenger exploded 10 days after Columbia landed. While the Columbia astronauts gave their pre-flight press conference Friday at Houston's Johnson Space Center, technicians at Cape Canaveral were installing Hubble's powerful batteries in preparation for launch. The batteries will power the telescope from the time it is disconnected from Discovery's power system until its energy-collecting solar panels are unfurled in space. Hubble, once in orbit 380 miles above Earth, will be capable of detecting objects 50 times fainter and with 10 times greater clarity than the best ground-based observatory. The Columbia crew will carry the $100 million Astro observatory into space to observe and measure ultraviolet radiation from objects in space without interference from the Earth's atmosphere. The four astronomers on the crew hope the three ultraviolet instruments and the board band X-ray will shed light on galaxies, black holes and quasars. ``We think this has tremendous science potential,'' Brand said. On Friday, the Columbia astronauts noted that their observatory should be able to relay information to the ground first, even though Hubble will get to space sooner. ``We will be sending down science data while space telescope is still doing engineering checkout, and so we should be able to beat them to the punch on getting down the first science data,'' said mission specialist Robert Parker. For the first time since the Challenger accident, two payload specialists will fly into space aboard Columbia. Ronald Parise and Samuel Durrance will be operating the telescopes along with mission specialists Jeffrey Hoffman and Parker. The observatory will be in the shuttle's cargo bay but will be operated by the astronauts in the shuttle cabin. Parise is a senior scientist in the space observatories department at the Computer Sciences Corp. in Silver Spring, Md. Durrance is a research scientist in the physics and astronomy department at John Hopkins University. Pilot Guy Gardner and flight engineer John M. ``Mike'' Lounge will be in charge of maneuvering the orbiter so the telescopes can be aimed at different points in space. Even though the Hubble mission has been getting most of the media attention, Hoffman said the two flights are not in competition. He said he teases the Discovery crew members, saying he'll get the chance to work as a space astronomer for more than a week. ``All they do is throw out a telescope. Anybody can do that,'' Hoffman joked.

DOC.HEAD: Toddler's Mother Sentenced to 30 Years
DOC.TEXT: A woman whose 2-year-old son was dunked head-first into a toilet repeatedly as punishment for soiling his pants pleaded guilty to her part in the boy's death and was sentenced to 30 years in prison. Sheryl McGee Coe, 21, was sentenced Friday for second-degree murder and aggravated child abuse in the July 27 death of Bradley McGee. Outrage over the toddler's death prompted lawmakers last fall to pass the ``Bradley McGee Bill,'' allocating an extra $78 million for the state to hire more child-protection workers. Mrs. Coe and her husband, Thomas Coe, 22, originally were charged with first-degree murder. Coe told authorities he repeatedly dunked Bradley head-first into a toilet for soiling his pants, then he and his wife beat him with pillows until he collapsed. Prosecutors said Mrs. Coe will be subpoenaed to testify against her husband at his first-degree murder and aggravated child abuse trial, set for July. Corrections officials said that with good behavior, Mrs. Coes would serve 10 years in prison. The boy had been put in foster care when he was 3 months old after his parents abandoned him at a mall. Two months before his death, the state Department of Health and Rehabilitative Services returned the child to his parents, despite repeated warnings from foster parents and relatives that he might be in danger. Three state child protection workers were charged with failing to report suspected child abuse in the case. One supervisor was acquitted in February and the others face trial.

DOC.HEAD: Predawn Vegas Hotel Fire Forces 200 to Evacuate; 3 Minor Injuries Reported
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with officials now saying fire burns top floor, sted whole building; lower evacuee total; adds background on MGM Grand fire, quotes from witness. No pickup. ADDS byline.
DOC.TEXT: Fire ripped through the upper floor of a five-story hotel before dawn today, sending 150 sleepy guests scurrying to safety near the glittering Las Vegas Strip, authorities said. Three people were treated for minor smoke inhalation in the fire at the Las Vegas Inn, but no serious injuries were reported and no one was believed trapped in the hotel, officials said. Early warnings allowed nearly all 150 guests in the 75-room hotel to evacuate the hotel without injury, city spokesman Doug Bradford said. ``We believe the fire started in the attic,'' Bradford said. ``We were able to keep the fire on the roof and top floor.'' The fire broke out about 2:30 a.m. and was brought under control nearly three hours later. The building was equipped with sprinklers in accordance with a state law enacted following the MGM Grand Hotel fire that killed 87 in November 1980, Bradford said. He added that the sprinklers ``definitely saved lives and probably saved the entire building.'' Tina Gutierrez, 26, of Los Angeles was asleep on the fourth floor when warnings first sounded. ``I woke up to find the fire alarm going off,'' she said. ``It went off, thank goodness. I opened the door and there was black smoke.'' Two smoke victims were treated and released from Valley Hospital, said nursing supervisor Eleanor Jakobs. A third was treated and released from University Medical Center, according to a nursing supervisor who said hospital policy prevented him from giving his name. Bradford said a couple of other people were treated at the scene for minor cuts or smoke problems. The cause of the fire was not immediately determined. Scores of onlookers lined the street as firefighters rained water on the blaze.

DOC.HEAD: Iranian Paper Urges Hostage-Takers To Free Captive
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS two grafs after 21st `Eight Americans...' to ADD West German hostage's birthday today; pickup graf 22 pvs `Relatives of...'
DOC.TEXT: A newspaper that often reflects the views of Iran's president today urged pro-Iranian hostage-takers in Lebanon to hasten talks to free an American captive. The Tehran Times said it hoped the release of one captive could be ``the prelude to the release of one more hostage by another group.'' The editorial was the latest in a series of hostage developments that began Wednesday, when one Lebanese group holding three American educators said it would release one hostage by Friday. However, the Islamic Jihad for the Liberation of Palestine said Thursday it had indefinitely postponed the release. It blamed the delay on the refusal of the United States to send a senior diplomat to Damascus, as the group demanded. A Shiite Moslem cleric reputed to have influence over the kidnappers, Hussain Musawi, said Friday by telephone from his headquarters in the eastern Lebanese town of Baalbek that freedom for a hostage was certain despite the delays. Asked when he expected the release to take place, Musawi said: ``That depends on how far-sighted the Americans might become. So far, their behavior is arrogant and one of cowboy mentality.'' Musawi heads Islamic Amal, a faction within the pro-Iranian Hezbollah group that advocates strong links with Syria. Hezbollah is believed to be the umbrella for Shiite Moslem groups holding most of the 18 Western hostages in Lebanon. Thousands of Hezbollah members joined a military parade Friday through Beirut's southern slums, two blocks from where many of the hostages are believed held. Syria has said it is working to free one by Sunday. In Damascus, officials have met frequently with U.S. Ambassador Edward Djerejian since he returned to the Syrian capital Thursday. The Islamic Jihad for the Liberation of Palestine had demanded the United States send John Kelly, the assistant secretary of state for Near Eastern affairs, to Damascus for final coordination of the release. He was the ambassador to Lebanon from 1986 to 1988, and he conducted secret hostage negotiations in what became known as the Iran-Contra affair. In Washington, Kelly said Djerejian was in Damascus and ``fully capable of handling all the details of bringing a hostage out safely, and quickly, and efficiently.'' ``You know American policy is that we do not make concessions to those who hold the hostages,'' Kelly said in a statement. ``We want the hostages out, but we are not going to bow to the demands of the hostage-holders.'' The English-language Tehran Times said the kidnappers should consider Djerejian's presence ``good enough to conduct the arrangements for the release of the hostage.'' It repeated an appeal, first made in February, for ``freedom of all hostages without any conditions and immediately.'' ``Hurdles there may be on the way, but it is our hope that despite all, the freedom of the hostages can become a reality materializing soon,'' said the newspaper, considered close to Iranian President Hashemi Rafsanjani. The Islamic Jihad for the Liberation of Palestine holds Alann Steen, a native of Boston who turns 51 on Sunday; Jesse Turner, 42, of Boise, Idaho; and Robert Polhill, 55, of New York. It had not said which of the three it had considered freeing. They were kidnapped from the campus of the U.S.-affiliated Beirut University College on Jan. 24, 1987, by gunmen disguised as riot police. Eight Americans are among the 18 Westerners held in Lebanon. The longest-held is Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press. He was kidnapped in Beirut on March 16, 1985. West German hostage Heinrich Struebig turned 49 in captivity today. Struebig, a relief worker with the German organization Asme-Humanitas, was kidnapped May 16, 1989, near the south Lebanon city of Sidon along with a German colleague, 28-year-old Thomas Kemptner. No group has claimed responsibility for their abduction. Relatives of two hostages said Friday in Damascus they were optimistic. ``The mood seems to be as if the hostage issue, the hostage file, will be finally closed,'' said Feryal Polhill, the wife of Robert Polhill. ``I would like President Bush not to spare any effort to free all the hostages,'' added Mrs. Polhill, who is Lebanese. Hala El-Khazen, sister-in-law of Jesse Turner, said she brought a suitcase full of his clothes with her to Damascus.

DOC.HEAD: Lithuanians Close Factories to Fight Embargo
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 15-17 `Algimantas Cekuolis...political support' with 3 grafs to UPDATE with Estonian premier in Vilnius. Pickup 18th graf `President Mikhail...'; SUBS 23rd graf `Lithuanian Prime...' with 1 graf to UPDATE with Prunskiene in Copenhagen...' Pickup 19th graf `Armed soldiers...'
DOC.TEXT: Lithuania shut most of its factories today to save fuel and raw materials in the face of an expanding embargo by Moscow to break the independence drive, a top government official said. Leaders of the republic, which declared independence March 11, said they were still searching for a compromise to end the standoff but that no firm proposals were under discussion. On Friday, the Kremlin tightened its vise on Lithuania by expanding its energy embargo to other products, and Soviet troops stormed a printing plant and beat at least 13 people, Lithuanians said. Today is a regular workday under normal circumstances, but Deputy Premier Romualdas Ozolas said the majority of factories were shut. ``We decided not to waste our strength while it is not necessary,'' Ozolas said in an interview. Since Wednesday, Moscow has cut off all oil and about 80 percent of the natural gas supply to Lithuania. Officials said Friday that supplies of some food products, tires, cable and other goods also were curtailed. Traffic on the streets of Vilnius, the Lithuanian capital, was greatly reduced today. A rationing plan limits drivers to about 7 gallons of gasoline a month. Ozolas said some Lithuanian factories probably would have to close starting Monday because of shortages of fuel and raw materials. However, he said the neighboring Baltic republic of Estonia was offering aid, and an agreement probably would be reached late today. President Vytautus Landsbergis, speaking to reporters at the opening of a meeting by the pro-independence Sajudis movement, said Lithuania was searching for a compromise with Moscow, but there were no proposals on the table. Asked about reports that Moscow was offering to negotiate if Lithuania delayed independence for two years, he said: ``We haven't received any kind of proposal.'' ``We haven't debated this,'' he said. But he also said some compromise ideas had been raised in contacts through middlemen. He would not give details. Landsbergis was quoted as saying Friday that a two-year moratorium on full independence could form part of a compromise. ``If somebody authorized by Moscow to negotiate presented us with a package of proposals including this, we could have a discussion,'' The New York Times quoted him as saying in today's editions. However, he also reportedly said Lithuania would not agree to put itself under the authority of the Soviet constitution. Ozolas, Landsbergis and Estonian Premier Edgar Savisaar conferred informally Saturday morning during a break in the Sajudis session. Savisaar, recalling that Lithuanian civilians were beaten by Soviet soldiers who occupied a Vilnius printing plant Friday, told the congress: ``What happened in Vilnius yesterday could happen in Tallin tomorrow. Estonians understand this and are ready to share the hardships.'' The Baltic republics of Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia were forcibly annexed by the Soviet Union in 1940. Despite the Soviet military and economic pressure, Lithuania has refused to back off its declaration of independence and has sought Western material and political support. President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has refused to negotiate unless Lithuania rescinds the declaration. In Birmingham, Ala., where President Bush addressed a political rally, spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said the White House is ``increasingly concerned'' by reports of the economic crackdown on Lithuania and that Bush will brief Congress early next week on possible retaliation. Lithuanians produce more meat and milk than they consume, and they are in no danger of serious food shortages. However, Lithuania's Communist Party chief, Algirdas Brazauskas, said the republic's 3.8 million people must compromise on its pro-independence decisions or face critical shortages of oil and natural gas in two weeks. ``In two weeks, we will have a critical situation,'' Brazauskas told the Lithuanian parliament. ``The price for independence must have limits.'' Lithuanian Prime Minister Kazimiera Prunskiene today traveled to Copenhagen for talks with Danish officials. She was in Norway on Friday discussing how to obtain oil at world-market prices instead of low-cost oil for Soviet rubles. She offered to trade Lithuanian dairy products. Armed soldiers stormed a Communist Party printing plant in Vilnius during the afternoon and beat at least 13 people, witnesses said. There has been almost no violence during the standoff with Moscow, even though Soviet soldiers have previously occupied several party and public buildings. Soviet forces have also dragged some deserters back to the military. Lithuanian legislator Zigmas Vaisvilas said civilian guards arrived Friday at the plant, which already was occupied by a few Interior Ministry troops without weapons. The Soviet news agency Tass said the colonel in charge asked the civilians to leave and called in reinforcements when they refused. Helmeted Soviet soldiers carrying automatic weapons and truncheons arrived in two trucks, entered the building and beat some of the civilians, said witness Angele Guobiene, who works for the trade union journal Darbas Ir Poilsis, which is printed at the plant. Soviet authorities let about two dozen foreign correspondents return to Lithuania until Sunday after expelling virtually all of them from the republic on April 1.

DOC.HEAD: Extremists Rampage Through East, West Berlin
LaserPhoto BER1
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of right-wing and left-wing extremists went on the rampage after a soccer game and at least 48 people were injured, authorities said today. Soccer fans and neo-Nazis were dispersed in East Berlin before a leftist group arrived from West Berlin to confront them. But the leftists themselves went on a rampage in West Berlin, looting stores and hurling rocks. Fifty-seven people were arrested, officials said. Trouble started after a soccer match between FC Berlin and Hansa Rostock Friday in the eastern part of the divided city, where 300 youths, some wearing masks, fought pitched battles in Alexander Platz, East Berlin's main square. Some rioters shouted tributes to Adolf Hitler's 101st birthday Friday and attacked passersby, police said. The official East German news agency ADN said the mob also stormed a homosexual bar screaming ``Gay's out.'' Amid cries of ``You know it's Adolf Hitler's birthday,'' they smashed windows and ransacked the club. Witnesses said some of the club's 15 guests suffered minor cuts and bruises in the fray, ADN said. They were not, however, included among the injured. An East German Interior Ministry statement said two people were seriously hurt and four police sustained light injuries in the Alexander Platz fracas. An official of the FC Berlin soccer club was also badly hurt after being attacked. The ministry said 30 youths were arrested. Police said about 300 West Berlin leftists and foreign residents gathered on the western side of the Wall after hearing radio reports of the violence, then moved into East Berlin to confront the thugs. Police said the group returned to West Berlin within an hour after discovering the opposing group had already been dispersed. ``As they did not meet any right-wing extremists, they came back to vent their fury here,'' said West Berlin police spokesman Heinz Wiedemann. The leftists hurled stones and bottles at police, built street barricades and smashed shop and car windows. He said at least three stores were looted in West Berlin's Kreuzberg district, he said. Wiedemann said 41 policemen were injured and 27 people were arrested in the West Berlin clashes. Berlin defeated Hansa Rostock 3-0 in the soccer match.

DOC.HEAD: Japan Running Out of Room For Its Garbage
DOC.TEXT: Japan will soon run out of room to stash its trash, the government said Saturday. ``The problem is a disease of extravagance,'' said Tetsuo Hayakawa, spokesman for the Health and Welfare Ministry's environmental affairs division. ``People are throwing away everything, even things still good enough to use.'' The mountainous island nation, comparable in size to California, created 48.3 million tons of trash in 1988, 3.9 percent more than the year before, the Health and Welfare Ministry said. It rushed to compile the data months ahead of schedule in time for international Earth Day Sunday. The volume of trash produced by the nation's industries and 120 million people was enough to fill Japan's largest stadium, the Tokyo Dome, 130 times over, the ministry said. Hayakawa said that if the Japanese continue wasting resources at the current pace, they will create more than 60 million tons of trash by 1994, and there will not be enough space to bury it. He blamed the wasteful use of computer paper in offices and consumers' growing use of disposable products, such as plastic bottles and even cameras. In addition, people are buying new home appliances and throwing out old refrigerators, televisions and the like in vast numbers, he said. In Tokyo, Japan's largest city, paper from offices accounts for about 42 percent of the city's trash, while kitchen garbage makes up 37 percent. Plastics, metals, glass and other materials account for the rest. Aside from landfill disposal, Tokyo uses 13 incineration plants to get rid of trash, but these are able to handle only 80 percent of the city's burnable trash, Hayakawa said, adding that the problem is similar in many other parts of the country.

DOC.HEAD: Students Clash With Riot Police During Protest Of Giant Governing Party
DOC.TEXT: Riot police fired barrages of tear gas today to disperse students throwing firebombs and shouting ``Overthrow (President) Roh Tae-woo!'' Clashes erupted at Seoul's Yonsei University when police blocked a march by about 2,000 dissidents and radical students protesting the recent creation of a giant governing party. Riot police backed by armored vans firing scores of tear gas shells moved about 70 yards onto the campus to disperse the protesters. About 1,000 police surrounded the school. During an earlier rally at the university, the dissidents vowed to launch an anti-Roh campaign across the nation, shouting ``Let's destroy the ruling party.'' The fighting lasted for an hour. Groups of masked students dashed out with firebombs that exploded in orange flames in the streets. It was not known immediately how many were injured. News reports said police took away about 400 students. During a street rally in the central provincial city of Taejon, opposition leader Kim Dae-jung urged President Roh Tae-woo to disband his governing party or face a national vote of confidence. Kim's aides said about 100,000 supporters attended the peaceful rally. Police put the number at 20,000. In Kim's southern hometown of Kwangju, police fired tear gas to disperse about 300 students trying to attack a ruling party office with firebombs and rocks. No damage and injuries were reported. The opposition leader accused Roh of backpedaling from his promised reforms and demanded Roh immediately dismantle the party formed in January through a merger of Roh's governing party and two opposition groups. Roh has introduced broad reforms since he took office in February 1988 and sent his authoritarian predecessor to disgraceful rural exile. In recent months, however, critics have accused him of ignoring calls for further reforms.

DOC.HEAD: California Community Ranked Best in `Micropolitan' City Survey
DOC.TEXT: The best small community in the United States to call home is the San Luis Obispo-Atascadero, Calif., area and the worst is Nampa-Caldwell, Idaho, according to a newly published book. ``The Rating Guide to Life in America's Small Cities'' ranks all 219 ``micropolitan'' areas for their desirability as alternatives to living in the nation's large metropolitan centers. San Luis Obispo's ``easygoing charm'' and ``mild climate'' helped earned it the top ranking. ``The town barricades its main thoroughfare, allows farmers and vendors to sell food, and stages a weekly street fair'' every Thursday, the book noted. The book's author, G. Scott Thomas, defines micropolitans as cities of between 15,000 and 50,000 people in counties of at least 40,000 population. The communities cannot be part of regions designated as metropolitan areas by the U.S. government as of June 15, 1989. Most suburban communities are disqualified because they are included in metropolitan areas. ``More than 15 million people live in micropolitan America, nearly 6.5 percent of the nation's population,'' said Thomas. In 20 states, the smaller cities make up 10 percent of the population, with Idaho having the highest proportion at slightly more than 35 percent, he added. In a few states, the cities included are independent and not located in counties. One city, Decatur, Ala., which the government designates as a metropolitan area, is considered a micro by Thomas. The District of Columbia and four states _ Hawaii, Massachusetts, New Jersey and South Dakota _ have no micropolitan areas. The cities were assigned a points in 10 categories: climate, economics, education, health care, housing, public safety, transportation, urban proximity, sophistication and diversions. The latter two categories measured things such as voter turnout, population turnover, newspaper readership, movie theaters, parks, golf courses, restaurants and retail stores. The maximum possible score was 1,000. The top five micropolitans, in rank order, are San Luis Obispo-Atascadero, Calif.; Corvallis, Ore.; Fredericksburg, Va.; Fairbanks, Alaska; and Wenatchee, Wash. The bottom five are Minden, La.; Gallup, N.M.; Rio Rancho, N.M.; Lumberton, N.C. and Nampa-Caldwell, Idaho.

DOC.HEAD: Budget Squeeze Could Torpedo `Hate Crimes' Program, Sponsor Says
DOC.TEXT: President Bush is believed ready to sign a bill requiring the government to keep track of ``hate crimes'' against minorities, but the sponsor says the program could be torpedoed by a budget squeeze at the FBI. ``The implementation of the landmark hate crimes legislation will be severely hampered if the staff responsible for administering the law at the FBI is reduced,'' Rep. Charles Schumer, D-N.Y., said. Schumer made his comment came Friday after the FBI acknowledged that it is considering a proposal to discontinue its uniform crime report _ an annual count of crimes in America. Under the recently approved hate crimes bill, the Justice Department is to keep statistics on offenses related to race, religion, sexual orientation and ethnicity as part of the uniform crime report. Approval of the hate crimes bill followed complaints about a wave of such offenses on the part of neo-Nazi skinheads and other bigot groups. A 1988 Justice Department report, however, said no such statistics were available. The Bush administration supported the measure, which was sponsored in the House by Schumer, and the president was expected to sign it this week. FBI officials, however, told Schumer at a hearing Thursday that a budget squeeze was draining manpower from their statistics-gathering staff. They said a proposal that would in effect eliminate the 60-year-old crime reports was under consideration by the records management division as a way to help absorb the manpower cuts. FBI officials said a longstanding drive by the Office of Management and Budget to slash payroll and channel work to private contractors was responsible for much of the reduction in manpower. They said the records division has lost 258 positions since 1987 and plans call for elimination of 92 more. The division has more than 1,100 employees Special Agent J. Harper Wilson, in charge of the uniform crime reports, said his staff might be spared the brunt of the cuts but would have to absorb at least 30 and more likely far more than that. Schumer issued a statement Friday, saying that ``at a time when information on overall crime is woefully thin, the Bush administration should be moving forcefully to bolster its understanding of crime, not undermining it. I hope the president personally intervenes to prevent these cutbacks.'' ``Without it, his signing into law of the hate crimes measure would be little more than an empty gesture,'' he added. Schumer also sent a letter to Attorney General Dick Thornburgh, saying that a large staff cut ``would eviscerate the bureau's ability to collect and distribute the uniform crime reports.'' The Justice Department also maintains a separate data-gathering arm, the Bureau of Justice Statistics.

DOC.HEAD: Quake Damages Villages in Eastern Turkey
DOC.TEXT: An earthquake rocked eastern Turkey early Saturday, causing damage in some villages, the semi-official Anatolia News Agency reported. There were no immediate reports of injuries. The news agency said the quake damaged houses in eight villages in Cayirli township. The quake measured 5.4 on the Richter scale. A quake of magnitude 5 can cause considerable damage. The Richter scale gauges the amount of energy released by an earthquake, as measured by the ground motion recorded on a seismograph.

DOC.HEAD: Unions Shut Down Nicaraguan Banks to Pressure Contras; U.N. Expands Duties
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS graf after 3rd graf ``We don't...'' to UPDATE with U.N. expanding peacekeeping operations. Pickup 4th graf `The U.S.-backed...'
DOC.TEXT: Sandinista activists shut down the nation's banks to demand higher wages and press the Contra rebels to disband. Sandinista labor leaders said they wanted to make certain with Friday's strike that the rebels would honor a pledge earlier this week to lay down their arms after a nine-year U.S.-backed civil war. ``We don't have any confidence that the Contras will comply with these accords,'' said Luis Jimenez, vice secretary of the national Sandinista union. The United Nations Security Council on Friday night instructed the U.N. Observer Group in Central America to expand its efforts in Nicaragua by monitoring the cease-fire and separation of government and rebel forces. It already has been overseeing the surrender of some rebel arms. The U.S.-backed administration of President-elect Violeta Barrios de Chamorro is scheduled to take over Wednesday after 10 years of leftist Sandinista government. The opposition coalition she leads, the United National Opposition, won the Feb. 25 elections. Sandinista Interior Minister Tomas Borge on Friday bade farewell to thousands of police in an emotional ceremony. Borge, with tears in his eyes, said in an hourlong speech that he leaves office with his ``hands clean of blood and gold.'' In 10 years as head of Nicaragua's internal security, Borge said, ``we never tortured one prisoner.'' The Sandinista union, which represents about 70,000 workers, had threatened a general strike earlier this week if no agreement was reached on disarming the Contras. The demobilization accord signed Thursday established an immediate truce and called for the Contras to disband by June 10. The accord holds out the promise of peace after a war that killed 30,000 people, mostly civilians. President Daniel Ortega, has pledged to work for a smooth transition of power and tried to calm the labor unrest. ``These struggles are just, but the problems can't be resolved overnight,'' he said in a nationally broadcast speech Thursday night. He said it would be impossible to grant salary increases of up to 200 percent demanded by some workers. Telephone, water and brewery workers as well as teachers staged work stoppages Thursday. Health workers, university employees and workers at a number of state-owned companies have also staged brief strikes in the past week. Electrical workers and butchers in several provinces are threatening a weekend walkout, according to reports in pro-Sandinista newspapers.

DOC.HEAD: Northwest Flight Delayed After Passenger Accuses Pilot of Drinking
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS 4th graf pvs, `The woman ...,' with 2 grafs to UPDATE with woman's name, effort to get comment; picks up 5th graf pvs: `Miller said ...'
DOC.TEXT: A Northwest Airlines flight from Detroit to Atlanta was delayed nearly four hours when a pilot refused to fly the plane after a passenger accused him of being drunk, according to the airline. The pilot, who had been called in Thursday night after the scheduled pilot was delayed en route from Milwaukee, insisted that he be given an alcohol and drug test to prove he was sober, the Star Tribune reported today. The plane was delayed nearly four hours while another substitute pilot was procured. When the plane finally left, the passenger and her husband stayed behind because other passengers were enraged with them, Northwest spokesman Douglas Miller said Friday. The woman and her husband were ``subjected to quite a bit of verbal abuse from the other passengers and they elected not to take the flight,'' Miller said. The couple took another flight Friday morning. The woman was Ann Beaver of the Detroit suburb of Bloomfield Hills, said Northwest spokesman Bob Gibbons. A call to her home this morning was answered by the woman's stepson, Brad Beaver, who said she and her husband, Harvey, were in Atlanta on vacation and probably wouldn't be available until Sunday afternoon. Miller said the airline supports the pilot's actions. ``We feel he was justified,'' Miller said. The pilot, whose name was not released, had been called in by Northwest when the scheduled pilot was delayed, Miller said. Thursday's incident happened aboard Flight 497, due to leave Detroit at 8:30 p.m. The rest of the crew was ready to take off but the pilot hadn't arrived, Miller said, and with no captain available, Northwest called an off-duty pilot who lives in the Detroit area. While the passengers waited for the substitute to drive the 50 miles to the airport, the woman began talking to other passengers on the plane, saying the substitute was probably drunk or partying, Miller said. When the substitute pilot arrived, flight attendants told him of the woman's concerns and he took her aside and asked if she had a problem, Miller said. ``She indicated that she was concerned about his ability to fly the plane,'' Miller said. ``He then insisted that he be tested for alcohol and drugs because he didn't want to give any impression or credence to this woman's accusations.'' The pilot left the plane and went to a clinic, where samples of his blood and urine were taken. The blood test came back late Friday and showed no alcohol in his system, Miller said. The urine test was to be completed Monday. But because the tests and results were not available immediately Thursday, Northwest had to bring in another pilot to fly the plane, Miller said. Three Northwest pilots were arrested March 8 in Minneapolis, where they were accused of flying from Fargo, N.D. while drunk. They were fired by the airline and face state and federal charges.

DOC.HEAD: Iran's Foreign Minister Heads For New York for Talks at U.N.
DOC.TEXT: Iran's foreign minister left for New York Saturday to hold talks with U.N. Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar on reviving stalled peace talks with Iraq, the Islamic Republic News Agency reported. The report, monitored in Nicosia, quoted Foreign Minister Ali Akbar Velayati as saying that he and his Iraqi counterpart, Tarek Aziz, will meet separately with Perez de Cuellar. He said Perez de Cuellar requested the meetings in an effort to facilitate a new round of peace talks. Peace talks between Tehran and Baghdad started five days after a cease-fire on Aug. 20, 1988 halted eight years of hostilities between the two neighbors. But the talks stalled immediately, mainly over the question of priorities. Tehran wants Iraqi troops to withdraw from Iranian territory captured in the closing weeks of the war before the two sides discuss other points such as a prisoner exchange. Iraq wants priority given to clearing the Shatt-Al-Arab waterway, the confluence of the Tigris and the Euphrates rivers, which is its main outlet to the Persian Gulf. The waterway, which forms the border between the two states, has been closed since the early days of the war and is now blocked by wrecked ships and other war debris.

DOC.HEAD: Chad Claims New Attack on Rebel Forces
DOC.TEXT: Chadian forces attacked Libyan-backed rebels for the second time in three days, killing 103 guerrillas and taking 45 prisoner, the army claimed Saturday. The fighting took place Friday along the country's eastern border with Sudan in a reconnaissance operation following a battle Wednesday that left 517 rebels dead, the high command reported. There was no mention of government losses. A television journalist accompanying the Chadian troops said rebel commanders Moussa Haroun and Youssouf Adoum were among the prisoners. Chadian forces seized 27 pickup trucks equipped with multiple rocket launchers, machine guns or light cannon and destroyed 28 similar vehicles, the statement said. Numerous small arms were also captured. ``The frequency and ferocity of these battles demonstrates the excessive, demented obstinacy of Tripoli,'' the statement said. Chad says Libya supplies the rebel group, called the Legion, with arms and training. Libya denies the organization exists. The rebels normally cross into western Chad from bases in the lightly populated Darfur province in eastern Sudan, where the Khartoum government exercises virtually no control. Renewed fighting in the sporadic civil war broke out last month when rebels took government outposts at Bahai and Tine. Chadian troops later recaptured the positions. The battles have caused France to reinforce its garrisons in eastern Chad with 146 paratroopers, a second transport aircraft and a military surgical unit. France had been stationing about 1,000 troops in its former African colony. Libya, which once occupied most of northern Chad, was chased out three years ago in a series of defeats. Tripoli still claims as its own a strip of land on Chad's northern border, the Aouzou Strip. In a peace agreement signed last September, Libya and Chad reconfirmed their cease-fire, agreed to the exchange of prisoners of war and to submitting their territorial dispute to international arbitration.

DOC.HEAD: Walesa Wins Re-Election As Solidarity Chairman
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf `Delegates to...' with 1 graf to ADD that Leszek a diminutive form of Lech. Pickup 5th `The election...'
DOC.TEXT: Lech Walesa turned back two challengers today to win re-election as chairman of Solidarity, the union that toppled Communist hard-liners but is losing popularity while the country makes the painful switch to capitalism. Some members had claimed Walesa was undemocratic in his manner of running Solidarity. Walesa, the shipyard electrician who has held the top job since Solidarity's birth, received 77.5 percent of the valid votes, the union's election commission said. Delegates to the union's second national congress welcomed the announcement of the results by chanting ``Leszek, Leszek, Leszek,'' a diminutive form of Walesa's first name. The election for chairman took place on the third day of the congress, which is meeting in this Baltic port city, the birthplace of Solidarity during a nationwide strike wave in August 1980. The congress, scheduled to end Tuesday, is expected to outline the union's stand on the economic reform program of the Solidarity-led government. The reform is aimed at bringing the moribund economy back to life and transforming it from Communist central planning to a market-oriented system, but it has thrown about 200,000 people out of work. The delegates, selecting a leader to shape the union's role in post-Communist Poland, cast 362 balllots for Walesa, 52 for veteran activist Andrzej Slowik and 25 for Tomasz Wojcik, a little-known local strike leader. ``I am very happy but I am aware of what a cross, a union cross, a Polish cross, we are to bear,'' Walesa told the congress after his victory. ``What's before us is even more difficult than what is behind us ... We shall not waste the heritage of generations,'' he said. Walesa's re-election comes at a time when recent public opinion polls show the union losing popularity due to the Solidarity-led government's austerity measures. Walesa, who won the Nobel Peace Prize in 1983 for his leadership of Solidarity, remains popular. Internal union tensions, including charges that Walesa's methods are undemocratic, have surfaced during the congress debates. But none of Solidarity's best-known activists decided to challenge the charismatic Walesa. Walesa himself proposed the candidacy of Slowik, a bus driver and union leader from the central city of Lodz who has often advocated a more militant course for Solidarity. Slowik opposed any concessions to the Communists during the negotiations that led to the re-legalization of Solidarity in April 1989 after a seven-year ban. Wojcik, the other candidate, is a chemist who helped lead 1988 strikes against the then-Communist government in the Wroclaw region of southwest Poland. Solidarity-backed candidates swept partially free parliamentary elections nearly a year ago and took control of the government from the Communists, installing Tadeusz Mazowiecki, a former union adviser, as the East bloc's first non-Communist prime minister. Walesa on Friday rebuffed former union leaders who have charged him with undemocratic leadership. On Friday, Walesa won a vote of confidence from the delegates after delivering an impassioned defense of his 10 years as union chairman. ``I am not the wisest guy but we are wise because we now have a democracy,'' he said in an emotional address. Delegates responded by voting 357-1 in favor of a report on his leadership since Solidarity's last congress in the fall of 1981. There were 22 abstentions. Some delegates said they saw Walesa's leadership as essential to keeping Solidarity together. Only about 2.2 million of the 10 million members the union claimed in 1981 have joined since it won back its legal status a year ago.

DOC.HEAD: Expectations Modest for Chinese-Soviet Summit
DOC.TEXT: Premier Li Peng begins a trip to Moscow Monday that neither side expects to accomplish much beyond reaffirming the resumption of relations declared last May. Both countries, preoccupied with domestic issues, are eager to submerge past hostilities but recognize the limitations of what they can offer each other, economically or politically. Li's visit will be the first by a Chinese leader to the Soviet Union in 26 years. He is returning the visit of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, who came to Beijing in May 1989 for the first Chinese-Soviet summit in three decades. He is expected to sign a trade agreement, which presumably will have limited significance as the two countries move away from planned barter toward paying for goods in hard currency. Soviet sources said the two sides also would adopt principles for reducing military confrontation along their 4,300-mile border, but there would be no specifics on troop withdrawals. Trade has increased steadily since tensions began to ease in the mid-1980s, and reached the equivalent of $2.8 billion last year. That still is less than China's trade with Taiwan or South Korea, both anti-Communist states. Chinese trade policy is based on exporting to the West, to obtain hard currency for technology and machinery only the West can supply. Politically, it's a different world from 1960, when the two Communist giants split over ideology. In a recent interview with Soviet reporters, Li said ``there is no perfect model for developing socialism.'' He pledged that relations would continue even if the Soviets ``think socialism is no longer the ideal system,'' but said he saw no signs of the Soviet Union veering from the socialist road. Traditional suspicions have deepened in the past year, however, as the Soviet Union pursues reform while China's aging Marxists, after crushing the democracy movement, dig in for a long ideological siege. ``They don't openly criticize us,'' a Soviet official said, ``but God knows what they do in private.'' It is said that senior leader Deng Xiaoping called Gorbachev a ``revisionist'' in an internal report and that Chinese leaders are appalled by the Soviet Communist Party's renunciation of monopoly rule. Analysts say longstanding differences rule out any kind of alliance against the United States. One Western diplomat was asked about the strategic significance of Li's trip to Moscow and responded: ``Who the hell cares?'' Li's trip should be much smoother than the one in 1964, when Premier Chou En-lai met with Leonid I. Brezhnev and Alexei Kosygin in Moscow. Chou sat silently when others applauded Brezhnev's reference to detente with the West, and snubbed his hosts by laying a wreath on the tomb of Stalin, who was still a hero in China. Differences over Cambodia, the dismantling of communism in Eastern Europe and increased Soviet contacts with Taiwan probably will be kept private during this visit. The Chinese premier, who studied engineering in the Soviet Union in the 1950s and speaks some Russian, can point to real progress in relations during the past year. High-level party and military contacts have resumed and China's Communist Party newspaper soon will reopen its Moscow office, which was closed 30 years ago. The two countries now have 1,200 exchange students, compared to 10 in 1983. Xinhua, the official Chinese news agency, said the visit will have ``profound significance'' for peace in Asia and the world. It also will give the two old adversaries some peace of mind so they can tend to problems at home.

DOC.HEAD: Anti-Abortion Groups Get Cool Reception From Some Pro-Life Politicians
DOC.TEXT: Conventional wisdom says 1990 is not a good year to run for office as an anti-abortion candidate, but don't tell that to the National Right to Life Committee. The group is running high-profile campaigns for a number of candidates despite defections by former supporters, polls that show most voters are pro-choice and the possibility its efforts may galvanize the opposition. The committee is getting a wary welcome from some pro-life candidates who fear they may alienate voters if they emphasize their opposition to abortion. Florida Gov. Bob Martinez, who called a special legislative session on abortion but failed to push through a single anti-abortion bill, was honored last week at a Right to Life rally attended by 10,000 abortion opponents. The governor's pollster, David B. Hill, said the group ``just happened to be meeting in Tallahassee. ... He would not have taken a whole day (to see them) if it had been in Miami. This is not a priority.'' When Right to Life scheduled newspaper and radio ads earlier this year for Penny Pullen, an ardent anti-abortion veteran in the Illinois legislature, she asked that they be canceled. ``She didn't want to be perceived as a single-issue candidate,'' said Sandra Faucher, director of Right to Life's political action committee. Pullen lost the GOP primary by 31 votes and awaits a recount. It's unclear whether Pullen's race demonstrates the folly of rejecting one's anti-abortion allies, as Faucher claims. But it does illustrate the ambivalence the right-to-life movement is up against at the same time the National Abortion Rights Action League is basking in sudden popularity. ``We used to have to slip in through the back door,'' said NARAL executive director Kate Michelman. ``Now candidates are coming to us and we can't be in all the places we want to be.'' Sen. Tom Harkin, D-Iowa, returned a $10,000 contribution from NARAL in 1984. This year he's gone out of his way to contrast his pro-choice views with the strict anti-abortion stand held by his opponent, GOP Rep. Tom Tauke. NARAL is spending thousands of dollars on an independent campaign against Tauke, with no discouragement from Harkin. Pro-choice candidates have been putting more emphasis on their support for abortion rights since the Supreme Court last year gave states more authority to restrict abortion. The ruling energized pro-choice voters and gave them a few electoral victories, putting some muscle behind polls showing a majority of Americans oppose government involvement in the issue. Faucher and her pro-life allies lately have been shifting focus from their ultimate goal of a constitutional amendment outlawing abortion to less sweeping proposals that a majority of Americans appear to support. The committee is stressing opposition to taxpayer-funded, sex-selection and late-term abortions, and pushing parental notification requirements. ``You have to deal with what is possible legislatively,'' Faucher said. ``Roe vs. Wade has not been overturned. You cannot ban abortions anywhere.'' The pro-choice side sees this as backpedaling. ``They've retreated,'' said Harrison Hickman, who does polling for NARAL. ``When the other side has more soldiers than you do, a retreat is dealing with reality.'' NARAL's Michelman predicts the strategy won't work. ``The other side doesn't understand the polls,'' she said. ``When it comes to elections, what the voter wants to know is do you support the legal right of a woman to have an abortion.'' Both sides contend the opposition's advertising, mailings and phone bank efforts are counterproductive and invite a backlash. Faucher cites a NARAL ad suggesting that Iowa women could end up with fewer rights than Romanian women under pro-lifers such as Tauke, Gov. Terry Branstad and Democratic gubernatorial hopeful Tom Miller. She said the ad was ``so radical and extreme that the people of Iowa are just going to shuck that off as crazy feminists.'' On the other side, Harkin's camp welcomed a Right to Life ad campaign attacking his abortion position, saying they expected it to help Harkin more than Tauke. ``If the anti-choice forces want to attack us on that issue, that's fine,'' said Harkin's political director, Phil Roeder. Despite all the sound and fury from both sides, some strategists believe neither side will make an impact. Hill, who does polling for both Brandstad and Florida's Martinez, is one of them. ``It's beyond imagination that there would be an ad that would awaken somebody for the first time to what the governor's point of view is,'' Hill said of Martinez. As for Branstad, he said, ``His position is so well-known. It's already gone to the bottom line'' and his approval ratings are above 60 percent.

DOC.HEAD: The `Bonus March' Continues
DOC.TEXT: The struggle by World War I veterans for a small pension makes it seem as if the trench fighting never stopped. Each year brings a new assault on a seemingly impregnable position known as Capitol Hill. Each new wave is smaller, as those who escaped bullets, gas, influenza and shrapnel are felled by time. More than 4.5 million Americans served from 1917 to 1918 _ 2 million ``over there'' with Gen. John J. Pershing's American Expeditionary Force. Half a million or more risked their lives elsewhere making ``the world safe for Democracy,'' according to the organization Veterans of World War I. But these veterans _ the few that are left _ complain that they never were recognized for their service the way other veterans were. They say they were underpaid compared with their civilian counterparts who profited from war production, and the Depression devoured the meager benefits they were able to squeeze out of a prostrate economy. Most were too old and settled by the end of World War II to take advantage of the array of housing, educational and other benefits offered in the GI Bill of Rights. So they tried again last week. ``Please help us over the top,'' Don R. Pears, 90, of Buchanan, Mich., said at a joint hearing of the House and Senate Veterans Affairs committees. After receiving a brief extension of his allotted time to testify, Pears asked,``How many minutes do I have?'' Not too many. Five years ago the World War I veterans were 171,000 strong. In March 1989, there were 111,000. This past March there were 90,000, and their average age was close to 95. Three-quarters of the veterans are in hospitals or nursing homes, and the Department of Veterans Affairs estimates that by the turn of the century there will be 7,000 left; by the year 2010, fewer than 500. Some World War I veterans receive pensions based upon illness or poverty. But the veterans group seeks passage of any of the perennial handful of bills that would grant either a $10,000 lump sum or $150 a month for veterans simply because they served in the war. A smaller amount would go to widows over age 80. ``Several measures to provide a non-needs-based World War I pension have been introduced in previous years,'' Sen. Alan Cranston, D-Calif., and chairman of the Senate veterans committee, says in a form letter to constituents. ``However, favorable action has not been taken because of the great costs involved.'' Cranston says poor or sick World War I veterans, their widows or both receive a pension that exceeds by $1,530 a year the normal VA pension for veterans of other wars. The WWI veterans have gained at least one vocal ally in Congress. Rep. Glenn M. Anderson, D-Calif., last month delivered a long speech on the House floor in favor of H.R. 1918, one of the pension bills, picking up about 25 more sponsors to bring the total to 100. Anderson also wrote a letter last week to President Bush calling attention to the veterans. Doughboys were paid $1 a day and received $60 to muster out. They also won ``bonus'' payments over the vetoes of presidents Coolidge and Roosevelt. The first bonus was a 1925 bond redeemable in 1945. Congress freed the money in the 1930s, after veterans marched on Washington and were routed by their former officers and future World War II heroes _ Gen. Douglas MacArthur and Maj. George S. Patton. By then many of the bonds were in the hands of banks, since the paper had been used as collateral for loans during lean times, says Muriel Sue Parkhurst, executive director of the veterans group. ``That group of men is all gone,'' Gilmer T. Carter, 94, of Winston-Salem, N.C., said, referring to the ``Bonus Expeditionary Force,'' as the bonus marchers called themselves. The old, old men who came to Washington still act with grace and humor. They are more prone to talk about the bad food, cold nights, monotony and the absurdities of the soldier's life than Chateau-Thierry, Argonne-Meuse or Belleau Wood. Many who were in Washington never got that close to the front. ``I was assigned to the `general intermediate storage depot,''' Pears said in an interview. The G.I.S.D. patch he wore, however, came to stand for ``Going Insane Serving Democracy.'' Nor are any members of the ``last man'' clubs who annually gather to drink toasts until the last one dies. ``I think all the last men are gone already,'' said H. Louis Brooks, 91, of Toms River, N.J.

DOC.HEAD: Congress Asks How Many Consultants It Takes to Plant a Tree
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's plan for planting a billion trees is prompting members of Congress to ask why he needs $35 million to set up a foundation to accomplish that aim. Though no one questions the need for more trees, especially in urban areas, the foundation was described by one congressman as a pig in a poke. ``I envision that in today's world a lot of consultants would be brought in,'' said Rep. Harold Volkmer, D-Mo. Volkmer heads the House Agriculture subcommittee on forests which questioned Patricia Kearney, acting assistant agriculture secretary for natural resources, last week about the president's plan. The president's proposal seeks $175 million annually for five years to achieve the goal of planting a billion trees per year, she said. Of that amount, $35 million would be used by a foundation that would seek donations for tree-planting from private corporations and do promotions to encourage people to reforest, Kearney said. Though the names of the foundation members have not been released, a White House spokeswoman said the group would include 20 to 25 people whose leaders would be announced soon. The spokeswoman, who asked not be identified, said White House is moving forward with the foundation, despite the reluctance being voiced by Congress. During questioning by the House, Kearney said the details of the foundation had not been worked out. That caused Volkmer to lean forward and ask, ``Do you know what a pig in a poke is?'' The phrase refers to buying something you can't see. ``I never buy one,'' said Volkmer. ``I think there are some justifiable concerns about the public trust,'' Rep. Bruce Morrison, D-Conn., told Kearney. Rep. Jim Olin, D-Va., asked why the government's Forest Service couldn't do the work being suggested for the foundation. Kearney said the government couldn't do the private fund-raising envisioned as a duty of the group. The $35 million, she said, would leverage private dollars. Rep. Jim Jontz, D-Ind., said he supported the president's plan, but thought it should be incorporated into legislation he introduced that already has passed the House. That bill would provide the government's technical assistance to those who plant trees. ``You need a core of people to make sure the trees are being taken care of. We need to do more to understand the urban environment as a habitat for trees,'' Jontz said. John Rosenow, executive director of the National Arbor Day Foundation, has other objections. He said he supports the president's initiative and likes the money-raising aspect in the proposal, but ``the original proposal for the tree trust foundation as drafted would be a duplication of the Arbor Day Foundation.'' In a telephone interview Friday from his Lincoln, Neb., office, Rosenow said his organization's 800,000 members already work nationally with existing groups and agencies throughout the country to promote tree-planting. He is meeting with Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter next weekend to discuss his concerns, he said. Other organizations also are working around the country to get more trees in the ground. Fred Deneke, Forest Service assistant director for urban community forestry, said the momentum began to grow about 10 or 12 years ago. He said people began to realize that the loss of trees in the cities was not only an aesthetic problem but also causing urban areas to be hotter. A city is often 5 to 9 degrees hotter than outlying areas, he said. Deneke said ``street trees'' can bring down temperatures and take some of the burden off air conditioners during the summer, thereby saving precious fossil fuels. But, he said, only one such tree is being planted for every four being lost.

DOC.HEAD: Walesa Re-Elected As Solidarity Chairman
DOC.TEXT: Lech Walesa was re-elected as chairman of Solidarity by an overwhelming margin Saturday, winning a mandate to shape the union's future during the difficult transition from communism to capitalism. In his victory speech, Walesa said the once-outlawed union cannot rest on its laurels after removing the Communists from power, but must bear responsibility for the country's future. ``I am very happy but I am aware of what a cross, a union cross, a Polish cross, we are to bear,'' Walesa told delegates to Solidarity's second national congress. ``What's before us is even more difficult than what is behind us ... We shall not waste the heritage of generations,'' he said. Delegates welcomed Walesa's victory over two challengers with chants of ``Leszek, Leszek, Leszek,'' a diminutive of his first name. Walesa, the shipyard electrician who has led Solidarity since its birth in 1980, received 77.5 percent of the vote, the union's election commission said. The delegates, selecting a leader to shape the union's role in post-Communist Poland, cast 362 ballots for Walesa, 52 for veteran activist Andrzej Slowik and 25 for Tomasz Wojcik, a little-known local strike leader. Although Walesa was widely expected to win, he joked later that ``I was not that sure of the victory because I have done a lot of mischief during the 10 years (as chairman).'' The election took place on the third day of the congress, which is meeting in a sports hall in this Baltic port city, the birthplace of Solidarity during a nationwide strike wave in August 1980. The union held its last congress in the fall of 1981, just months before it was suppressed under martial law. The six-day congress, scheduled to end Tuesday, also will draw up a program determining Solidarity's future role now that it has gone from being an opposition movement to being part of the political establishment. Walesa's re-election comes as public opinion polls show the union losing popularity, due to economic hardships brought by the Solidarity-led government's shock treatment austerity program for the country's moribund economy. Some union members had criticized Walesa for being undemocratic in his means of running Solidarity, but none of the best-known union activists challenged him. In order to ensure a choice, Walesa himself proposed the candidacy of Slowik, a bus driver and union leader from the central city of Lodz who has often advocated a more militant course for the union. Slowik opposed any concessions to the Communists during the negotiations that led to the re-legalization of Solidarity in April 1989 after a seven-year ban. Wojcik, a chemist, helped lead 1988 strikes against the then-Communist government in the Wroclaw region in southwest Poland. In speeches before the balloting, Walesa and Slowik differed over a key issue facing Solidarity _ whether the union should step back from the political arena to emphasize its original trade union goals of defending workers' interests. Walesa advocated an ``intermediate program'' mixing political and trade union goals. But Slowik said Solidarity's only role should be as ``the leadership of a trade union, not a social movement or political party.'' The congress is expected to outline the union's stand on the government's economic reform program aimed at transforming Poland's centrally planned communist economy into a market-oriented capitalist system. In its initial stages, the reform's austerity measures have raised prices and thrown about 200,000 people out of work. Solidarity-backed candidates swept partially free parliamentary elections last June and took control of the government from the Communists, installing Tadeusz Mazowiecki, a former union adviser, as prime minister in the East bloc's first non-Communist government in almost 40 years. But only about 2.2 million of the 10 million members the union claimed in 1981 have joined since it won back its legal status a year ago. Some critics have accused Walesa of viewing the union chairmanship as only a stepping stone for an eventual bid for president of Poland. The post is currently held by Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the former Communist Party leader who led the December 1981 martial law crackdown that suppressed Solidarity. Earlier this month, Walesa raised the possibility of running for president, but then backed away. He said his remarks were meant only to spur the government to make the needed political and economic reforms.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Tanya Tucker said she is searching for a new assistant who won't contribute much more to her music than cutting down on one little voice in the background. The country singer and single mom says she needs a nanny to help her take care of 9-month-old daughter, Presley. ``I'm looking for a great woman who will come with me on the road and do her job and not get caught up in the star scene, which is what happened to the last one'' said Ms. Tucker, who performs at a Dallas rodeo Sunday. ``I want someone that doesn't care about anything but her. If there's a party going on, they don't need to be there.'' Ms. Tucker's new album, ``There's a Tennessee Woman,'' is scheduled to be released later this month.

Actress Ann Jillian, who underwent a double mastectomy, stands up to show women they can survive. ``We hear about the horror stories and they are true,'' said Jillian, who was here over the weekend to speak to a women's health seminar. ``We don't tend to hear about the success stories. There are legions of survivors out there.'' Jillian was diagnosed with breast cancer in 1985. ``Every time I see a woman or man in the audience who is moved I, of course, am right there with them,'' said Jillian, who starred this season in a NBC-TV comedy series named for her. ``I'll never be able to forget.''

Ask most 14-year-old girls to name a role model, and they might say Madonna or Paula Abdul. But Staci Keanan of the NBC series ``My Two Dads'' has a different focus. ``Jack Nicholson has all the qualities that can't be taught, like screen presence and the ability to laugh realistically. He's a pretty amazing guy and I want to be a character actor like him,'' Keanan said. Her first feature movie, ``Lisa,'' is a far cry from situation comedy. In the suspense film, which also stars Cheryl Ladd, Keanan attracts a serial killer's attention after making flirtatious crank calls. She identifies with the independent streak of her movie character, Keanan said in a recent interview. ``It's OK for your parents to put controls on you that are for your own good, but not ones that are just used to limit you. It's like moving to America and then being told you can't go west of the Mississippi.''

Actress Colleen Dewhurst gave a group of high school students a candid and sobering description of acting calling it ``a profession of rejection.'' ``You are told constantly you are wrong for it,'' said Ms. Dewhurst, best known for her portrayals of the passionate women in Eugene O'Neill's plays. A frequent joke at Equity, said the president of the Actors' Equity Association, is: ``Once an actress, always a waitress.'' Ms. Dewhurst recalled for the 20 drama students her own days as a struggling student 44 years ago at New York's American Academy of Dramatic Arts. ``It was more agony to get up in front of my peers than to audition in front of strangers,'' she said Friday. ``The greatest destroyer I saw at school was the bitterness,'' Ms. Dewhurst cautioned the students of the struggle to get work. Her break finally came when she was cast as Kate, in Joseph Papp's Shakespeare Festival production of ``The Taming of the Shrew.'' ``That was 14 years after I'd come to the city,'' she said. ``It's not easy, but it's worth it.''

Veteran actor Sir Michael Hordern made his opera debut at the age of 79 and confessed afterward he was terrified. But the audience at the London Coliseum cheered and applauded his performance Friday night as the bewigged and powdered Major Domo in Richard Strauss' ``Ariadne auf Nexos'' staged by the English National Opera. In the only non-singing role, Hordern had to contend with a full orchestra and move on a steeply sloping stage loaded with singers and dancers. ``I once had a part in Spenser's `Faerie Queene' at Covent Garden about 50 years ago but this is virtually my first opera part,'' he said sipping champagne in his dressing room afterward. ``I was terrified. I always have first-night nerves. The trouble is that with eight more performances, all spaced out, every time will seem like a first night. But the audience was very kind and made up for the terror.'' The renowned Shakespearean actor played King Lear in the PBS ``Shakespeare Hour'' in the United States in 1986 and also starred in the television version of John Mortimer's ``Paradise Postponed'' the same year.

Batman's television sidekick, Robin, wrote a $25,000 check that bounced, an architectural firm claims, but actor Burt Ward says they're the bad guys because they were asked to give it back and didn't. The check was written by the co-star of the 1960s television series to TRA Architects Inc. in Ponte Vedra Beach on Oct. 1, 1988. Ward planned to have the firm do work for him and asked TRA to hold the check while his company negotiated a land purchase in Arkansas, he said Friday by telephone from his Beverly Hills, Calif., office. When the land contract fell through, Ward said he asked TRA to return the check. He said he was not aware the company tried to cash the check until Friday and planned to contact his lawyer. ``It's really not nice,'' Ward said. Officials at TRA Architects declined to comment on the matter. TRA filed the complaint with the Jacksonville state attorney's office, which is in the wrong county. The case will be turned over to St. Johns County prosecutors, who handle Ponte Vedra Beach cases. ``We are going to have to let them pursue it,'' said Pamela Simpson, director of the worthless check division at the state attorney's office in Jacksonville.

DOC.HEAD: Financier, Arms Merchant Adnan Khashoggi Appears Unfazed by Trial
LaserPhoto NY29
DOC.TEXT: At 3 a.m., the telephone buzzes Adnan Khashoggi awake in his luxurious bedroom, 47 floors above Manhattan. The Saudi Arabian financier plugs the phone into a transmitter locked around his ankle, sends a signal and goes back to sleep. Most people who deal in billions of dollars and hobnob with presidents and kings might think it demeaning to be monitored so. But Khashoggi seems amused by this nightly ritual that lets authorities check his whereabouts outside U.S. District Court, where he is on trial with former Philippine first lady Imelda Marcos. ``I call it the government's wake-up service. It wakes me up in time for morning prayers,'' joked Khashoggi, a Moslem. Raising a pants leg to reveal the black, wristwatch-like gadget, he added: ``When this (trial) is over, I might go into selling these things. This one, I am going to auction off _ for charity.'' It wouldn't be the first time ``A.K.,'' as his intimates call him, found a business opportunity in an unexpected place. He has done that for years on his way to becoming one of the world's most famous citizens and, for a time, perhaps its richest. Despite a series of business setbacks in recent years, Khashoggi is so wealthy that numbers are almost irrelevant. ``Adnan would consider himself penniless if he was down to his last hundred million,'' says James Linn, his lawyer. Khashoggi, 54, is vague about his current worth but doubts that he ever was the world's richest man. He says that title belongs to his friend the Sultan of Brunei. His wealth may be best judged by his bail. He put up the required $10 million, but authorities said it was small change to Khashoggi, and feared he would forfeit it for freedom. He was released from jail only after King Fahd of Saudi Arabia sent a letter guaranteeing that he would not attempt to flee, and after he agreed to wear the monitoring device. In an interview at his lavish apartment, with its artworks by Dufy and Miro and its sweeping views of the city, Khashoggi described an investment portfolio that once ranged over 35 countries. ``In my heyday I used to earn $80 million to $100 million a year and probably spent, on this style of life, $40 million,'' he said. ``But when they say I am the world's richest man, how do they come to this conclusion? I don't have $10 billion in the bank.'' When a $600 million Salt Lake City project went bust in 1987, he lost $300 million. ``That was the beginning of the disaster stories. Because it was me, everybody thought I went bankrupt, but it was not true,'' he said. Khashoggi reportedly was a middleman and financier of the Iran-Contra affair, in which profits from secret U.S. arms sales to Iran were channeled to rebel groups fighting the Sandinista government of Nicaragua. In his opening statement at the trial, Linn tried to dispel the idea that there was something wrong with being an arms trader, saying all Khashoggi's arms dealings had U.S. and Saudi government approval. Khashoggi describes himself as an ``international salesman,'' and ``merchant banker.'' He insists there is nothing sinister or mysterious about what he does. ``I am a hard-working man, and I have to pay my bills,'' he said. ``I am just like you _ with a few extra zeros.'' Despite his wealth, Khashoggi takes the subway to and from court to avoid traffic. Last week, when the train stalled, he walked 29 blocks home; few passersby took notice of the short, portly man talking into a hand-held telephone as he strode up Park Avenue. In court, he dozes off occasionally as testimony focuses mainly on Mrs. Marcos' alleged financial misdeeds. The government claims she and her late husband, Ferdinand, looted their country's treasury of about $220 million, depositing some in secret Swiss bank accounts and spending more on lavish living and real estate purchases. Khashoggi is charged with mail fraud and obstruction of justice. It is alleged that he forged documents to help conceal the Marcoses ownership of four New York office buildings and an art collection bought with stolen funds.
