He concedes that he was ``foolish'' to get involved with the Marcoses, but contends he committed no crime because the document backdating occurred in 1985, the year before Marcos was ousted from power and a U.S. court froze all transactions involving the buildings. ``When you ask me why this trial is unfair, it is because they (the prosecutors) know all this,'' he said. ``Without me, they don't have a case. They want to get the Marcoses, by hook or by crook.'' Khashoggi said he believes Judge John F. Keenan eventually will dismiss the charges against him, but if not, he'll be acquitted by the jury. ``These people are not going to be unfair,'' he said. And he contended the trial is doing great damage to America's image in the Middle East. ``This case has become a symbol of fear,'' he said. ``I am trying to say, `Hey, guys, this is not America.' We will have our day in court and they will see that it is not America, but a corner street called New York.''

DOC.HEAD: Would-be Defense Chief Urges Caution in Military Cuts
DOC.TEXT: The walls of John Tower's downtown office hold daily reminders of the Cabinet post that escaped the grasp of the former senator and arms control negotiator. Both the swords from West Point and the photograph of President Bush with his first nominee to run the Pentagon testify to the time not too long ago when Tower, 64, thought he might become secretary of Defense. Tower's rejection in March 1989 by his former colleagues capped a rancorous period in the brief history of the Bush administration and the long tradition of Senate comity. Charges of womanizing and alcoholism were leveled at the former Texas senator, while Republicans were bitter in their accusations of Democratic partisanship. More than a year later, Tower remains on the fringes of defense work. Dividing his time between Dallas and Washington, he serves on Bush's Foreign Intelligence Advisory Board, teaches a course at Southern Methodist University on national security policy and does consulting. He doesn't consult for defense contractors. Tower's ties with them also prevented his confirmation. In an interview last week, Tower provided a hint of the defense budget he would have crafted in light of the revolutionary changes in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union. ``I worry a little bit that the budget is anticipating changes that are going to take place before they take place,'' said Tower, who sat across the table from the Soviets during the Reagan administration. ``We have not completed our negotiations in two important areas.'' Tower believes that the administration and Congress should wait until U.S.-Soviet treaties to reduce strategic weapons and conventional arms have been satisfactorily completed before military cuts are made. ``I get a little concerned about our, in effect, conceding an advantage to the other side by making unilateral reductions before mutual reductions have been negotiated,'' he said. The former chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee dismisses characterization as a Cold Warrior, and says he is optimistic about the prospects for a U.S. agreement with Moscow. His stand, however, is far closer to that of Defense Secretary Dick Cheney than several Republicans and Democrats in Congress. ``We have to continue our strategic modernization ... because the threat has not yet significantly diminished and because we are in the process of negotiating strategic arms reductions,'' Tower said. He favors development of the B-2 stealth bomber, describing it as essential to the modernization of the airborne leg of the triad and as a key element in the nuclear deterrent. Opposition to the radar-evading plane _ considered the most expensive in history at more than $530 million a copy _ is increasing in Congress. Tower acknowledges that the battle over the bat-winged bomber will be contentious. Although his support for the Strategic Defense Initiative came under attack from leading conservatives last year, he favors some type of anti-missile shield. ``I think it's prudent to proceed with deployment of at least a rudimentary SDI system,'' Tower said. ``Bear in mind that the Soviets do have in place an anti-ballistic missile system. We do not.'' This year is a transition year, according to Tower. Only after U.S.-Soviet treaties can the Pentagon set its sights on a military that emphasizes ``force projection capability rather than the maintenance of massive land armies and large numbers of strategic weapons,'' he said. On the dispute between Cheney and CIA Director William Webster over the level of the Soviet threat, Tower believes both are correct. ``I think it would be very difficult for a hardliner to turn back the clock,'' he said. ``However, the enormous military power of the Soviet Union has not diminished during the course of the Gorbachev regime. Perhaps in terms of numbers it has, but not in terms of capability.'' Tower won't comment directly on the Cheney military blueprint, explaining, ``I've not walked a mile in his moccasins.''

DOC.HEAD: New Hampshire Observes Unique `Fast Day'
DOC.TEXT: When New England's long winter starts surrendering to spring, New Hampshire's citizens get a special gift _ a long holiday weekend heralded in the heavens by Halley's Comet three centuries ago. The state of many onlys and firsts on Monday will once again be the only one to celebrate Fast Day. The holiday was originally a day for New Hampshire colonists to fast and pray for their ailing governor. Now it's the time when folks pack away snow tires and storm windows, bring out the baseball gloves and bats and lawn rakes, and shop the Fast Day sales. The first known fast day was observed by Massachusetts after the drought of 1622, but in New Hampshire, the practice dates from the 1680s, after the appearance of Halley's Comet was divined as a portent of the demise of the colony's first governor, John Cutts. When Cutts fell ill, citizens were urged to set aside March 17, 1681, to pray and fast for his recovery, a custom peculiar to New England in times of fear of impending catastrophe. In 1894, Massachusetts substituted its Fast Day with Patriots Day to memorialize the Revolutionary War. Massachusetts and Maine observe Patriots Day on the third Monday in April. That leaves New Hampshire with the only Fast Day, now marked on the fourth Monday of April. In New Hampshire, little is known about Cutts, other than that he was ``President of the Royal Province ... by grace of Charles II,'' was an immigrant from Wales, and sometimes spelled his name Cutt. Cutts was the richest merchant in Portsmouth, the colonial capital. On May 6, 1680, when he was 60, he had a foreboding of his death and wrote his will. By the following year, he was so ill that the colonial General Assembly declared a day of ``fasting, humiliation and prayer'' for his recovery. His death, the assembly feared, would ``occasion much trouble'' and noted ``that awful, portentous, blazing star, usually foreboding sore calamity'' _ the comet whose path was being plotted in England by the 25-year-old astronomer Edmund Halley. The special day didn't help Cutts, who died April 1, 1681, but his Fast Day lived on. Other things, however, have changed. Church attendance no longer is compulsory and citizens no longer must listen to sermons such as ``Three of the Public Evils of the Day: Public Education, Extravagance, Intemperance.'' Recreation no longer is forbidden and the 10-shilling fine against those taking part in ``labour, business or work of their ordinary calling'' was abolished long ago. Fast Day since has been transformed into a time of relaxation and recreation with extravagance of mercantile promotions rivaled only by Presidents Day sales. State offices have stayed open for the past five years, thanks to a contract provision that makes Fast Day a floating holiday that some state workers take at another time. But school is out and banks and some city and town offices close, leaving plenty of shoppers and rakers and ball players to enjoy the budding spring.

DOC.NOTE: EDS: ADDS 2 grafs after 6th with Baker phone call; picks up 7th pvs, Bush flew
DOC.HEAD: Bush Buys Time in Weighing U.S. Response to Soviet Crackdown
DOC.TEXT: President Bush is giving Mikhail Gorbachev a few more days to loosen the economic noose the Kremlin is tightening to keep Lithuania inside the Soviet Union. Bush set off fishing this morning, clad in a green shirt, camouflage pants, red cap and white satin Wyoming centennial jacket. ``Wish us luck,'' was the vacationing president's only comment to reporters as the party left on Florida Marine Patrol speedboats. On Friday the White House put Moscow on notice to expect a U.S. response early next week unless Gorbachev lets up against the rebellious republic. Bush himself said nothing during political speeches Friday in Birmingham, Ala., and Orlando, Fla., about the crisis threatening a setback for U.S.-Soviet relations. Asked as he toured Orlando's Sea World why he needed more time to frame a response, Bush said only, ``There's a lot of consultations going on right now.'' But amid reports the Soviets were intercepting food supplies and shutting off Lithuania's oil and gas, and eyewitness accounts of troopers seizing a printing plant in Vilnius, White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater decried what he called ``another unfortunate step'' in the Soviet economic crackdown. A senior U.S. official today said Secretary of State James Baker had had a telephone discussion about Lithuania with Soviet Foreign Minister Edouard Shevardnadze early Friday afternoon. A previous telephone conversation between the two was announced on Wednesday. Baker's consistent approach to the Soviets has been a call for a peaceful solution to the dispute with the maverick republic. Bush flew by helicopter from Homestead Air Force Base late Friday night after helping fill Republican coffers with more than $2 million in Birmingham and Orlando. He was accompanied by national security adviser Brent Scowcroft, Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady, Sen. Alan Simpson, R-Wyo., and Overseas Private Investment Corp. Chairman Fred Zeder, on hand to join the fishing expedition. Fitzwater, standing in a hotel driveway in Birmingham, said Bush had ``stepped up'' consultations with U.S. allies and would meet early next week with leaders of Congress before taking action. Administration officials reiterated that Bush was contemplating making the Soviets pay an economic price for the campaign to force the Baltic republic to retreat from its March 11 declaration of independence. Bush has been treading cautiously, trying to promote a peaceful dialogue that would respect the Lithuanians' right to self-determination and not cloud U.S.-Soviet relations and prospects for nuclear arms negotiations. Fitzwater said the United States still hopes ``this matter can be resolved in a responsible manner.'' He said the president would complete his deliberations ``early next week,'' and meet with lawmakers ``to discuss possible courses of action.'' ``I would assume that we would be prepared to announce actions fairly soon after that,'' the spokesman said. When asked why Bush needed more time to frame a response, Fitzwater replied, ``Because many of the actions that we would contemplate taking would involve other countries, would have international implications, and we therefore think it's important that we touch base with our allies on this issue.'' The administration already has signaled that the most likely U.S. action against Moscow would be economic, such as trade, rather than a slowdown in arms negotiations or discussions of regional disputes. Bush and Gorbachev agreed at the Malta summit last December on expanded commercial contacts that now stand in jeopardy. Asked if any sort of military reprisal were possible, Fitzwater said, ``We've said from the beginning that we didn't anticipate military involvement.'' Bush was spending the weekend at a private condominium on a stretch of Florida Keys 75 miles south of Miami. He was loudly applauded at the Florida GOP dinner in Orlando when he predicted that democracy will come to Cuba, which he called the ``one last hard-line holdout in the West.'' ``It will happen. The people of Cuba will be free. I guarantee you that,'' said Bush, who also criticized the Senate for not passing his $800 million emergency aid package for the new regimes in Panama and Nicaragua.

DOC.HEAD: Prime Minister Warns of New Flood of Immigrants to the West
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere said Saturday that a new wave of frustrated East Germans will head west unless their wages and pensions are valued at West German standards. In his toughest remarks yet on the issue, the East German leader said he would not back down from his demand that most East German marks be converted equally to West German marks as the nations are unified. ``As far as wages, salaries and pensions are concerned, it is not negotiable,'' he said in an joint interview on East and West German radio. West Germany's central bank has said most East German marks must be converted at a 2-1 exchange, and that an equal trade would erode the power of the mighty West German mark and result in higher interest rates and inflation. The nonconvertible East German mark is essentially worthless in free market economies. But de Maiziere said the 1-1 rate is needed to offset the effects of eliminating the vast price and rent subsidies of East Germany's former socialist government. He said that not granting the 1-1 conversion could result in a new flood of East Germans to the West. More than 500,000 East Germans have migrated to West Germany in the past year. Many left after the former Communist government opened the East German borders in November in an attempt to quell massive pro-democracy demonstrations. The protests brought down old Stalinist regime and de Maiziere was chosen prime minister after his party won the most votes in East Germany's first free elections on March 18. Chancellor Helmut Kohl said on Saturday that the West German mark will definitely become the currency of East Germany on July 2, the East German news agency ADN said. Both governments previously had set that date to merge their currencies. Kohl, during an appearance in Wolfsburg, West Germany, also said the currency exchange demands in East Germany will be taken into consideration during negotiations, ADN said. He also said that joint elections in a unified Germany could conceivably be held in the latter third of next year, but that he wouldn't seek to postpone the West German elections on Dec. 2, ADN said. Both Germanys say unification is inevitable, but there has been increased sniping in recent weeks over how to mesh East Germany's decaying socialist economy with the wealthy west. The two Germanys are to begin talks within two weeks on merging their economies as a prelude to eventual full unification. The government of West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl has been putting together its own proposal for a monetary union. In a report to be published on Monday, the West German magazine Der Spiegel said the Kohl government will in fact grant 1-1 exchanges on East German savings accounts of 5,000 marks (about $2,800) to 8,000 marks (about $4,700) or less. The report said some wages and pensions also would receive a 1-1 exchange. It said the conversion would cost about 40 billion marks ($23 billion) a year. A West German government spokesman, speaking on condition of anonymity, dismissed the Der Spiegel report as ``speculation.'' Both Germanys say they want to combine their economies by July 1. Talks involving the superpowers also are expected in the coming weeks on the strategic future of a united Germany.

DOC.HEAD: Truck, Bus Accidents Kill 14
DOC.TEXT: A bus collided head-on with a truck Saturday and another truck overturned with football revelers, killing a total of 14 people and injuring at least 54 others, news reports said. The bus-truck collision in Batang, central Java, 375 miles southeast of Jakarta, killed seven people and seriously injured eight, the daily Angkatan Bersenjata quoted police as saying. Police said a truck carrying 53 people after a football game crashed Friday in the village of Pontianak, 1,000 miles northeast of Jakarta. Seven were killed and 46 others were injured.

DOC.HEAD: Pre-Election Silence Observed Ahead of Crucial Vote
DOC.TEXT: Slovenia and Croatia, Communist Yugoslavia's wealthiest republics, observed a day of silence Saturday ahead of crucial elections that may determine the fate of this fragile Balkan country. In Croatia, voters will choose Sunday among more than 30 parties vying for parliamentary seats in the republic's first multiparty elections in 50 years. In Slovenia's second-round balloting, 1.4 million people who voted on April 8 will elect the state president and 65 remaining parliamentary deputies. Under existing law, all campaign activities stop a day before the elections to give citizens a chance to think about their decisions before voting. Slovenia and Croatia have liberal judiciaries and media, unlike Yugoslavia's largest republic of Serbia, and they are already pushing for closer ties with the West. If pro-independence forces win in both republics, they would move further away from Serbia's hard-line Communist leadership and could tear apart the loose federation of six republics and two autonomous provinces. Slovenian voters will choose between Milan Kucan, a reform Communist who steered the republic to a multiparty democracy, and Joze Pucnik, an advocate of Slovenian independence. Kucan won 44.6 percent of first-round voting in Slovenia, the most prosperous of Yugoslavia's republics. Pucnik, who heads the center-right DEMOS coalition, was second with 26.6 percent. DEMOS, an alliance of five opposition parties, won about 55 percent of the vote for the state legislature and, barring an upset, was expected to form the first non-Communist government in Yugoslavia since 1945. In Croatia, the second-largest republic behind Serbia, 16 representatives of the U.S. Republican and Democratic Parties will monitor the elections, said Milko Gajski, president of the local election commission. Three main political groupings and a host of smaller parties will field 1,706 candidates in Croatia's elections for 356 seats in the three-chamber state legislature. The three main contenders are the Croatian Democratic Union, the Coalition for National Accord and the reformed Communist Party. During a two-hour televised debate that officially marked the end of campaigning Friday, leaders of the three main groups delivered their final message to the electorate. ``The debate showed that the differences between us are slim on most issues,'' Anton Vujic of the centrist five-party Coalition. Differences center on whether Yugoslavia should become a confederation in which states would have ``full sovereign rights,'' favored by the center-right Croatian Democratic Union, or remain a federation, favored by the Communists. Critics in Serbia regularly accuse the Union of being ``extremist and fascist,'' and of planning to secede from Yugoslavia if they win a parliamentary majority. Earlier this month, the Yugoslav army warned that any attempt by Slovenia or Croatia to win independence from the rest of the country ``will be prevented.'' Mika Tripalo of Croatia's Coalition said his group advocates a compromise _ a ``state contract'' signed by all republics to provide for a small but efficient federal government. Pre-election surveys indicate the Communists _ now called the Party for Democratic Change _ are leading, with the Union in second place and the Coalition trailing third. The polls show, however, one-third of Croatia's 3.5 million registered voters are still undecided. Two other Yugoslav republics, Bosnia and Macedonia, have legalized opposition parties and are expected to schedule free elections soon. But in Serbia and Montenegro, the smallest republic, the ruling Communists have yet to legalize independent parties. Both still follow a one-party system and there is a strong Communist influence in the press, judiciary and other aspects of life. Polls there open in Slovenia at 7 a.m. and close at 7 p.m. In Croatia, polls are also open for 12 hours, starting at 8 a.m. First results in both republics are expected around midnight.

DOC.HEAD: Mom Pleads Guilty in 6-year-old Poison Death of Baby
DOC.TEXT: A woman pleaded guilty to killing her infant son by feeding him sulfuric acid and will testify that the boy's father planned the poisoning to collect damages from a baby-formula maker, prosecutors said. Sheila Smith, 27, said ``guilty'' in a soft voice Friday in making her plea to a first-degree murder charge in a convoluted case that has gone before the U.S. Supreme Court. Smith and Ricky Irby Sr., 29, were charged with murder in the death of their son Quinten Irby. Irby's trial is scheduled to begin April 30. Quinten was 3 months old when he was poisoned in May 1984. He lingered in a hospital for more than two years before dying Aug. 26, 1986, at the age of 2{. During Friday's hearing, Lake County prosecutor Matthew Chancey said Smith will testify that Irby told her on May 30, 1984, ``that he had a way to make some money, but it would involve hurting Quinten.'' At the time, Smith was on public aid, living with her parents in the town of North Chicago, and Irby was an unemployed auto worker. Later that evening, Chancey continued, ``Ricky Irby told Smith that he had messed with the milk. He mentioned acid.'' The next day, Quinten was hospitalized, and Irby produced an open can of formula and a bottle that proved to be tainted with sulfuric acid. Quinten's burns scarred his mouth and trachea. He had one lung removed, and remained on a respirator, apparently comatose, until his death 27 months later. Ingestion of sufuric acid was ruled to be the cause. After the boy died, Irby sued a baby formula manufacturer, but the suit was withdrawn before it went to trial. Under her plea bargain, Smith will escape a possible death penalty but could get up to 65 years in prison. Her sentencing is scheduled for June 29. A dispute over the handling of evidence in the case at one point led to the U.S. Supreme Court. The evidence was tested by toxicologist Joerg Pirl at a state crime laboratory in Chicago. But it and Pirl's case file were discovered missing in January 1985, well before the child died. At one point, Pirl underwent hypnosis in an effort to find the evidence, but the hypnotist later died, and Pirl could not recall what he had told the man, said Laureen Cahill Casey, a Lake County public defender representing Smith. Investigators later determined that the evidence had been destroyed accidentally by a lab clerical worker, and with no evidence, the case essentially was closed, Chancey said. It was reopened after a U.S. Supreme Court ruling in November 1988 that said evidence lost by accident does not preclude prosecution. Smith and Irby were charged with murdering their son in an indictment returned May 31, 1989. Both parents have been held on $1 million bail. The couple's older son, Ricky Irby Jr., 9, lives with Smith's mother.

DOC.HEAD: Scoutmaster Faces 126 Counts Of Sodomy
DOC.TEXT: A Boy Scout leader has been charged with 126 counts of sodomy, accused of having sex with members of his Scout troop at a summer camp during a three-year period, authorities said. Guy Sparks, 31, of Elmira was arraigned Friday in Lodi Town Court. Justice Howard Cunningham adjourned the case pending Seneca County grand jury action. Investigators said Sparks had sex with members of Boy Scout Troop 20 from Chemung County during summer trips to Camp Seneca in Lodi, about 40 miles southwest of Syracuse. The incidents took place from 1985 to 1988, police said. Sparks has been held in Chemung County jail on $10,000 bail since March 17, when he was charged with one sodomy count. Police say they are investigating further allegations that Sparks sexually abused Scouts during campouts in his Elmira back yard and at a camp in neighboring Schuyler County. Sparks was returned to Chemung County jail Friday after his arraignment. In Seneca County, Sparks faces 54 counts of second-degree sodomy and 72 counts of third-degree sodomy. An adult is charged with second-degree sodomy for having sex with children under 14. Third-degree sodomy involves having sex with children under 17.

DOC.HEAD: 200 Million Expected To Wave Green Flag for Planet Earth
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf, `Polls have ..., with 6 grafs to UPDATE with world events. Picks up 5th graf pvs, `More than eight...'.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos CX3, BK2, LaserColor
DOC.TEXT: An estimated 200 million people in villages, cities and state capitals in the United States and in 135 countries will wave the green flag for planet Earth on Sunday to celebrate the 20th anniversary of the first Earth Day. At last count, demonstrations, parades, concerts and festivals were planned in some 3,600 American communities, said Earth Day 1990, a coalition of groups helping to coordinate activities. ``Earth Day 1990's campaign clearly has struck a nerve in the American public and in people around the world,'' Denis Hayes, the group's chairman, said in a statement. ``People are tired of the failure of leadership from elected officials and corporate policy makers on environmental issues.'' Many countries celebrate the planet on June 5, the World Environment Day instituted by the United Nations, but many others have jumped on the Earth Day bandwagon. Some 10,000 South Koreans are expected to attend a rally Sunday called ``Korea Earth Day '90'' in central Seoul; in Japan, a festival will be held on a Tokyo Bay island built with landfill consisting mostly of the city's garbage. In Ireland, the group Earthwatch kicks off a week of events Sunday, including a children's parade through 11 Irish towns and a festival at Dublin's St. Stephen's Green park called ``Green on the Green.'' In Britain, activities range from a marathon to benefit rain forest preservation to an effort by mountain climbers to clear up debris left by previous climbers. Kuwait marks Earth Day as host to the Regional Organization for Protection of the Maritime Environment, a group of eight oil-producing countries. Czechoslovakia's events include a relay race Sunday that culminating atop Mount of St. Catherine near the East German border. President Vaclav Havel will symbolically plant a tree on Earth Day at the presidential estate in Lany. In the United States, polls have shown repeatedly that Americans say they will make sacrifices for a cleaner environment. More than eight in 10 Americans say they will separate their trash for recycling, give up plastic fast-food containers and needless packaging materials, and get their cars inspected annually to cut emissions, according to one of the latest surveys, a Wall Street Journal-NBC News poll released Friday. More than two-thirds of the respondents said they would pay up to $600 more for a less polluting car. That reflects a sharp change from a decade ago. In 1981, only 51 percent of those polled said that protecting the environment was more important than keeping prices down. Now 80 percent say they favor environmental protection over cost savings. The Earth Day celebrations will be as diverse as the groups sponsoring them. In Richmond, Va., four tons of household garbage will be dumped on a park lawn to provide a hands-on lesson in recycling. Students from the University of New Orleans will hold a jazz funeral for heavily polluted Lake Ponchartrain. In Georgia, prisoners planted more than 100,000 trees and shrubs in anticipation of Earth Day, and work began on a 110-mile canoe trail through Georgia's coastal marshes. ``We want this Earth Day to have an emphasis on things that will last,'' said Robert Kerr, senior vice president of the Georgia Conservancy. In New York City, a model of the Earth will rise where the ball usually falls on New Year's Eve to symbolize the beginning of the decade of the environment. A concert in Central Park will feature Hall and Oates, the B-52s, Carly Simon, Edie Brickel and others. Tom Cruise will be host of a gathering of politicians, conservationists and entertainers on Capitol Hill in Washington, D.C. Jane Alexander, Kevin Bacon, Bruce Hornsby, Branford Marsalis and Olivia Newton-John are among the celebrities who will be on hand. At 6 a.m., activists will hold a candlelight Mass wearing black shrouds and death masks outside the Y-12 nuclear weapons plant at Oak Ridge, Tenn., west of Knoxville. The point is to symbolize the destructiveness of war and the waste of resources that might otherwise be devoted to repairing the environment, organizers said. Earth Day's organizers hope it will kick off a new decade of environmental awareness, much as the original Earth Day in 1970 launched a decade that saw the creation of the Environmental Protection Agency and the passage of landmark environmental legislation. ``Earth Day 1990 must do the same _ promote enactment of a new, truly clean air act, accelerate a worldwide ban on CFCs (chlorofluorcarbons), encourage community groups to work with neighboring industry to prevent adverse health effects from industrial emissions, and involve individuals in the effort to improve the state of the environment,'' said Hayes. The government also must reduce dependence on fossil fuels by creating incentives for conservation and energy efficiency and by promoting research on alternative energy sources, he said. The initial Earth Day was conceived by Gaylord Nelson of The Wilderness Society, then a senator from Wisconsin, as an ``environmental teach-in'' modeled after the anti-Vietnam-war teach-ins of that era. On Friday, Nelson called on students at Indiana University to form a ``conservation generation.'' ``I don't want to have to come limping back here 20 years from now,'' said Nelson, 74, ``and have the embarrassing responsibility of telling your sons and daughters that you didn't do your duty.''

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Bought It, Britain Seized It, But What Is It?
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to ADD background on Iraq-Britain feud; EDITS to trim; No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: The British government says it's a gun, but speculation rages about Iraq's purpose in ordering eight massive steel tubes that were seized by British customs officers. Whatever device the tubes may have been for, it would be the world's largest: perhaps a cannon, a rocket launcher, an update of Germany's V-4 gun, an experiment, or just something to show off, various experts have suggested. The hypothetical weapon has also been described as too long, too flimsy and too vulnerable for a workable gun. ``I wouldn't say a gun, I think a launch system is the right thing to say,'' Christopher Foss, editor of Jane's Armor and Artillery, said in an interview Friday. ``I think the actual military mission is still hard to define.'' Customs officers seized the tubes, with an overall length of 131 feet, on April 12 in Middlesbrough. The manufacturer, Sheffield Forgemasters, and the Iraqi government insisted the tubes fit into a petrochemical plant. Iraq claims it is the target of a smear campaign orchestrated by Britain and Israel since last month's execution of a London-based journalist in Baghdad. Iraq had accused the Iranian-born man of being a spy. Other suspected weapons parts shipped from Britain to Iraq were intercepted Friday by customs officers in Greece and Turkey. Britain banned weapons shipments to Iran and Iraq when the two countries were at war and the ban remains in effect. Iraq has been aggressively developing weapons, including the new al-Abbas missile with a reported range of 560 miles, and a 210mm self-propelled gun unveiled last year. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein has said his arsenal includes chemical weapons. Iraq is also thought to be attempting to develop atomic weapons. The tubes seized on the dock in Middlesbrough were unlike any artillery now in use. The barrel was in eight pieces, not one, and had a smooth bore, devoid of the spiral rifling that is standard in artillery. ``There is no question it could be used as a barrel of a large artillery gun to fire a projectile of some considerable size,'' said Douglas Tweddle, chief customs investigator. But the bore, reported by customs officers to be 1000 mm, was nearly five times wider than the 203 mm self-propelled howitzers that are the largest in the U.S. and Soviet arsenals. Sheffield Forgemasters acknowledged that Space Research Corp. of Brussels, founded by cannon builder Gerald Bull, was involved in the project. The government says the tubes correspond to a Bull design, based on guns he helped build for the U.S.-Canadian High Altitude Research Project in the 1960s. The so-called HARP gun theoretically could fire a rocket-boosted shell 1,150 miles, the British journal Defense reported. Bull later founded Space Research in Vermont. He served a brief jail term in 1980 for violating the U.S. arms embargo against South Africa. Bull was found shot dead outside his apartment in Brussels on March 22. Robert Turp, a British ballistics consultant, said Bull would ``work for literally anyone who would give him the money and facilities to play with designs for big guns.'' At various times, Bull's clients reportedly included Israel and China as well as South Africa and Iraq. Defense reported in February that Iraq had shown interest in a gun, based on the HARP designs, ``capable of firing satellites or weapons into low earth orbit.'' Defense asked Bull's son, Michel, whether Space Research was involved. ``I cannot confirm this or discuss it,'' Bull was quoted as saying, but he confirmed Space Research had ``very close contacts in Iraq'' including military contracts. If the tubes seized in Britain were used as a conventional gun with a single explosive charge, ``it would blow itself to pieces,'' said Phillip Wright, chief executive of Sheffield Forgemasters. But experts say there are other ways to accelerate a projectile, and some have pointed to the German V-4 built in World War II. The V-4, according to the Imperial War Museum, was a 150mm gun built in 40 sections totaling 492 feet. The V-4 had 28 powder chambers that fired in rapid sequence as the projectile moved up the barrel. Built near Calais on the French side of the English Channel, the V-4 was bombed by the Royal Air Force before it could fire any of its 150-pound projectiles at London. The Independent, citing unidentified sources in Space Resaerch, said Forgemasters built parts for two barrels, each 492 feet long in 26 sections. Forgemasters has acknowledged shipping 44 pieces of tubing before the eight were seized.

DOC.HEAD: 1990 Off to a Warm Start
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS 4th graf pvs, That followed, to include average temperatures for January, February
DOC.TEXT: This year is off to the second warmest start on record, the federal Climate Analysis Center reports. Only 1921 was warmer during the first three months of the year, according to climate records going back to 1895. The nation's average temperature in March was just over 45 degrees Fahrenheit, making it the 10th warmest March on record, the center noted. That followed the nation's warmest January on record, with an average temperature of about 37 degrees, and the 15th warmest February, when temperatures averaged just above 37 degrees. The hot first quarter contrasts sharply with 1989, which went out with the 4th coldest December on record. Overall, 1989 was somewhat cooler than average in the United States. January's warm weather has been attributed to strong westerly winds that carried abundant moisture ashore in the Northwest and blocked cold air from moving south out of Canada during the month. That blocking prevented normal cold from developing and led to the record warm month. The first half of February was a continuation of January's weather pattern, but by mid-month weather began to look more normal, with severe outbreaks developing. March is usually a month of contrasts and this year was no exception. But a strong high pressure area kept the East warm early in the month before weakening and giving way to cool, damp weather at the end of the month. In mid-month, however, cold weather in the West was replaced by mild air moving inland from the Pacific Ocean.

DOC.HEAD: Breaking Up That Old Gang of His
DOC.TEXT: A wedding for ``Junior'' Gotti on Saturday? Hey, forget about it. The 26-year-old son of reputed mob boss John Gotti wasn't seen tying the knot at his neighborhood church Saturday afternoon, but that didn't stop assorted reporters and shutterbugs from staking out the building in anticipation of the rumored nuptials. The elder Gotti, who's used to the intense scrutiny of federal agents, was shadowed instead by local media types desperately seeking bridesmaids. But the press found no sign of the bride's family or the Gambino ``family'' at the Queens church. In fact, the only wedding Saturday at Our Lady of Grace Roman Catholic Church in Howard Beach featured two people whose phones were never even wiretapped (probably). Rumors were rampant last week that John A. ``Junior'' Gotti, whose dad is the reputed head of the nation's most powerful crime family, would be walking down the aisle Saturday with Kim Albanese. ``Married to the Mob,'' the tabloids yelled. The two have reportedly been dating for three years. Junior himself dismissed the reports. ``I don't know what you're talking about,'' he told the Daily News. ``You guys believe everything you hear?'' His dad, the ``Dapper Don,'' wasn't wearing a tux Saturday afternoon when he slipped out the back door of his Queens home and zipped over to his local hangout, the Bergin Hunt and Fish Club. If there was a wedding Saturday, the reception _ allegedly _ was to take place at the posh Helmsley Palace in Manhattan. A large Italian flag fluttering outside the building was the only thing even hinting at a bash for Junior. Law enforcement officials say that the younger Gotti followed his father in the Gambino family business last year. He is said to be president of a Brooklyn trucking company and he has been arrested several times in bar fights.

DOC.HEAD: European Community Asks Soviets to End Blockade of Lithuania
With AM-Lithuania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The European Community on Saturday called on Moscow to lift its expanding embargo on natural gas, oil and other shipments to Lithuania, denouncing the action as coercive. Foreign ministers attending the 12-nation meeting in Dublin urged immediate talks to end the crisis. However, wary of destabilizing Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the foreign ministers made no move to take action against Moscow and ignored a plea by the Baltic republic for full recognition as an independent state. Moscow has cut all oil and more than 80 percent of Lithuania's natural gas supply to get the republic to rescind its March 11 declaration of independence. Food and raw materials from Soviet sources were also being curtailed. The community nations ``believe measures of a coercive nature can make no contribution to the search for a solution through dialogue,'' the foreign ministers said in a joint declaration. Expressing grave concern, the community statement called for ``maximum restraint'' and said ``an outcome acceptable to all ... is possible only by means of discussion.'' It said the foreign ministers ``call on all concerned not to carry through measures which are inconsistent with this objective.'' Irish officials said the Irish ambassador to Moscow, Patrick McCabe, will present the European Community's demand for a lifting of the Lithuanian blockade to the Kremlin. The foreign ministers said they would meet again soon to review the situation, but gave no date. They also made no hint of plans to take action against the Soviet Union. Lithuanian Prime Minister Kazimiera Prunskiene had sent a message to the meeting calling on the European Community to recognize the independence of Lithuania. ``By recognizing Lithuania now, the EC can protest the Soviet Union's obstacles to normal trade relations, not only between us and the Soviet Union, but also between us and the rest of the world,'' Mrs. Prunskiene said. ``Other countries shouldn't leave us alone to solve this problem,'' she said in Copenhagen. Danish Foreign Minister Uffe Ellemann-Jensen, who met Mrs. Prunskiene in Copenhagen earlier Saturday, relayed her appeal to the Western alliance. A spokesman for the Irish government, which holds the current presidency of the community, said the ministers' reply ``is appropriate.'' ``It is not just important for the European Community to maintain good relations with the Soviet government,'' said the spokesman, speaking to reporters on condition of anonymity. ``It is important from Lithuania's own point of view that Gorbachev is not undermined.'' The Irish spokesman stressed the community was not calling on Lithuania to retract its declaration of independence. The one-day foreign ministers' meeting was called to prepare for a special European Community summit April 28 on incorporating East Germany into the Western trade bloc and a call by some members for political and economic union of the community by 1993. Ireland included Lithuania in the agenda at the last minute, marking the community's first move on Lithuania since Moscow began the blockade this week.

DOC.HEAD: County GOP in Maine Battles to Remove Accused Thief As Chairman
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 4 grafs to recast, CORRECT that arraignment is Friday, sted Wednesday, CORRECT spelling of Robertson. Picks up 5th graf pvs, `Volle first...'. Volle is pronounced like `volley'.
DOC.TEXT: Mutiny is stirring in Cumberland County among Republicans saddled by a chairman who broke the commandment: Thou shalt not criticize a party candidate. To make matters worse, Paul A. Volle was arrested on a $21.21 shoplifting charge but still refuses to step down as party chairman. GOP regulars called a special meeting Wednesday, with an eye to removing Volle before the state convention Friday, the same day he's to be arraigned in district court on the charge of stealing batteries and microcassettes from a supermarket. But no one is confident enough to predict victory against the conservative forces of Volle, a supporter of former television evangelist and presidential candidate Pat Robertson. Volle first angered his fellow partisans in January by saying Republican congressional candidate David Emery, a former U.S. representative who lost a 1982 Senate race to Sen. George J. Mitchell, should abandon his candidacy for the good of the party after flip-flopping from an anti-abortion position to pro-choice. Volle ``called a press conference and implied it was him speaking as the chairman of the Republican Central Committee,'' said Everett Giles, a former county GOP chairman. Many Republicans were outraged by that violation of the party's so-called 11th Commandment, which prohibits Republicans from running down Republicans. ``You don't speak evil of other Republicans,'' Giles said. Then, when Volle was arrested March 20 and charged with shoplifting, party regulars and state GOP Chairman Phil Jackson assumed Volle would step down. They were wrong. At an April 11 meeting called to determine Volle's status as chairman, he adamantly refused to quit. ``I have been asked to resign,'' Volle said. ``I refuse to do so.'' When Republican regulars moved to oust the chairman, Volle called the motion out of order. Volle's opponents admit they were outmaneuvered through Volle's superior use of the party bylaws. ``When you go to the ball, you'd better have your dancing shoes, and we didn't,'' said Tony Payne, a former Republican chairman for Portland. Cumberland County includes Portland and surrounding areas. ``We've had some difficulties in the process because Paul has used the procedures to shield himself from the debate,'' Payne said. ``He ruled that the motion that had been made was out of order. He made a number of arbitrary rulings. As chairman, he has that prerogative. We don't know what the dickens is going to transpire.'' They need a two-thirds vote by county party committee members to oust Volle at Wednesday's meeting. Part of Volle's power base includes his wife, Carolyn, the county party's secretary, who is accused by Volle's foes of withholding information on who the committee members are and which ones may vote in the special meeting. Neither Volle nor Mrs. Volle has returned several messages left on their telephone answering machine. But Volle's supporters note that he has not been proven guilty of anything. ``I guess the question is, `Why should he step down?''' said Carolyn Cosby, chairman of the Portland city GOP. ``He claims he is innocent, and I believe him. I think this has turned into some kind of a witchhunt.'' ``I have had a number of harassing phone calls since this has taken place,'' she said Saturday. ``Those people who are Paul Volle's supporters are being bothered.'' Volle has worked tirelessly for the party and helped form a strong slate of candidates for the November elections, she said. But Giles expressed concerns that if Volle survives the meeting Wednesday and appears at the state convention, he will become even further entrenched. At the 1988 state convention, Volle and other Robertson supporters tried to drag out a debate on an anti-abortion amendment but were muzzled by party regulars. Payne said Volle was able to gain power in the local party following the 1988 presidential election, when Payne led the local Republicans who favored George Bush and Volle led the backers of Robertson. Many party regulars backed Volle in an unsuccessful run for the state House. ``My concern at this juncture is that Paul's methodic wresting of power from mainstream Republicans has resulted in a party of Volle's group that is not inclusive,'' Payne said. ``It's a case of one guy who refuses to budge. It's an aberration of one personality.''

DOC.HEAD: Bright & Brief
DOC.TEXT: Derek Chung is a Spam fan with a mission _ to enlighten college students about ``this brick of pink meat.'' ``I just put up posters to get people here to eat more Spam,'' said Chung, a senior at Carnegie-Mellon University. ``I can never tell whether people will want to come over and actually eat the stuff.'' Chung spent Saturday trying to coerce 50 or so fellow students to sample the culinary delights of Spam at Spamfest VI, his sixth free love feast of canned luncheon meat, soda pop and Twinkies. Billed as the ``premier pork event of Carnegie Mellon,'' the minifestival at Chung's off-campus apartment draws the curious, the doubters and the determined. ``We don't sit around and eat Spam normally,'' said senior Barbara McQuain, 21, of Elkins, W.Va. ``But Derek makes things out of Spam that you wouldn't believe.'' There's Spam pizza, Spamwiches, macaroni and Spam, and the main staple, Spam and eggs. Chung said the all-time favorite is Spam Polynesian, in which the meat is sliced up, mixed with pineapple and served in a pineapple shell topped with apricot preserves ``to cover up some of the Spam flavor.'' ``Spam partially fills you up and partially you just don't want to eat much of it,'' said Chung, 20, of Dublin, Ohio. Bob Patterson, vice president at Geo. A. Hormel & Co. in Austin, Minn., said the company is used to jokes aimed at its most famous product, which was introduced in 1937 and was a staple of GIs during World War II. ``Even back in the early days people would joke about it as a ham that didn't pass its physical,'' he said. ``But you've got to laugh at yourself once in while.'' Chung has extolled the versatility of Spam since his freshman year, when he began serving it as a snack to members of his study group. He has held Spamfests twice a year since, but skipped last fall's fest because consumption had tapered off. ``I figured if I skipped one, people would be hungry enough to eat more next time,'' he said. ``I don't want leftovers.''

The proprietor of Aaron's Bait and Tackle has his window display set for the opening of the trout season, and he figures he has the competition beat this time. Aaron Weinberg is a veteran in business, after all _ even though he's only 10. He set up shop last fall with a small assortment of fishing gear at Northwest Auto Clinic, operated by his stepfather, Pat Osmon. ``I was open but not stable,'' Aaron recalled. ``Then nobody came in because they didn't know I was open.'' This time, he has a pink wooden fish twice as big as he is outside the shop, and Osmon has invested $3,500 in stock. Aaron said half the proceeds would go back into the business, a quarter into his pocket and a quarter into his college savings fund. He said he checked a local sporting goods store and a pharmacy that sells fishing tackle and found his own prices were lower. In addition, he said, he can offer advice on gear and lakes in the area. The state's lowland lakes fishing season opens Sunday. Howard Weinberg, the boy's father, said he began taking his son fishing more than six years ago. Last year, the youngster landed a 20-pound salmon on 10-pound test line. ``Whenever we go fishing, he always catches more,'' Weinberg said. ``He thinks like a fish. He knows where they're going to be.''

DOC.HEAD: Family: In Lieu of Flowers, Abstain An Hour From Alcohol
DOC.TEXT: The funeral director hestitated when he read the obituary Sally Clausen wrote for her husband: ``In lieu of flowers, his family requests one hour of abstinence of alcohol and smoking in his memory.'' Mrs. Clausen said she wrote the notice to help her husband of nearly 30 years send a message in death that he couldn't articulate in life. Donald J. Clausen, 60, died Friday, two days after collapsing of a heart attack at a Madison hospita . ``Donald was an abusive beer drinker and cigarette smoker, which resulted in his death. He was an alcoholic,'' Mrs. Clausen wrote. While her husband was dying, Mrs. Clausen said she lay in bed wondering what she could say about him. She said it dawned on her that she should tell the truth about a lifestyle that killed him. She telephoned her four children, who approved of the obituary and the message that smoking and alcohol abuse can kill, Mrs. Clausen said. Clausen, who began smoking when he was 13 years old, suffered from emphysema, she said. ``He was very often drunk,'' Mrs. Clausen said. ``Everybody knew what he was. He knew he was like that but couldn't change. He didn't want his children to be like that. He didn't have the know-how to send this message.'' Mrs. Clausen said she knows the obituary will catch people off guard, including funeral home director William O'Rourke, who read the message and asked if she was sure that was what she wanted to say. Although it was difficult, Mrs. Clausen said she did not waver in her decision. ``Maybe if we talk about this, more people will think about what they are doing,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Israel Remembers Jews Slain In Nazi Holocaust
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 13 grafs to UPDATE with Shamir quotes, details. Pickup 8th graf pvs, `Although Israel...'
DOC.TEXT: Flags were lowered and cafes and restaurants closed their doors late Saturday as Israelis began marking the most tragic event in Jewish history _ the loss of 6 million lives at the hands of the Nazis in World War II. Holocaust Day comes on the 27th day of the Hebrew lunar month of Nisan _ the timing set by Parliament to fall between the anniversary of the 1943 Warsaw Jewish Ghetto uprising against the Nazis and Israel's Independence Day. A 1961 law orders all places of entertainment shut for the holiday, which begins at sundown Saturday and ends 24 hours later. Some of the 300,000 Israelis who survived the Holocaust are now leading the nation. The family of Polish-born Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir was killed by the Nazis. The 800,000 children of victims have been named a ``second generation of victims.'' Although the shadow of the Holocaust still hovers over lives and deeply influences Israeli politics, its impact is diminishing. The annual 24-hour memorial is intended to remind them of the Jewish loss. ``Our generation ... is not free from prejudice and evil,'' Shamir told a solemn gathering of survivors and soldiers at Jerusalem's Yad Vashem Holocaust Memorial Saturday. ``Manifestations of anti-Semitism throughout the world use the winds of freedom to carry their lying voices ... history must not be forgotten.'' Concentration camp survivors and former Jewish fighters in the allied armies of World War II then lit six torches. As they did last year, hundreds of Israeli children and soldiers will recite lists of victims' names and ages at ceremonies across the country. The main opening ceremony for the name-reading will be held Sunday at Israel's Knesset, or parliament. Near Tel Aviv's Culture Hall, dozens of people stood in line and read names of slain relatives from a podium. ``My father Yisrael, my mother Ethel, my four brothers _ Mendel, Yehiel, Yosef and Baruch, and my two sisters,'' a small, elderly woman recited. Although Israel is preoccupied with its political crisis, weekend newspaper editions devoted much of their space to Holocaust stories and some interviewed Germans living in Israel. Rock music and newsreels were gradually replaced by solemn tunes and interviews with survivors in radio broadcasts. This year, Holocaust Day carries a unique meaning for Israel because of renewed ties with Eastern Europe. The Jewish state hopes that the warming in relations will enable it to gather new information on the Holocaust and reveal new names of Nazi war criminals. Some new names were found this year, like those of 223 Lithuanian and Polish war crime suspects who fled abroad after the war. Nazi-hunting groups plan to turn these names over to the United States, West Germany and Australia. The focus of Holocaust remembrance this year shifted to Poland, where some 4,000 Jewish teen-agers, including about 1,000 Israelis, are to conduct a one-mile ``March of the Living'' from Auschwitz to the Birkenau death camp. The march was to be broadcast live on Israeli television and radio. Earlier this week, the youths visited other death camp sites in Poland, where millions of Jews were killed in the Holocaust. Another Eastern European country, East Germany, this month made a major gesture of reconciliation gesture when its new, freely elected parliament apologized for the atrocities of the Nazi Holocaust. Israel had not maintained diplomatic ties with East Germany because that country's former Communist government refused to offer an apology.

DOC.HEAD: Pope, Havel Celebrate End To Communist Rule
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 11th pvs, `A rainy...' with 2 grafs to UPDATE with cloudburst during Mass. Picks up 12th pvs, `The pope...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto PRA1,2
DOC.TEXT: Pope John Paul II and President Vaclav Havel on Saturday celebrated Czechoslovakia's peaceful revolution that toppled the Communists, portraying it as a victory over spiritual darkness. Hundreds of thousands of faithful welcomed the Polish-born pontiff as he made his first visit to Eastern Europe since a pro-democracy tide ousted the region's hard-line Communist leaders last year. ``It is the first time I have seen so many believers around me, people who do not fear to show their faith,'' said 25-year-old Martin, a Franciscan studying for the priesthood in the Moravian city of Brno. The Roman Catholic leader's two-day trip, which includes stops in Velehrad and Bratislava on Sunday, was hastily arranged at Havel's request to allow John Paul to lend his support to democratic change. The pontiff was last in Eastern Europe in June 1987, when he visited Poland. In a prelude to the trip, the Vatican and Czechoslovakia restored diplomatic relations Thursday after a 40-year interruption. As barriers have fallen throughout Eastern Europe, the Vatican has moved quickly to forge ties with countries with centuries of Christian tradition. ``I daresay ... I am participating in a miracle,'' said Havel, a nominal Catholic who only last year was jailed by the hard-line Czechoslovak regime for his dissident activities. ``The messenger of love comes into a country devastated by the ideology of hatred; the living symbol of civilization comes into a country devastated by the rule of the uncivilized,'' he said. John Paul, speaking of the entire region, said communism had proved itself to be a ``tragic utopia'' because it denied the spiritual needs of man. He assailed what he called the ``violent application of a materialistic ideology'' that had paralyzed the nations of Eastern Europe. Huge crowds standing eight deep waited during sporadic thunderstorms to watch the pope's motorcade pass through the narrow cobblestoned streets leading to the spired gothic cathedral and Hradcany Castle, the presidential residence. An open-air Mass on the Letna Plain, for decades the site of staged Communist Party extravaganzas, drew an estimated half million people, including many from neighboring Poland waving Solidarity banners. The crowd stayed despite a raging 10-minute cloudburst and intermittent rain throughout the two-hour service. Nevertheless, the mood of the throng was cheerful for what was believed to be the biggest Mass in Czechoslovakia since before World War II. The pope turns 70 next month and who was making the 46th foreign pilgrimage of his pontificate. Referring to the country's former rulers, he said at the Mass, ``The ones who feared truth and freedom feared Christ.'' He urged Czechs and Slovaks to guard against divisive nationalist tensions. ``Now you have to unite and together step out into the future,'' he said. The papal speeches were filled with praise and encouragement for the Czechoslovak church and its 90-year-old leader Frantisek Tomasek, for whom the visit is a vindication of decades of resistance to Communist pressures. The church in Czechoslovakia suffered greater repression than anywhere in the Soviet bloc and up to 10 of its 13 dioceses have remained vacant for years. In a meeting with members of the clergy, John Paul told them he was paying tribute ``to all your suffering, to listen to you, to ackowledge publicly the value of the witnesses of your church, and to thank you for it.'' He cautioned them however against what he called ``viruses'' from the West, listing secularism, ``hedonistic consumerism'' and atheism. In the evening, the pope was scheduled to meet with Havel at Hradcany Castle and then deliver an address. On Sunday, he was to travel to Velehrad and Bratislava. In Velehrad, 1985 celebrations were held to honor saints Cyril and Methodius, who helped spread Christianity in the Slavic world. John Paul often deplored the state of the church in the East bloc and urged Roman Catholics in Czechoslovakia to remain firm in their faith. But soon after the regime led by Milos Jakes was toppled by Czechoslovakia's peaceful revolution last year, restrictions on the church were lifted and long-vacant bishops' posts were filled. Statistics released by the Vatican estimate 10.7 million Catholics live in Czechoslovakia, out of a population of 15.6 million.

DOC.HEAD: NASA, Scientists Eagerly Await Second Launch Attempt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to add launch time. Picks up 3rd graf, `We are...'. Should stand for AMs.
DOC.TEXT: Two weeks after a failed launch attempt, an improved Discovery is ready to embark on one of the most momentous shuttle missions, hoisting the Hubble Space Telescope high enough to behold the threshold of time. The countdown began Saturday afternoon for a launch set for 8:31 a.m. EDT Tuesday. If the launch goes on schedule and all else goes well, the first picture from Hubble could be available next weekend. ``We are as excited, maybe even more. You can cut it with a knife, incredible,'' said Eric Chaisson, senior scientist at the Space Telescope Science Institute at Johns Hopkins University in Baltimore. Nothing, at least scientifically, seems to have been lost as a result of the two-week wait, one of numerous delays plaguing the mission since its original 1983 launch date. As Chaisson remarked last week: ``The universe has been around for 15 billion years. A couple of weeks is not going to matter.'' ``The heavens look the same to me. The secrets are the same,'' Chaisson said. ``There's not a bit of difference,'' agreed Charles Pellerin Jr., NASA's director of astrophysics. ``I think the main point is the Hubble Space Telescope still is in perfect condition.'' The $1.5 billion telescope, the most expensive unmanned spacecraft ever built, rests safely inside Discovery's payload bay awaiting the Tuesday launch. If all goes well, Discovery will return to Edwards Air Force Base, Calif., on Sunday, April 29, with an empty payload bay. NASA said it may release its first telescope image from Hubble _ of an open star cluster in the constellation Carina _ as early as that same day. After the early test images are made and other preparatory work is done, Hubble is expected to start providing significant scientific data by satellite in a month or two. The observatory is considered the greatest advance in astronomy since Galileo first used a telescope in 1609. It also is considered by many at NASA to be the most important shuttle mission to date; it will be the 35th. The telescope is named for the late astronomer Edwin P. Hubble, who discovered during the 1920s the universe constantly is expanding. His work gave rise to the theory the universe was created by a tremendous explosion about 15 billion years ago. From its perch far above Earth's obstructing atmosphere, the telescope will be able to discern objects 50 times fainter and with 10 times greater clarity than the best ground-based observatory. Astronomers are counting on Hubble to unravel some of the mystery surrounding quasars, pulsars and black holes. By studying stars and galaxies so distant their light has been traveling to Earth for 14 billion years, they hope to determine the precise origin of the universe and learn whether other solar systems _ and life forms _ exist. ``If everything goes well, it's going to knock our socks off,'' Chaisson said. NASA's sole attempt to launch Discovery was halted four minutes before liftoff April 10 when one of the shuttle's three auxiliary power units failed. The 88-pound unit was replaced with a new one, the first time NASA ever had installed such a unit at the launch pad. The procedure went so smoothly the space agency decided last week to advance the launch to Tuesday, a day earlier than planned. Hubble's six nickel-hydrogen batteries were returned to the telescope Friday following 130 hours of recharging. The batteries will power Hubble from the time it is disconnected from Discovery's power system until its energy-collecting solar panels are deployed 380 miles above Earth, the highest a shuttle has ever gone. Astronaut Steven A. Hawley will use the shuttle's mechanical arm to lift the 24,250-pound telescope into space on the second day of the mission. The telescope's aperture door will be opened on the next to allow the first starlight to strike the mirror. Mission specialists Bruce McCandless II and Kathryn Sullivan, veteran spacewalkers, will leave the cabin to assist if necessary. The shuttle will follow Hubble from 40 miles away in case a problem develops and the telescope must be retrieved and returned to Earth. ``You can never eliminate those oddball quirks of fate or gremlins that may sneak up on any given day,'' Sullivan said. ``But those are very remote potentials I really suspect we won't encounter.'' In addition to the $1.5 billion cost of the telescope, $500 million has been spent to stockpile spare parts, train astronauts and develop computer software to operate the instrument. The European Space Agency contributed $250 million to the Hubble project and will get to use the telescope 15 percent of the time.

DOC.HEAD: Lithuania Closes Factories to Conserve Fuel, Seeks Compromise
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout with official saying economic blockade is total, help from West crucial, calling for EEC recognition. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A top Lithuanian official said Saturday that Moscow has clamped a full economic blockade on the Baltic republic and support from the West is crucial. Lithuania closed its factories for the day to conserve fuel and raw materials during the Kremlin embargo, designed to pressure the republic into rescinding its declaration of independence. Leaders of the republic said they are seeking a compromise with Moscow but no firm proposals are under discussion. Moscow has cut off all oil and more than 80 percent of Lithuania's natural gas supply since Wednesday. Officials said supplies of food products, tires, cable and other goods from Soviet sources also are being curtailed. Deputy Premier Romualdas Ozolas quoted a Soviet Ministry of Transportation directive as saying that nothing can be transported to Lithuania by railway. Later, he said the order apparently included truck traffic as well. Ozolas said Moscow's orders to stop land shipments to Lithuania and its diversion of shiploads of goods bound for the republic amounted to a full embargo. ``I believe a blockade has started, a total blockade, absolutely,'' he said. Some shipments, however, were still reaching Lithuania, he said. Moscow also is impounding checks to and from Lithuanian factories, putting a financial stranglehold on them, Ozolas said. Saturday is a normal working day in Lithuania but Ozolas said the majority of factories were not working. ``We decided not to waste our strength while it is not necessary,'' Ozolas said. Traffic on the streets of Vilnius, the capital, was light Saturday as motorists grappled with a rationing plan that limits them to about 7 gallons of gasoline a month. Ozolas said some factories still open Saturday would probably have to close down begining Monday because of shortages of fuel and raw materials. Ozolas said Lithuania would pay unemployment compensation to workers left unemployed. Lithuania voted March 11 to restore the independence it lost when it was forcibly annexed to the Soviet Union in 1940. Despite military and economic pressure, Lithuanians have refused to back off their declaration. Ozolas said Saturday that help from the West was crucial. ``We must get support from the West. If there is no alternate supply from the West, we'll be nothing,'' he said. ``If we don't find such alternate supplies, we can say our struggle is useless.'' The neighboring republic of Estonia, also moving toward independence, has offered aid to Lithuania and an agreement was expected to be reached late Saturday, Ozolas said. Estonia and Latvia were also annexed by Moscow in 1940. Also Saturday, a delegation from Lithuania arrived in Denmark for talks on obtaining oil to counteract the Soviet blockade. The delegation, led by Lithuanian Prime Minister Kazimiera Prunskiene, met Norwegian oil officials on Friday. ``Other countries shouldn't leave us alone to solve this problem,'' Mrs. Prunskiene said. She later appealed to European Community foreign ministers meeting in Dublin asking that they recognize Lithuania as a sovereign nation. They ignored her request but called on Moscow to lift its blockade. Lithuanian President Vytautas Landsbergis said Saturday that ``the threat we are facing is very great.'' Landsbergis told an opening session of a congress of the pro-independence movement Sajudis that Lithuania was searching for a compromise with Moscow, but there were no proposals on the table. Asked about reports Moscow was offering to negotiate if Lithuania delayed independence for two years, Landsbergis said: ``We haven't received any kind of proposal. We haven't debated this.'' But Landsbergis did say some compromise ``ideas'' have been raised in contacts with the Kremlin through middlemen. He did not elaborate. In a message to Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev late Friday, Lithuania's Supreme Council said the republic's independence could not harm the Soviet Union, and again expressed willingness to negotiate. The cable to Gorbachev demanded, however, that Soviet soldiers who stormed a Communist Party printing plant Friday afternoon and roughed up civilian guards be punished. The Sajudis congress was called to discuss changes in the 2-year-old movement's strategy. The Communist Party faction still loyal to the Kremlin opened a congress of its own in the Lithuanian capital Saturday. The official Tass news agency said the issue of independence, the termination of oil supplies and cutback of natural gas would be discussed by the 800 delegates. ``Landsbergis and Prunskiene must resign,'' said an ethnic Russian worker from the port of Klaipeda who identified himself only as Alexander. ``Landsbergis plays the balalaika well, but as a president, he's a zero,'' he said of the music professor-turned-politician. Communist Party chief Algirdas Brazauskas told Lithuania Friday that it must compromise on its pro-independence decisions or face critical shortages of oil and natural gas in two weeks. ``The price for independence must have limits,'' Brazauskas told the Lithuanian parliament. The energy embargo has left the republic with only 15 to 17 percent of the 18 million cubic meters of natural gas it uses daily for homes and industry. Lithuania, however, produces more meat and milk than it consumes and is in no danger of starving.

DOC.HEAD: Rapist Who Threw Victim in Pit Gets 20 Years
DOC.TEXT: A man who pleaded guilty to raping a young woman he imprisoned in a pit behind his mobile home will be imprisoned himself for 20 years. When William Richard Grau, 48, was sentenced Friday for kidnapping and six counts of rape, prosecutors told the judge how he dug the 4-foot-wide, 9-foot-deep pit complete with a small seat, plexiglass roof and electric fan. ``We can only speculate by the way he built it in secret, it was in contemplation of the act,'' Assistant State Attorney John Valenti said in outlining the case. The 19-year-old victim had lived with Grau and his two teen-age daughters on and off for nearly six years and even began calling him ``Dad.'' But nine hours of terror began the night of Jan. 9. The woman told Hillsborough County sheriff's deputies that she was dressing for a date when Grau burst in, wrapped her mouth, wrists and ankles with duct tape and raped her in a tent pitched in the back yard. After a struggle, he pushed her headfirst into the 9-foot-deep hole, but ultimately let her out only to rape her three more times. ``She stated she kept crying and he was crying and kept telling her he couldn't believe he was doing this to his baby, but he had already started and he would finish,'' according to the police report. Grau then let the woman go and told her, ``Do what you have to do.'' The retired Air Force technical sergeant who was managing a shopping mall video arcade had never been arrested before. In accordance with his plea agreement, Circuit Judge Susan Bucklew imposed the 20-year sentence to be followed by 20 years probation. Upon his release, Grau is to seek treatment as a sex offender and can have no contact with the victim or anyone under age 16.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands Line Streets For Pope Visit
With AM-Pope-Czechoslovakia
DOC.TEXT: It was the same street along which Communist rulers passed on their way into town, but it was a far different crowd that turned out Saturday to cheer Pope John Paul II. During Communist rule, the people of Prague were accustomed to lining Lenin Street, the long avenue leading from the airport to the center of town. Throngs of uninterested bystanders, bribed with an afternoon off work, would show up whenever a head of state came to town. But this time, tens of thousands of people needed no encouragement as they joyfully waited for hours to glimpse John Paul. It was his first visit to Eastern Europe since a pro-democracy tide toppled the region's hard-line Communist leaders last year. ``I was out here only once, when Gagarin was in Prague,'' said bystander Marie Martincova, referring to astronaut Yuri Gagarin.``He saw the stars, so I thought that was a good reason to say hello.'' She spent the entire morning standing in her Sunday best for the minute John Paul II would pass by in his white Popemobile, blessing the crowd. A policeman, waiting in a yellow van, declined to give his name but did not hide his relaxed mood. He said the crowd would not be a problem. ``After all, the people got what they wanted.'' Eva Hurychova, a 38-year-old bank accountant from Eastern Bohemia, traveled to Prague on an overnight train wearing a dress embroidered by her mother for special occasions. ``They (Communists) robbed us of 40 years of spiritual life and our generation should realize it is a great honor to witness this personally,'' Ms. Hurychova said. Street vendors rushed to sell the last color posters of the pope at a discount price as the motorcade moved toward Prague Castle. Hawkers sold everything from bananas and Hungarian salami to pictures of saints. Some 5,000 representatives of the country's clergy and handicapped Czechoslovaks received papal blessings inside the Gothic St.Vitus Cathedral. ``It is the first time I have seen so many believers around me, people who do not fear to show their faith,'' said 25-year-old Martin, a Franciscan. ``This would not have been possible several months ago,'' he said. Sitting in a wheelchair, Kveta Navratilova said the pope's visit was an important encouragment to all who want to make sure Czechoslovakia is not led astray on its journey to freedom. ``I hope the pope's visit will help stabilize the country before elections and unite all democratic forces so that we keep the Communists away from power for good,'' she added.

DOC.HEAD: Jury May Get Ford Case Early in Week
DOC.TEXT: The fate of U.S. Rep. Harold Ford likely will be in a trial jury's hands this week, three years after he was charged with taking political payoffs from two Tennessee bankers. Ford, a Memphis Democrat first elected to Congress in 1974, has been on trial since Feb. 12 on charges of conspiracy, bank and mail fraud. ``I want to say now that I expect a verdict of acquittal exonerating me from these charges,'' Ford said Friday after his lawyers wrapped up their closing arguments to the jury. Ford is on trial with three former aides of banker C.H. Butcher Jr., who is serving a 20-year prison sentence for bank fraud. Butcher and his brother, Jake, a two-time candidate for governor also serving a 20-year bank fraud sentence, once controlled the largest chain of banks in the state but their financial empire collapsed in 1983. Prosecutors say Ford got more than $1 million in loans from the Butchers between 1976 and 1982, many of them allegedly intended as political payoffs he was not expected to repay. Ford contends his Butcher loans totaled $650,000 and all of them have been settled. His co-defendants are accountant David Crabtree and lawyers Douglas Beaty and Karl Schledwitz, who are charged with helping him get and hide Butcher payoffs. The government called 29 witnesses in its case against Ford, and defense and prosecution lawyers filed more than 170 exhibits for the jury to review. The defense declined to call any witnesses. Ford said he spent more than 500 hours preparing his trial testimony but decided not to take the witness stand because he regarded the government's case as weak. Government witnesses outlined a complicated string of loans to Ford on which few if any payments were made prior to the Butcher banking collapse. ``While the Butchers were in control, he didn't have to repay anything,'' Assistant U.S. Attorney Dan Clancy said in his summation to the jury. In his closing statement, defense attorney William McDaniels said the government failed to show what services Ford supposedly supplied in exchange for Butcher payoffs. Prosecutors showed that Ford borrowed heavily and bought expensive home furnishings and a $35,000 car while deep in debt. They also showed that he supported Jake Butcher politically, but none of that means he broke the law, McDaniels said. ``If you are to remove a political leader for his politics or his lifestyle, that is to be done at the ballot box, not the jury box,'' he said. Ford, the only black in Tennessee's congressional delegation, contends the charges against him are the work of racist prosecutors who dislike him personally. Clancy, who has denied those allegations, has the opportunity Monday to address the jury for a final time.

DOC.HEAD: `Red Saturday' Not Such a Celebration for Lenin
DOC.TEXT: ``Red Saturday'' was different this year. Instead of mouthing the usual praises for Soviet-founder Vladimir I. Lenin on his birthday, party officials felt compelled to defend his honor and workers who voluntered for a day's labor sent their earnings to charity instead of the state budget. The April Saturday is a decades-old cross between spring cleaning and solemn obeisance to the Soviet founder on the eve of his birthday, which is Sunday. Millions of Soviets traditionally spend the day at their workplaces or tidying up yards and streets under intense social pressure to ``volunteer'' their labor. TV films, banners and assemblies mark Lenin's birthday. But this year, radical legislators who made major gains in Soviet regions in recent months have tried to turn the day into more of an ecological holiday than an ideological day. The image of Lenin on his 120th birthday has been severely tarnished as the Communist Party he founded loses ground in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union. On Friday night, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev complained of ``slander'' against Lenin in a speech to a holiday gala at the Bolshoi Theater. ``Disrespect for Lenin is unacceptable,'' he told the gathering. ``Slander, immoral and unfounded, ambitious and vulgar in its essence (is) directed at him as a person. (These are) foolish attempts to cast doubt on the nobility of his aims and purity of his thoughts.'' Gorbachev's remarks and a series of impassioned defenses of Lenin in the Soviet press this week appeared aimed largely at parliamentarian Yuri Afanasyev and his backers. Afanasyev, speaking to the Soviet Congress on March 12 in a session that was later broadcast nationwide, blamed Lenin for founding a policy of ``state terror,'' violence and lawlessness. Afanasyev shocked and infuriated many, but his remarks were no more outrageous than other recent published attacks on Lenin. Last year a Soviet journal reprinted a statement by exiled author Alexander Solzhenitsyn calling Lenin an ``evil person.'' There have also been suggestions that Lenin's embalmed body be removed from its mausoleum on Red Square and given a traditional burial. With the most sacrosanct of Soviet icons under attack, Lenin's champions have launched a broad defense. This month's edition of the journal Communist argued that Lenin should not be blamed for distortions of his thoughts, and proclaimed that ``Lenin needs protection today.'' In Arguments and Facts, the country's most popular newspaper, Lenin's niece argued that ``something should remain holy!'' In that interview, Olga Ulyanova also objected to vandalism against statues of Lenin in Eastern Europe. This week, deputies of the radical Moscow City Council raised proposals to remove the giant bust of Lenin from their assembly hall and to cancel his honorary possession of Deputy's Identity Card No. 1. The Moskovskaya Pravda newspaper condemned the proposals as ``blasphemous'' and lamented: ``It is so much easier to ruin traditions than to restore them, and we have ruined so many of them that much is impossible to restore.''
