In Leningrad, where the new city council is also dominated by radical reformers, deputies refused to pay for celebrations of Lenin's birthday and declared Saturday an ``ecological subbotnik,'' journalist Maxim Korzhov said. Residents of the city of Kiev, said popular movements have also called for subbotnik money to be spent on ecological measures, particularly the cleanup of areas contaminated by the 1986 Chernobyl nuclear power plant accident. Workers who put in extra hours Saturday insisted on earmarking the money for special charities, including orphanages and poor families, the official Soviet news agency Tass reported. Formerly, earnings from the day were given to the general state budget.

DOC.HEAD: Columbia Mission Marks First for Glasnost
With AM-Space Shuttle
DOC.TEXT: Space shuttle Columbia's flight next month to study the cosmos may be overshadowed by the Hubble Space Telescope's historic journey aboard Discovery, but it will mark a first for glasnost. Columbia's astronauts plan to talk via ham radio to two cosmonauts aboard the Soviet space station Mir. It's believed that will be the first time an American and Soviet spacecraft have exchanged direct radio communication, said Ronald A. Parise, a payload specialist who came up with the idea. Columbia's commander, Vance Brand, said he doesn't know yet what he will say during the brief conversation. But he imagines it will be rather ordinary chitchat free of political overtones. ``I think basically we'll just say, ``Hi. What are you doing over there? What sort of experiments are you working now. What do you expect to learn? How's your food?' '' he said during an interview Friday at Johnson Space Center. Brand wants to converse with the cosmonauts as much as possible in Russian. He was part of the Apollo-Soyuz mission in 1975 in which the crews of the American and Soviet spacecraft docked in space. Parise said he believes communications between the crews were handled through ground controllers on that joint mission. Brand is NASA's oldest active astronaut, 2{ weeks shy of his 59th birthday. ``I'm going to be prepared to do the best I can in Russian,'' he said. ``I'll have to drag out some books. I'm pretty rusty.'' Parise said it's impossible to know when the precedent-setting conversation will take place during Columbia's nine-day mission since NASA has not yet announced a new launch date. In addition, Mir frequently changes orbits, making it difficult to know when Columbia's seven astronauts will be able to make contact with the two cosmonauts who have been on board the station a few months, Parise said. Columbia originally was scheduled to lift off May 9 with a $100 million observatory called Astro that will measure ultraviolet radiation from stars, galaxies and quasars. But the date was pushed back at least a week by the delay in getting Discovery off the ground with the $1.5 billion Hubble Space Telescope, NASA's most expensive and complex payload that will orbit 380 miles above Earth for 15 years. Discovery is scheduled to lift off Tuesday, two weeks after its first launch attempt.

DOC.HEAD: Mandela Visits His Tribal Homeland
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela was given a spear, a ceremonial club and the buckskin of a tribal chieftan when he arrived Saturday in Transkei, the tribal homeland where he was born. ``I'm very happy to be home,'' the African National Congress leader told a crowd of several hundred uniformed ANC marshals at the airport in Umtata, capital of the homeland that South Africa declared an independent republic in 1976. Mandela received the presents during the airport welcoming ceremony. He was scheduled to address a rally on Sunday. Mandela, 71, said he had fond memories of hunting animals and swimming in rivers as a boy growing up in the village of Qunu, which he will visit during his six-day stay in Transkei. Mandela is the son of a chief of the royal Tembu clan of the Xhosa tribe. His father was adviser to the paramount chief and Mandela was raised as an aristocrat. He fled the homeland to avoid an arranged marriage, and became involved in politics in Johannesburg. Mandela, who was freed on Feb. 11 after spending more than 27 years in prison for subversion against the white-minority government, had not been to his homeland for 30 years. But in prison, he had many meetings with his relatives. He kept in contact with his cousin, Kaiser Matanzima, who became Transkei's first prime minister in 1976. Matanzima and his brother, George, lost their power in a series of coups in 1987 which resulted in a military government run by Maj. Gen. Bantu Holomisa, the army commander. South Africa has 10 tribal homelands, four of them designated as independent. The ANC and some other black organizations oppose the homeland system because it deprives the 28-million black majority of voting, residence, work and land ownership rights in the 87 percent of South Africa that is designated for 5 million whites. No foreign countries recognize the homelands as independent states. Mandela's first wife, Evelyn Mase Mandela, his son from that marriage, Makgatho, and several grandchildren, live in Transkei. During the visit, Mandela plans to visit the graves of seven relatives who died during his imprisonment.

DOC.HEAD: Proms Are Big Night Out for Grandmas
DOC.TEXT: Jeff Johnson told classmates he was taking a senior from out of town to the high school prom. He didn't tell them that ``senior'' was his grandmother. All eyes were on Johnson and his grandmother, Julia Burris, 78, of Park River, when they arrived at the prom with 34 other couples Friday night. They had a great time _ dining, dancing, and cruising Main Street in Bismarck about 30 miles away. ``It was wonderful,'' Mrs. Burris said Saturday. ``Nobody fainted when I walked in, and they were all very nice and friendly. I really enjoyed it.'' She and her grandson danced the first dance because the music was slow, she said. ``I didn't want to look ridiculous doing a fast one, so we left right after that,'' she said. ``We went to Bismarck for supper and then we cruised Main Street. We had fun. I didn't feel my age, that's for sure.'' In Maud, Okla., Eric Bundy went one better and asked his great grandmother, Nettie Crawford, 77, to go with him to his junior prom Saturday night. ``My great grandpa died in November. She's all alone now. She doesn't get out much, maybe just to go to Seminole or something.'' Maud is about 15 miles from Seminole and 60 miles southeast of Oklahoma City. Bundy was nervous about telling ``the guys.'' But ``they all thought it was pretty neat,'' he said. ``Nobody has ever done it before.'' Johnson said he decided to ask his grandmother to the prom because she won't be able to attend his May 20 graduation because of the graduation the same day of another grandchild. ``I was thinking of being a little different,'' he said. ``And then my grandma's not going to be able to come down for graduation, so I figured she could come for the prom, the next best thing.'' Mrs. Burris said at first she thought he was kidding. ``Are you sure you want to do that,'' she said she asked several times. Friends ``gave me a little more courage,'' when they told her it was an honor to be invited. Johnson is president of his school's National Honor Society, a member of its wrestling and track teams, and plays in the band. ``It's really funny how much people assume,'' Johnson said. When friends asked whether he and his date had a serious relationship, he replied: ``She's pretty special to me.''

DOC.HEAD: Post-Soccer Match Violence Injures Nearly 50
LaserPhoto BER1
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of right-wing ``skinheads'' and leftist extremists went on the rampage in East and West Berlin after a soccer game, injuring about 50 people, authorities said Saturday. West Berlin police said even worse violence was narrowly avoided late Friday when hundreds of rowdy soccer fans and neo-Nazi skinheads were dispersed in East Berlin before a leftist group arrived from West Berlin to confront them. Trouble started after a soccer match in East Berlin when a crowd of more than 300 youths, some wearing masks, fought each other in Alexanderplatz, East Berlin's main square. Some of the rioters shouted tributes to Adolf Hitler's 101st birthday, which was Friday, and attacked passersby, police said. East Berlin police chief Maj. Dirk Bachmann said that 700 police were deployed, including 350 in Alexanderplatz, according to the ADN news agency. He was quoted as saying that police action was hindered by the presence of 3,000 onlookers who refused to move away despite police appeals. Bachmann told ADN that eight people, including four policemen, were injured in the fracas. Two of the injured were in serious condition. He said 30 hooligans were arrested. ADN said the mob also stormed a homosexual bar, screaming ``Gays out!'' Amid cries of ``You know it's Adolf Hitler's birthday,'' they smashed windows and ransacked the club. Witnesses said some of the club's 15 guests suffered cuts and bruises in the fray, ADN said without elaborating. Police said about 300 West Berlin leftists and foreign residents gathered on the western side of the Berlin Wall after hearing radio reports of the violence in East Berlin, then went into East Berlin to confront the neo-Nazis. Since East Germany began dismantling the wall in November after the hard-line Communist government was toppled, passage between East and West Berlin has become routine. Police said that the leftist group returned to West Berlin within an hour after they discovered the right-wingers had already been dispersed. ``As they did not meet any right-wing extremists, they came back to vent their fury here,'' said West Berlin police spokesman Heinz Wiedemann. Wiedemann said the leftist mob hurled stones and bottles at police, built street barricades and smashed shop and car windows. He said 41 policemen were injured and 27 people were arrested. Wiedemann said at least three stores were looted in West Berlin's Kreuzberg district. There were no immediate estimates of the cost of the damage.

DOC.HEAD: Hundreds Evacuated After Fire at Grand Central
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to restore dropped word `hour.'
DOC.TEXT: A trash fire on Saturday at Grand Central Terminal sent smoke billowing into the main concourse and caused the evacuation of about 500 people, authorities said. The blaze began shortly after 10 a.m. under the cement slab of a platform on the station's upper level, said John Mulligan, spokesman for the Fire Department. He said the fire was under control within the hour. Homeless people were thought to be responsible for the fire, which police considered of suspicious origin because there should not be any debris under the platforms, said Dan Brucker, a spokesman for the Metro-North Railroad. ``Virtually all trash, rubbish fires, not only on the tracks but in such areas as steam tunnels, have been directly related to the homeless,'' Brucker said. They either have started the blazes or sparks from the electrified third rails have set their nests on fire, he said. Mulligan said electrical wiring and other debris was found under the track. Brucker said about 2,000 passengers were delayed for almost an hour. About 400 passengers were evacuated from four trains, and another 75 to 100 people were evacuated from nearby platforms or the main concourse, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Lithuania Looks Westward with Frustration
With AM-Lithuania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Lithuania is looking with increasingly frustration to the West for relief from Soviet embargoes of goods ranging from oil to fish. The West is limiting itself ``to lip service or statements of hope that the Soviets will start acting better,'' Lithuanian President Vytautas Landsbergis told reporters Saturday. ``This could have led Mr. Gorbachev to believe he could do whatever he wanted.'' No foreign nations officially recognized the Baltic republic after it declared its independence March 11. Lithuania's leaders continue looking westward for moral support if not material help as Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev shuts down fuel supply lines and Lithuanian factories are threatened with closing. On Saturday, Deputy Premier Romualdas Ozolas said Western help was critical as Moscow appeared to institute a virtual total blockade on supplies to the Baltic republic. He said a show of support could help Lithuania's cause by offering a challenge to Gorbachev. ``At least one oil tanker at the Soviet border might change the blockade situation radically,'' he said. But without such help, Lithuania will be ``closed down in a kind of prison, kept in the cold, suffering from food shortages, and it will be an interesting picture for the so-called free and democratic world,'' Landsbergis said. Ozolas said Friday the next two to three days would determine whether Lithuanian hopes pinned on the West were an illusion. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said President Bush will brief Congress next week on possible retaliation for the Kremlin's economic crackdown. The White House is ``increasingly concerned'' about reports of the economic pressure on Lithuania, Fitzwater said Friday. On Saturday, European Community foreign ministers ignored a Lithuanian request for oil but urged Gorbachev to call of the blockade. Western diplomats in Moscow have been reserved in their support of Lithuania. They have limited themselves to warning the Kremlin that growing cooperation with the West could be damaged if the Soviet Union continues to opt for confrontation instead of negotiations. One diplomat, who spoke on the condition he remain anonymous, said a ``major disruption'' in U.S.-Soviet relations could result. The United States and most Western governments never recognized the forcible annexation of Lithuania and its Baltic neighbors, Latvia and Estonia, by Josef Stalin's army in 1940. Lithuanians say for many years afterward they waited for the West to somehow come to their rescue. But it was the political changes unleashed by Gorbachev in his own country and Eastern Europe that gave Lithuania its chance. Lithuania sought official recognition from other countries when it declared independence. But in the delicate political atmosphere of improving East-West relations, Landsbergis said Lithuanians realized it probably would not be forthcoming immediately. ``When we started out on this form of struggle for independence, we did not expect quick help,'' he told the Supreme Council legislature on Friday. ``We made the decision because it was necessary, and everything else flows from this.'' Landsbergis said he did not believe that international trade union organizations would stand idle if Soviet sanctions throw thousands of Lithuanians out of work. Lithuanian officials acknowledge political recognition or an economic bailout is no long-term solution to Lithuania's dispute with the Soviet Union. Ozolas and Deputy Premier Algirdas Brazauskas, who is also the Communist Party chief, say that the only long-range solution is a political agreement with Moscow. Vitas Batsis, an 18-year-old student, said in an interview that the West is being too gentle with Gorbachev because it doesn't understands the Soviet Union. ``You have to live here to understand the Russians.''

DOC.HEAD: Heavy Rain Soaks Arkansas, West Virginia
DOC.TEXT: Showers and thunderstorms brought locally heavy rains to parts of West Virginia and Alabama on Saturday, but dry weather prevailed across much of the rest of the nation. Flash flood warnings issued for southern sections of central West Virginia's Randolph and Tucker counties, where as much as 2{ inches of rain fell. Muscle Shoals, Ala., got more than an inch of rain. Showers and thunderstorms extended from Arkansas to the southern Appalachians by afternoon, across southern Louisiana, and developed ahead of a cold front ranging from Virginia and eastern Kentucky to New England. Dry weather prevailed across the rest of the nation, with sunshine falling on the Great Plains, upper Mississippi Valley and the upper Great Lakes. Temperatures warmed into the 70s in the nation's midsection and the Southeast, with readings in the 80s in the Dakotas, southern Texas, southern Louisiana, southern Florida and the desert Southwest. The Northeast had highs in the 50s and 60s, and the northern Pacific coast reached the 50s at midday. Saturday morning's low reading for the Lower 48 was 28 degrees at Hibbing, Minn., and Sault Ste. Marie, Mich. In Barrow, Alaska, participants in the Piuraagiaqta, or spring festival, were warned to wear appropriate attire: Temperatures below zero and 30-mph winds pushed wind chill factors down to 50 degrees below zero. Sunday's forecast called for showers in the Northwest from Oregon to Washington and Montana. Thunderstorms were expected from Colorado to Texas, with a thin band extending from North Dakota to Minnesota. A crescent of thunderstorms also was predicted to curve northeast from southeast Mississippi, turning to showers in parts of North Carolina.

DOC.HEAD: Gadhafi Says He Would Have Rocketed New York in 1986
DOC.TEXT: Libyan leader Moammar Gadhafi called on Arab nations Saturday to develop nuclear weapons and said he would have fired missiles at New York had he possessed them when U.S. planes bombed Tripoli in 1986, Libya's news agency reported. ``If the world enjoys the missiles and bombs we must be able to enter this game,'' the official JANA news agency quoted him as saying. In the dispatch monitored in Rome, Col. Gadhafi said Arab nations need to have nuclear weapons as a deterrent ``within the next 20 years.'' ``If we had a deterrent force of missiles able to reach New York we would have directed them at that very momment,'' he was quoted as saying. ``We therefore must have this force so that the Americans and others would not think to attack us once again.'' The United States bombed Tripoli and Benghazi in 1986 in retaliation for what it called Libyan support for international terrorism. Gadhafi said Arab nations must work together so that ``the whole Arab world becomes one single country possessing a deterrent force (of) missiles and even nuclear bombs,'' JANA reported. ``If the world enjoys the missiles and bombs we must be able to enter this game,'' he was quoted as saying. Libya does not have an advanced nuclear program, but U.S. officials said earlier this year that Libya possesses factories to producing poison gas. There have also been repeated allegations that Iraq is attempting to produce nuclear weapons and already has medium-range missiles capable of launching nuclear warheads. On March 28, British customs officials seized U.S.-made parts for atomic bomb triggers bound for Iraq. Iraq has denied seeking a nuclear capability, but has confirmed that its arsenal includes chemical weapons. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein recently threatened to destroy half of Israel with chemical weapons if Israeli forces attacked his country.

DOC.HEAD: Russian-Born Leader Of Art Deco Dies at 97
LaserPhoto NY33
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 11 grafs to UPDATE with comments by gallery owner, CORRECTS spelling of given surname in 3rd and 10th grafs pvs to Tirtoff. Picks up 11th pvs, `Times were...' Minor editing to TIGHTEN.
DOC.TEXT: Erte, whose pioneering art deco designs in graphics, fashion and theater of the 1920s returned to popularity in recent years, died Saturday, a hospital spokesman said. He was 97. A spokesman at Paris' Cochin Hospital refused to disclose the cause of death. Friends said Erte was hospitalized in poor health three weeks ago after returning from a vacation on the Indian Ocean island of Mauritius. Erte _ whose real name was Romain de Tirtoff _ was known as a painter, sculptor, lithographer and set designer. He designed costumes for the legendary dancer Anna Pavlova and the performer-spy Mata Hari. The prolific artist designed every cover of Harper's Bazaar from 1915 to 1936. His most recent project was to design the sets for the Broadway musical ``Stardust.'' Some of his other major designs for sets and costumes included Debussy's ``Pelleas et Melisande'' and Racine's ``Phedre.'' He was also well-known for the opulent clothes and sets he designed for George White's ``Scandals,'' the Ziegfeld Follies and the Folies Bergere. ``He was just a genius,'' said Harris Shapiro, president of the Dyansen Corp. gallery chain in an interview in Los Angeles. ``I think history will reflect a few years from now that he was one of the greatest artists of the 20th century.'' He helped pioneer art deco designs. The style, derived from cubism, is characterized by slender forms and straight lines expressive of modern technology during the 1920s and 1930s. It _ and Erte _ regained popularity beginning in the mid-1960s. Born Nov. 23, 1892 in St. Petersburg, Russia, Erte decided to be an artist from the moment he could use colored pencils. ``I was interested in fashion and even sketched a dress for my mother when I was about five,'' he said. The family expected him to follow in the tradition of serving in the Russian navy, but Erte went to Paris at age 19 to study art and changed his name from Tirtoff to Erte. Times were hard, but he loved Paris, and later his parents and sister joined him during the Russian Revolution. A second-rate French seamstress had meanwhile hired and fired him, saying he would never succeed in art or fashion. But he was soon working for the great designer Paul Poiret. Later came a major contract with William Randolph Hearst and Harper's Bazaar, which shot Erte to fame across the Atlantic as perhaps the leading star of art deco. About 1925 he began work on what became probably his best-known works, his alphabet designs. The 26-part series took him nearly 40 years to complete. The alphabet features the Erte woman: festooned with jewels and trailing feathers and furs. Often, at the end of a diamond-studded leash, was the ultimate art deco fur _ a leopard or panther. Erte became a French citizen and lived in Paris most of his life, but once said ``I am probably better known in the States.'' The United States often honored him with big retrospective shows _ including one at the Smithsonian Institution and at big galleries all over the country during his 90th year. In the postwar period, his reputation faded and his work was dismissed as kitsch. However, in the mid-1960s he was rediscovered. Diana Vreeland, the former Vogue editor, declared that no one in the 20th century had a greater influence on fashion. Erte's designs, graphics and sculptures now command respectable prices at top galleries. The Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York has more than 200 Erte drawings and paintings in its collection. In later years, he spent several months a year in Barbados and Majorca, where he had many of his sculptures cast. In Paris, he lived comfortably but modestly in a flat near the Bois de Boulogne with a view of the Eiffel Tower. Always appearing trim and elegant, even past 90, Erte kept fit by walking long distances. But he once said he didn't start exercising until he was 70. ``I drink and eat what I like, smoke a little bit,'' said the artist, who looked fit at a birthday party at Maxim's last November hosted by fashion designer Pierre Cardin. A lover of nature, Erte surrounded himself with natural forms like seashells and living things _ including a couple of aristocratic Burmese cats and at least eight turtle doves in a glass cage. Funeral arrangements were not immediately known. Erte was never married and had no known survivors.

DOC.HEAD: Son of Reputed Mob Leader Surfaces in Wedding Clothes
DOC.TEXT: Eds: SUBS 4th graf to CLARIFY it was father who was followed by reporters; SUBS 5th graf to restore dropped word `whose.'

``Junior'' Gotti, son of reputed mob boss John Gotti, gave the press the slip at the church where he was expected to be married Saturday, but was spotted at a hotel looking very much the groom. Clad in a simple black tuxedo and black tie and accompanied by a bride in an ornate wedding gown with train and boquet, John A. ``Junior'' Gotti arrived at the Helmsley Palace Hotel about 5:15 p.m. Gotti had fooled and eluded assorted reporters and shutterbugs who staked out his neighborhood church Saturday afternoon. The elder Gotti, who's used to the intense scrutiny of federal agents, was shadowed instead by local media types desperately seeking bridesmaids. But the press found no sign of the bride's family or the Gambino Family at Our Lady of Grace Roman Catholic Church in Queens. Rumors were rampant this week that the younger Gotti, whose dad is the reputed head of the nation's most powerful crime family, would be walking down the aisle Saturday with Kim Albanese. The two have been dating for three years, friends say. Junior himself dismissed the reports. ``I don't know what you're talking about,'' he told the Daily News. ``You guys believe everything you hear?'' His dad, the ``Dapper Don,'' wasn't wearing a tux Saturday afternoon when he slipped out the back door of his Queens home and zipped over to his local hangout, the Bergin Hunt and Fish Club. At the Helmsley, a large Italian flag fluttering outside the building was the only thing even hinting at a bash for Junior. Law enforcement officials say that the younger Gotti followed his father in the Gambino family business last year. He is 26 and is said to be president of a Brooklyn trucking company; he has been arrested several times in bar fights.

DOC.HEAD: Son of Heart Recipient Needs Same Surgery
DOC.TEXT: Penny Maple has promoted organ donations ever since she became the first woman to undergo a heart transplant in Michigan five years ago. Now she hopes for a donor heart that may save her critically ill son. Maple's son, Tom Van Buren, entered Bloggett Memorial Medical Center a month ago with a worsening case of cardiomyopathy, the same deterioration of the heart that she suffered. Maple and Van Buren, 29, are fighting an uphill battle to promote organ donations in Michigan. According to the Organ Procurement Agency of Michigan, the number of donated organs has remained at about 400 every year since 1986. But as of January, 751 patients were waiting to undergo transplants. ``It's ridiculous,'' Van Buren said. ``Every day in Michigan somebody dies who could be a donor and help me or somebody else. It's such a shame people are ignorant of the need for their organs.'' ``I think there's concern and interest, but there's a lot of apathy,'' Dr. William LaPenna, a cardiologist at Blodgett, said of the lack of donors. ``People don't realize this can happen to anybody. It can happen to people in your family too.'' Because his heart is so diseased, Van Buren was moved to the top of a list of 60 people in Michigan awaiting a donor heart. He takes medication to keep his heart beating and will undergo the same operation his mother underwent when she was 57. ``We were taken back so completely that another member of the family could have this happen,'' said Maple, who waited 6{ weeks for a heart. ``It's almost like somebody wrote a story and wanted to throw in all the punches.'' ``This is a whole new ball game,'' Maple said of her son's condition. ``I'm the one who can't do anything, the one who looks down through this window, wondering how long he's going to be able to breathe OK.'' Maple realizes that as she waits along with her ailing son for the surgery that saved her life and may save his. ``I don't know whether it's a gift or a sentence,'' she said. ``When you get this heart, you want to take care of it every single day and get every minute you can out of it.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Goes Fishing While Watching Lithuania Developments
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Inserts graf 7, ``The group xxx to update with Bush return
DOC.TEXT: On a picture-perfect day, President Bush went fishing in the Florida Keys on Saturday as the administration continued its wait-and-see approach toward Moscow's economic squeeze on Lithuania. ``Wish us luck'' the vacationing president called to onlookers as his party pulled away from shore on Florida Marine Patrol speedboats for a daylong fishing expedition. The sun was bright and the weather was warm. Bush, clad in a green shirt, camouflage pants, red cap and white satin Wyoming centennial jacket, was accompanied by Brent Scowcroft, his national security adviser. His other fishing buddies were Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady, Sen. Alan Simpson, R-Wyo., and Overseas Private Investment Corp. Chairman Fred Zeder. Bush has been coming to this sportfishing haven for years, angling for bonefish and tarpon in the sand flats and coral reefs. The group was gone about eight hours, but Bush said they only caught a few small fish. He went jogging before dinner. As the president relaxed, his administration continued consultations with allies about possible action against the Kremlin for its coercion of Lithuania, which is struggling to break away from Soviet control. White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said Bush would not be making any calls himself Saturday, leaving that assignment to other officials. A senior U.S. official Saturday said Secretary of State James A. Baker III had had a telephone discussion about Lithuania with Soviet Foreign Minister Edouard Shevardnadze early Friday afternoon. A previous telephone conversation between the two was announced on Wednesday. Baker's consistent approach to the Soviets has been a call for a peaceful solution to the dispute with the maverick republic. But the administration, moved by escalating Soviet pressure on Lithuania, has raised the prospect that Bush will announce some steps against Moscow this week. The most likely course of action is in the commercial field, such as suspending talks aimed at a trade agreement or reversing course toward giving Moscow favorable trade status. However, Bush has given Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev at least several days of breathing room to reconsider his tactics. After returning to Washington on Sunday night, Bush is to meet early in the week with congressional leaders to discuss possible courses of action. Fitzwater, talking with reporters at a resort hotel, said he could not provide any new information, beyond his statement Friday that the United States was increasingly concerned by developments in Lithuania and that Bush would meet with lawmakers. Officials said they did not know when that meeting would take place, although the president has a regularly scheduled meeting on Tuesday with members of Congress. Leaving room for Moscow to reverse course, Fitzwater refused to say Saturday whether Gorbachev had already crossed the line that would trigger some form of retaliation. ``We're still consulting,'' he said. On Friday, the spokesman had said ``I would assume that we would be prepared to announce actions fairly soon'' after Bush meets with members of Congress.

DOC.HEAD: Vital Statistics on F-117A Stealth Fighter
With AM-Stealth Fighter
DOC.TEXT: Here are some statistics from the Air Force on the F-117A stealth fighter: Wingspan: 43 feet, four inches. Length: 65 feet, 11 inches. Height: 12 feet, five inches. Weight: 26 tons. Power: Two engines. Cost: $42.6 million. Mission: ``A single-seat fighter designed to penetrate dense-threat environments and attack high-value targets with pinpoint accuracy.''

DOC.HEAD: Local Uprising Leaders Cancel Strike Orders
DOC.TEXT: Palestinian uprising leaders in the largest town in the Israeli-occupied West Bank on Saturday canceled an order from the rebellion's clandestine leadership for a two-day general strike, Arab reports said. The orders for a work stoppage on Sunday and Monday were contained in a leaflet distributed this week by the Unified National Leadership of the Uprising, which closely identifies with the PLO. However, activists in Nablus issued their own leaflet Saturday, calling off the strike because of ``special conditions'' in the city of 120,000, a Palestinian journalist said. He said it was the first time that Nablus leaders canceled strike orders from the unified leadership. Strike days occasionally have been canceled in smaller towns and villages, but never in Nablus, a stronghold of Palestinian nationalism. Arab reports said the leaflet argued the Israeli army could impose an extended curfew on the city in response to the general strike. This would make it very difficult for residents to celebrate the end of the Islamic fast month of Ramadan, later this week. Masked activists marched through the city center Saturday announcing the cancellation, witnesses said. In the occupied Gaza Strip, meanwhile, troops shot and wounded at least six Palestinians in clashes in the Khan Yunis refugee camp and the nearby village of Bani Suhaila, Arab hospital officials said. The army confirmed five of the wounded. Palestinian reports and the Israeli news agency, Itim, said unrest began in Khan Yunis after soldiers intervened to save an Arab who was severely beaten by uprising activists after he was caught trying to sell thousands of dollars worth of counterfeit Jordanian dinars. Also Saturday, Greek Orthodox Patriarch Diodorus I led a procession of priests in the old, walled city of Jerusalem to protest a Jewish settlement in the Christian quarter. The priests were joined by about 100 Palestinian youths, some of them masked and waving outlawed Palestinian flags, witnesses said. Six youths were reportedly detained by police after the march. The church has contended the settlers are illegally occupying four church-owned buildings, and two lower courts and the attorney general ordered their eviction. The Supreme Court blocked the eviction until it hears an appeal by the settlers Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Fire Guts Top Floor of Hotel; No Serious Injuries
LaserPhoto VG1
DOC.TEXT: A top-floor fire routed 150 guests from a five-story hotel near the Las Vegas Strip before dawn Saturday but fire alarms and a rapid evacuation prevented all but minor injuries. The fire destroyed the roof and fifth floor of the 75-room Las Vegas Inn but only seven minor injuries were reported among hotel guests and 60 firefighters involved, said city spokesman Doug Bradford. The hotel had fire sprinklers on just the bottom two floors but the Fire Department had developed a firefighting plan specifically for the inn and the scheme was credited with saving lives and most of the structure. ``We've done training exercises on that fire scenario. We knew where everything was; we knew the situation going into it,'' Bradford said. The fire apparently began in the attic but the exact point of origin and cause had yet to be determined. The roof fell on the fifth floor but lower floors had only smoke and water damage. Damage costs weren't estimated. Evacuees and scores of onlookers stared as firefighters poured water onto the top of the hotel, where the fire broke out just before 2:30 a.m. and sent smoke billowing past the casinos of the glittering Strip two blocks away. ``All of our plane tickets and everything is in there, said Carol Grass, of Fort Bragg, N.C., looking up to her room as charred shingles fell free. ``We were right there,'' she said. ``Right where those shingles fell.'' Two guests suffered smoke inhalation, two had minor cuts and bruises and one had chest pains. One firefighter sprained an ankle and another suffered a minor wrist injury, the city spokesman said. The Fire Department was called at 2:29 a.m. and firefighters were on the scene by 2:35 a.m., Bradford said. ``The alarms went off. Immediately we got a call from hotel security that there was a fire there. They in turn evacuated the fifth floor,'' he said. Firefighters checked the fifth floor, found no one, and hurried the evacuation from the lower floors, the spokesman said. Guests reported that the fifth floor was suddenly filled with smoke and they dropped to the floor and exited, saving themselves from smoke inhalation, Bradford said. It took 40 minutes to control the fire to the point where firefighters could return to the fifth floor and attack remaining hot spots. The city initially reported that the hotel had fire sprinklers that aided the battle against the flames. Bradford said it was determined later that the hotel only had sprinklers on the bottom floor and second-floor mezzanine. Fire sprinkler retrofitting laws were enacted in Nevada after the disastrous MGM Grand Hotel fire which killed 87 people in November 1980. However, the Las Vegas Inn was exempt from retrofitting laws because the building's height did not exceed 55 feet, Bradford said. The hotel was inspected in January and alarms were found to be working.

DOC.HEAD: Horst Sindermann, Former East German Parliamentary Leader, Dead at 74
DOC.TEXT: Horst Sindermann, a former high-ranking East German Communist official and Parliament leader, has died, the official ADN news agency said. He was 74. Sindermann, who was ousted from power last year along with the hard-line government that had ruled for four decades, died Friday from a heart attack, ADN said, quoting family members. Sindermann was a member of the ruling party Politburo and president of the Communist-dominated Parliament until November, when mass demonstrations toppled the hard-line leadership. Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere, East Germany's first freely elected leader, sent his personal condolences to Sindermann's widow, Ingeborg Sindermann, ADN said. The son of a Dresden book printer, Sindermann was jailed for eight months in 1933 for after joining a Communist youth group. He was convicted of high treason in 1935 and spent the next 10 years in Nazi prison camps until the end of World War II. After the victorious Allies divided Germany into East and West, Sindermann served as editor of various Communist Party publications and held regional party posts until named to the Politburo in 1967. Nine years later, he became president of Parliament and a member of the former council of state. His duties included overseeing the press and radio, guarding against any softening of the government's hard socialist line. After the demonstrations that toppled former party leader Erich Honecker, the Communist leaders who replaced him purged many members of the old guard. Sindermann was stripped of power and party membership in November. An investigation began in January to determine if Sindermann should be charged with crimes against the country. It was abandoned a month later because of Sindermann's poor health. A Communist caretaker government allowed free elections March 18 and a government led by non-Communists was elected. Several other fallen leaders are in poor health, including the 78-year-old Honecker, who resides in a Soviet-run sanitarium in East Germany. A year ago, Sindermann's death would have warranted a huge state funeral. The government news agency ADN had no information on surviving family members or funeral service plans.

DOC.HEAD: Hungarian Group Holds Congress Amid Tight Security
DOC.TEXT: An organization of ethnic Hungarians opened its first congress Saturday, only a month after bloody clashes between the ethnic minority and Romanians in the northern city of Tirgu Mures. Security checks were carried out on all roads leading into Oradea, a city of 240,000 near the Hungarian border. Police patrolled the city and placed a cordon around the conference site, and helicopters hovered overhead. The Democratic Federation of Romanian Hungarians was to nominate its candidates for the country's first multiparty parliamentary elections May 20 after almost 40 years of Communist rule. The 346 delegates were meeting just a month after clashes in the Transylvanian city of Tirgu Mures. At least seven people were killed and many others injured. The ethnic Hungarian federation was officially registered at the end of January, one month after the revolution that toppled Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu. The federation, which puts its membership at 700,000, says it intends to field candidates in all regions. Federation chairman Geza Domokos said the group was set up to protect the interests of about 2.1 million ethnic Hungarians in the nation of 23 million. The ethnic Hungarians are concentrated in the region of Transylvania. The conference was attended by representatives of the National Salvation Front, which heads the country's interim government, opposition political parties, two Hungarian political parties, and observers from the Soviet and Hungarian embassies. At the opening of the congress, Domokos said there was ``no other alternative'' for Romania than democracy. Switching to speaking in Romanian, he emphasized that ``where Transylvania belongs is not at issue. ... There is no room for ideas questioning the sovereignty of the Romanian nation.'' Ethnic Hungarians have been demanding language and other minority rights. But Romanian nationalists have accused them of secretly harboring desires for Transylvania to secede from Romania. Transylvania was part of Hungary in the Austro-Hungarian Empire, but after World War I the region was ceded to Romania. The Ceausescu regime persecuted the ethnic Hungarian minority as part of its official policy aimed at creating a homogeneous society. After the December revolution, the new National Salvation Front government promised to address the ethnic Hungarians' grievances. But Domokos told the Congress that so far ``the Front has failed to implement its declared policy on minorities. We see only hesitation and uncertainty on the issue.''

DOC.HEAD: Former Dissident Elected Chairman of Writers' Union
DOC.TEXT: A former dissident poet was elected chairman of the Romanian Writers' Union on Saturday at the group's first free congress since World War II. The congress also approved a new charter of the 1,700-member union calling for political and financial autonomy of writers from state control. Mircea Dinescu, elected as chairman, said in an opening speech Wednesday that Romanian writers should discard their fears which prevented them from freely expressing their thoughts. ``We are an independent union. We are no longer run by the ministries of culture, labor and foreign affairs,'' he said. Dinescu, 40, was the first to appear on Romanian television to tell the people and the world that dictator Nicolae Ceausescu had been overthrown on Dec. 22, 1989. During more than four decades of Communist rule, the Writers' Union was run by the Council of Socialist Culture and Edcuation, a government-led body which supervised all cultural life in Romania. The council was dismantled in the wake of the December revolution.

DOC.HEAD: Princess Stephanie of Monaco Engaged to French Property Magnate
LaserPhoto PAR1
DOC.TEXT: Princess Stephanie of Monaco and French property magnate Jean-Yves Le Fur announced their engagement Saturday night to friends and relatives at a private party in a Paris restaurant, the restaurant owner said. Among the 50 or so guests were Stephanie's older siblings, Princess Caroline and Prince Albert. Albert is heir to the principality's throne. After Le Fur gave Stephanie the engagement ring, they toasted their coming nuptials with champagne, said Bernard Marck, owner of the chic Le Telegraph restaurant. The palace issued no official statement on the engagement. But after persistent demands by journalists, press officials at the palace confirmed a report about the engagement published Saturday in the French newspaper Nice Matin. Sources close to the palace had said the engagement would be made known to family and friends at the party, and an official announcement would be made in the principality next week. About two dozen police officers manned the streets around Le Telegraph as a parade of cars let off the partygoers. Le Fur and Stephanie entered the restaurant without speaking to reporters. Monaco's ruler, Prince Rainier III, had been expected to attend but was not seen by photographers. Stephanie, 25, has appeared in public several times this year with Le Fur, 26. They have been seen together at the Festival of Magic in Monte Carlo and at boxing and soccer matches. The youngest of three children born to Rainier and film star Grace Kelly, Stephanie has cut a hit record, made a movie and marketed a perfume named after her. Le Fur operates a real estate firm in Paris. The princess was injured in the car accident that claimed the life of her mother in 1982. Rumors in the celebrity press placed Stephanie behind the wheel, but the palace maintains Princess Grace was driving.

DOC.HEAD: A Sampling of Environmental Activities Across the Land
With AM-Earth Day, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A so-called ``living garbage disposal'' that features 800 earthworms could handle the garbage of a family of four, say university students who designed the project. The setup, which goes under the kitchen sink, will be on display Monday by students at Cedar Valley College in the Dallas County Community College District.

An exhibit at the Oklahoma City Zoo showed visitors on Saturday the effects of global warming and how warmer temperatures could turn an environment of lush, green vegetation into a hot, arid landscape of little growth. The U.S. Department of Agrigulture has warned that the forests of eastern Oklahoma and the state's western wheat fields will be affected by global warming. Crop yields could drop as greater irrigation would be required and possible pest infestations increased, said state forester Tim Cannon.

Two University of Massachusetts researchers have been experimenting the past four years with inducing bacteria to grow a natural form of plastic that would be biodegradable. Biochemist R. Clinton Fuller and Robert Lenz, a polymer scientist, brew their natural plastics in jars full of fermenting bacteria. ``These plastics are made by microorganisms and they can be digested by microorganisms,'' Fuller said. The scientists' work differs sharply from the degradable plastics made with cornstarch that have appeared in the past few years. Those bags have come under criticism because they are mostly synthetic and do not degrade in landfills. The pair have reached the point where they can produce small amounts of a tough, clear rubbery material that is a combination of several types of polymers. Polymerization is the science of chaining together simple molecules to form a more complex molecule with different physical properties.

A bank and a paper company in North Carolina had 19,000 seedlings on hand to go along with plans by various groups to plant 1 billion trees worldwide on Earth Day. First American Savings Bank official planned to give away 17,000 white pine seedlings, and Champion International Paper Co. a additional 2,000 tree seedlings. James Bethel, chief executive officer of Greensboro-based First American, said statistics show an average of four trees are removed for each one planted. ``Environmentalists say the massive removal of trees is contributing to a number of problems, such as soil erosion and global warming, and, perhaps worst of all, is the tremendous amount of waste paper generated,'' Bethel said.

More than 700 people on Sunday were expected at a $100-a-plate dinner to raise money to buy the home of Marjory Stoneman Douglas, the 100-year-old defender of the Everglades, to honor her pioneering environmental efforts. Ms. Douglas, author of ``The Everglades: River of Grass,'' was to give a short talk Sunday in suburban Pembroke Pines.

The founders of a coral reef protection group to be honored by President Bush on Earth Day were excited about their meeting but concerned he has not responded to efforts to ban offshore drilling along the Florida Keys. ``I do not want to misplace our appreciation for the award, but the oil is a real threat to us,'' said DeeVon Quirolo, who has helped her husband Craig install 83 mooring buoys to keep boaters from damaging reefs with anchors. The president's ``better judgment should tell him we really can't handle it,'' Quirolo said of oil drilling, which he said is ``counterproductive to everything we do.'' The Quirolos founded Reef Relief in Key West four years ago to save the barrier reefs from human destruction. They were expected to be honored by Bush in Key West on Sunday. Bush and the Interior Department haven't announced a final plan for for drilling off the Keys, where nine oil companies hold 73 leases. The entire Florida congressional delegation and Republican Gov. Bob Martinez support proposals to make permanent a moratorium on drilling.

Environmentalists point to the Edwin B. Forsythe National Wildlife Refuge as an example of man serving as steward to the planet. The preserve operated by the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service has 289 species of birds, including the abundant snow goose to the more rarely sighted snowy owl. Asked what the wetlands area just north of Atlantic City would be without federal protection, Annette Macek, the refuge's primary assistant, said, ``Condos.'' ``And ducks don't nest in a parking lot,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Police Intensifying Manhunt for Medellin Cartel Leader
DOC.TEXT: Police said they have intensified their manhunt in Medellin for reputed cocaine chieftain Pablo Escobar following several bombings and the slaying of a newspaper employee. The Bogota daily El Espectador, whose main offices were bombed last year by traffickers angered by their anti-drug stand, was not distributed Saturday in the northern city of 2 million following the shooting death Friday of a deliveryman. The newspaper said it would halt its circulation to the cocaine trafficking center ``until the lives and work of our collaborators can be guaranteed.'' Police raided private homes and offices of businesses, including one building that contained some city government offices, in the search for Escobar, said Gen. Carlos Arturo Casadiego, the assistant director of the national police. ``We are giving this maximum priority,'' he told reporters late Friday. Escobar is the reputed leader of the Medellin cartel, which U.S. officials say is responsible for much of the cocaine entering the United States. Police had already upgraded the search by sending 300 members of a special anti-terrorist unit to Medellin following a car bombing April 11 that killed 20 people, including eight police officers. Casadiego also said he had ordered an investigation into the killing of the delivery man for El Espectador. Authorities will try to determine why two policemen guarding the paper's Medellin distribution offices had left their posts shortly before the killing outside the offices, Casadiego said. Gunmen fled after they shot and killed the man charged with distributing the paper in the city. The Medellin cartel threatened in a recent communique to carry out more terrorist attacks against El Espectador, a leading crusader against the drug lords. The delivery man was the seventh El Espectador employee killed since the drug traffickers began a terrorism campaign in August. The traffickers have been blamed for more than 200 deaths since then. Also Saturday, police said a group of armed men attacked a farm outside of Medellin, burning 15 antique automobiles and a luxury ranch house in suspected violence between rival drug traffickers. The men used explosives to destroy the farm's swimming pool, police said. The property, located in suburban Envigado, is registered in the name of Hector Arango, an engineer. But police raided the farm two times last year because of suspicions that it belonged to drug traffickers. A judge is deciding whether or not to expropriate the property. Arango is out of the country, police said.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Navy Destroyer Rescues 35 Vietnamese Near Singapore
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to RESTORE spelling of ship to Elliott
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. Navy destroyer rescued 35 Vietnamese refugees aboard a wooden boat drifting in the South China Sea near Singapore, a Navy spokesman said Saturday. The USS Elliott was on ``routine transit'' in the area Friday night when it found the 35-foot boat about 180 miles east of Singapore, said Lt. Cmdr. Joseph Gradisher. The Elliott's commanding officer determined the Vietnamese boat was ``unseaworthy, adrift and unable to navigate'' and ordered the destroyer's crewmen to let the refugees aboard, Gradisher said. He said the refugees, which included 23 men, seven women and five children, were found to be generally in good health after being at sea for six days since leaving the town of Vien Loa. Gradisher said the refugees will be brought to Singapore. Thousands of Vietnamese boat people have left their Communist homeland to flee political persecution and to find better economic opportunity.

DOC.HEAD: Teaneck Residents March To Protest Officer's Killing of Teen
DOC.TEXT: About 500 people marched through this New York City suburb Saturday to protest the handling of an investigation into the police shooting of a black teen-ager that has heightened racial tensions. A vigil for the dead youth April 12 turned into a riot in a community that has prided itself on racial harmony. The march, scheduled to start at 1 p.m., began two hours late as about 200 people from the area waited until seven busloads of marchers arrived from New York City, led by the Rev. Al Sharpton, a black activist. Sharpton marched down Teaneck Road, a main business district in the township, flanked by associate Alton Maddox Jr., Lenora Fulani, chairwoman of the New Alliance Party, based in New York City. Also with him were the parents of Yusuf Hawkins, a black teen-ager allegedly killed by white youths in the New York borough of Brooklyn. The mile-long march ended outside the township's police station, where speakers demanded that a state grand jury return a murder indictment of the white police officer who shot and killed Phillip Pannell, 16, on April 10. ``We demand that this man be arrested,'' Sharpton said. ``He's committed a crime. He's committed a murder.'' The officer, Gary Spath, 29, was suspended with pay pending a review of the shooting, a decision that angered some blacks who said he should have been taken off the payroll. Pannell, 16, of River Edge, was shot in the back. Investigators said a gun was found on the youth's body, but friends of Pannell dispute that claim. ``Don't keep looking for a gun that isn't there,'' Sharpton said. The march and rally were peaceful. Before Sharpton arrived, Tony McKinley, a black resident of Teaneck, stood holding his 16-month-old daughter, Toni. He said he was marching because he wanted to ``wake up the town that we want justice.'' The community has been tense since a candlelight protest against Pannell's shooting erupted into a disturbance in which black teen-agers and young adults overturned police cars, broke store windows on Teaneck Road and attacked people on the street. At least five people were injured. A grand jury in Trenton is to begin investigating the case early next week.

DOC.HEAD: Procession Honors 200th Anniversary of Burial
DOC.TEXT: About 1,200 people, including members of institutions that Benjamin Franklin founded more than two centuries ago, marched Saturday in a ``funeral procession'' commemorating the 200th anniversary of his burial. People dressed in period costume took part in the fesitive procession that depicted Franklin's legacy to Philadelphia and the nation. The procession stretched five blocks from Independence Hall to Christ Church Burial Ground. Some of the 1,200 people who came out in a light rain tossed pennies on Franklin's grave, a tradition that began with his saying, ``A penny saved is a penny earned.'' The city hopes to draw an 1 million visitors more than usual this year with its yearlong tribute to Franklin. According to the visitors bureau, more than 35 museums and groups are dedicating programs and exhibits to Franklin. On April 21, 1790, roughly 20,000 people, or about half the city's population, lined the streets to honor the budding nation's elder statesman, inventor and publisher. ``Ben would have enjoyed this,'' Bob Dewel of Baraboo, Wis., said Saturday ``He was a jolly guy.'' An admirer of Franklin, Dewel and his wife traveled to Philadelphia for the celebration. A fire fighter walked with a Dalmation, a reminder that Franklin organized the first fire department in Philadelphia. About 140 employees of the Philadelphia Contributionship and their families marched in red rain slickers to remember the founder of the nation's first property insurance company. Members of the American Philosophical Society, which Franklin started, also marched through the historical district, as did a delegation from the U.S. Postal Service, in honor of its first postmaster general. There also were representatives from the Free Library of Philadelphia and students from the University of Pennsylvania, two more institutions Franklin helped establish.

DOC.HEAD: South African Church Leaders Discuss Return of Exiles With ANC
DOC.TEXT: Forty South African religious leaders began a two-day meeting Saturday with African National Congress officials to discuss the return of South African exiles. The Rev. John Lamola, head of the ANC religious affairs department, said long-term exiles are expected to encounter difficulties finding homes and jobs when they return home. They are also likely to face emotional stress in readjusting to life in white-governed South Africa, he said. About 20,000 South Africans, including ANC members and other apartheid opponents, are estimated to be living in exile worldwide. Many have been abroad for as long as 25 years. ``We'll be discussing the response of the churches to the plight of these exiles,'' said Lamola. ``We want to draw the attention of those in South Africa to these problems.'' The religious delegation included representatives from the South African Council of Churches, the Catholic Bishops Conference, and the Moslem, Hindu and Jewish communities. Medical experts and social workers from South Africa were also taking part in the discussions. In reforms announced Feb. 2, South African President F.W. de Klerk lifted bans on the ANC and other anti-apartheid opposition organizations. The ANC, which advocates black majority rule, is to hold talks in early May with de Klerk on the political future of the country, which has some 28 million blacks and 5 million whites. The ANC moved its headquarters to the Zambian capital of Lusaka after it was banned by South African authorities in 1960.

DOC.HEAD: Pakistani, Indian Troops Exchange of Fire on Border
DOC.TEXT: Indian and Pakistani soldiers exchanged gunfire along the border in the northern Jammu-Kashmir state Saturday, killing at least one Pakistani soldier, Indian army officials said. The officials, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the battle occurred near the border town of Poonch after Pakistan attempted to dig a trench on the border. Further north, Indian forces shot and killed six civilians who were illegally crossing the frontier, a state government spokesman said. Tension along the border has been heightened in recent weeks because of Indian allegations that Pakistan is supplying arms and training Moslem militants who demand the secession of the Kashmir province from Hindu-dominated India. Pakistan denies the charges and says New Delhi's comments are intimidatory. Also Saturday, the Human Rights Committee for Kashmir in Pakistan asked the United Nations for help in the region. Led by Agha Shahi, a former minister of state for foreign affairs, the group urged the U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez De Cuellar to intercede with New Delhi to ensure ``Indian armed forces act in Kashmir strictly in accordance with principles of humanity.'' About 280 people have died and thousands more arrested in Kashmir since Jan. 20 as a part of India's crackdown against the secession movement. India and Pakistan have fought two wars over the region and a U.N.-monitored cease-fire line divides the area into Indian and Pakistani sectors. A state government spokesman, who cannot be identified under briefing rules, said the six killed were Moslem militants who were returning to India after arms training in Pakistan. Another five militants were injured and nine arrested, the spokesman said. In Kashmir, 23 militants were arrested by security forces, he said. In Srinagar, the largest town in Kashmir, militants shot and killed a Hindu policeman during relaxation of a curfew, which was invoked at the beginning of the month, witnesses said.

DOC.HEAD: Antigua and Barbuda to Seek Extradition of Suspected Israeli Arms Dealer
DOC.TEXT: The Caribbean nation of Antigua and Barbuda plans to seek the extradition of an Israeli suspected of involvement in a 1989 arms shipment that ended up in the hands of Colombian drug traffickers. ``It appears conclusive that one Mr. Morris Safarti was associated with the arms handling and can now be called upon by the government to account for his action,'' Prime Minister Vere Bird Sr. said Friday. His remarks were broadcast on radio and television. ``The Cabinet has therefore advised that appropriate steps will be taken to extradite Mr. Safarti to Antigua with a view to pressing appropriate charges,'' Bird said. The government did not say where Safarti was, but there were reports he was in the United States or Israel. It was not clear what connection Safarti, who owned a melon farm in eastern Antigua two years ago, had with the arms shipment. Colombian officials have said that the arms were shipped to the Antigua and then diverted to drug traffickers working with the Medellin cocaine cartel. On Monday, Bird issued a statement denying allegations that the country's defense forces had first purchased the weapons. He said Saturday that the arms shipment included rocket-propelled grenade launchers, anti-aircraft guns and automatic rifles. The weapons were shipped from Haifa, Israel, to an Antiguan port and then shipped to Santa Marta, Colombia, according to a preliminary investigation led by Deputy Prime Minister Lester Bird, the prime minister's son. In February, Colombian soldiers found 232 Israeli-made weapons during a search of ranches seized from Gonzalo Rodriguez Gacha, a leader of the Medellin drug cartel who was killed in a December gun battle with police, Colombian Defense Minister Oscar Botero said last week. The weapons found included assault rifles, machine guns, submachine guns, pistols, shoulder-fired rockets and infrared night scopes, Botero said. He said authorities have not been determined how the weapons wound up with Medellin drug traffickers. Bird said ``it has become evident...there were irregularities and breeches of our customs regulations in handling the arms which were transshipped through Antigua in April 1989.'' On Monday, Bird said that documents were falsified and customs procedures ignored to facilitate the passage of the arms shipment through Antigua. The mystery over the Israeli weapons follows a scandal that broke last year concerning the alleged involvement of Israeli mercenaries in training the private armies of the Medellin cartel. The Colombian government has formally charged two Israelis, Yair Klein and Arik Afek, with complicity with the Medellin cartel. Colombian authorities have requested the extradition of Klein, a former Israeli army lieutenant colonel, who is in Israel. Afek was found dead Jan. 24 in the trunk of his parked car at Miami International Airport in what police describe as a gangland slaying.

DOC.HEAD: College President Cancels Visit of Soviet Speaker in Protest
DOC.TEXT: To protest the Soviet Union's pressure on Lithuania, the president of Daemen College has withdrawn his invitation to a Soviet diplomat to speak at the school's commencement. Igor Khripunov, first secretary of the Soviet Embassy in Washington D.C., had already agreed to speak at the private liberal arts college's May 13 commencement. ``I know it's not exactly the most genteel thing to do, but I think I'm right,'' Robert S. Marshall said of his decision to cancel the invitation. ``I could not in good conscience present to our graduating class a representative of a country which uses the jackboot of tyranny to attempt to halt a movement toward freedom,'' he said. Marshall said he originally wanted Khripunov as a speaker because of the Soviet Union's apparent ``momentum toward democratization.'' A spokesman for the Soviet Embassy said Khripunov had not received the letter and could not comment on the decision.

DOC.HEAD: Northwest: Pilot Accused of Being Drunk has ``Impeccable Record''
DOC.TEXT: A Northwest Airlines pilot who was wrongly accused by a passenger of being drunk has an ``impeccable record'' over more than 20 years of service, an airline spokesman said Saturday. In part because of the accusation, a flight from Detroit to Atlanta was delayed for nearly four hours Thursday night. The pilot, who was called in after the scheduled pilot was delayed en route from Milwaukee, insisted that he be given an alcohol and drug test to prove he was sober. ``We have had no problem with his performance with the company,'' spokesman Bob Gibbons said of the pilot, who took a blood test that showed he had no alcohol in his system. He refused to identify the pilot. The plane was delayed nearly four hours while another substitute pilot was found. When the plane finally left, the passenger and her husband stayed behind because other passengers were angry with them, Northwest spokesman Douglas Miller said. The woman and her husband were ``subjected to quite a bit of verbal abuse from the other passengers and they elected not to take the flight,'' Miller said. The couple took another flight Friday morning. Thursday's incident occurred aboard Flight 497, due to leave Detroit at 8:30 p.m. As passengers waited for the substitute pilot to arrive, the woman began talking to other passengers, saying the pilot was late because he was probably drunk or partying, Miller said. When the pilot arrived, a flight attendant took him aside and told him of the woman's concerns. The pilot ``felt his integrity was being questioned, so he asked if the lady wanted to speak to him,'' Miller said. ``She did.'' After hearing her accusations, he insisted on being tested. Gibbons identified the woman as Ann Beaver of the Detroit suburb of Bloomfield Hills. A call to her home Saturday was answered by her stepson, Brad Beaver, who said she and her husband, Harvey, were in Atlanta on vacation and unavailable to comment. It wasn't known whether the woman's concerns were prompted by the arrest of three Northwest pilots on March 8 in Minneapolis, where they were accused of flying from Fargo, N.D., while drunk. They were fired by the airline and face state and federal charges. Miller said the airline supports the actions of the substitute pilot. ``We feel he was justified,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Air Force Displays Supersecret Stealth Fighter to Public for First Time
LaserPhoto VG3
DOC.TEXT: One of America's worst kept military secrets, the F-117A stealth fighter, was unveiled Saturday to a crowd of thousands who cheered a demonstration flight by two of the multimillion dollar planes. The two bat-shaped planes swept in under thin cloud cover and passed over Nellis Air Force Base, banked sharply against the Las Vegas skyline and landed to give the public its first closeup of the once top-secret aircraft. There was an eerie whine as the lead craft, piloted by Capt. Randall Peterson of Rock Island, Ill., made a pass 58 feet above the runway. The second, piloted by Maj. Steven Charles of Springfield, Mass., then swept by the crowd, circled and landed. Both jets were surprisingly quiet in flight and while taxiing to an area encircled by several thousand people, including military families, VIPs and 225 reporters and photographers, including 37 from five foreign countries. Viewing was opened to the public later and as many as 150,000 people were expected. Foreign journalists represented Britain, France, Australia, Japan and West Germany. Asked if any Soviet reporters were on hand, Tech. Sgt. Bobby Shelton, the stealth unit information officer, replied, ``They didn't ask us.'' The F-117A costs more than $100 million a copy, according to a recent report by the General Accounting Office. The Air Force gave a figure of $42.6 million _ the so-called fly-away cost of one plane, without counting development costs for the program. No performance details were released, other than that the radar-evading F-117A is a single-seat, twin-engine subsonic jet. ``It is a fighter in every respect,'' Peterson, 30, told the crowd. He said the jet has outstanding handling and gives the United States unprecedented capabilities. Pressed about those capabilities, he said, ``We're not allowed to discuss any capability. A lot of the information is still classified.'' Referring to an F-117A nickname that has surfaced, he said, ``Nobody that flies the stealth aircraft calls it a wobbly goblin.'' Also off-limits were questions on reports that a stealth fighter used in the U.S. invasion of Panama last year dropped bombs far from its target. ``The bombs hit exactly where they were aimed,'' Randall said before another Air Force officer broke in and said, ``We can't discuss information like that.'' ``I only wish I could tell you what this fighter can really do,'' said Ben Rich, vice president of Lockheed Corp., which builds the jet at its secret ``Skunk Works'' in Burbank, Calif. ``The performance is awesome and the weapons system is unmatched anywhere in the world.'' Though the ``fighter'' designation suggests dogfights with other planes, the F-117A's main mission is as an attack jet. It is designed to sneak through enemy defenses and bomb selected targets such as defensive radar installations. The Air Force only recently lifted the shroud of secrecy on the F-117A, which long had been rumored to exist and has been flying for a decade. Previously, only pictures had been shown. The stealth fighters are attached to the 37th Tactical Fighter Wing at the Tonopah Test Range, a remote airfield 140 miles northwest of Las Vegas. Most of the 2,500 military personnel assigned to the program live in the Las Vegas area and commute to Tonopah each week. For their families, the public demonstration was the first view of the plane. The F-117A is a relatively simple aircraft to fly and operate. said Col. Anthony Tolin, commander of the 37th. With only three accidents in nine years, it has the best safety record of any Air Force plane, he said. A test pilot survived the crash of the initial plane. Two Air Force officers were killed in other accidents during operational training. A total of 59 stealth fighters have been purchased and the last will be delivered this fall. Each costs $42.6 million. Lt. Gen. Peter Kempf, commander of the 12th Air Force, said it took 31 months to develop the stealth fighter, compared to a normal aircraft development time of 10 to 12 years. The first stealth fighter flight was in 1981, and the first production aircraft were delivered to the Air Force a year later. The plane was flown strictly at night and over remote deserts until November 1988, when the Air Force acknowledged the aircraft's existence. Officials said the secrecy was lifted because the plane needed to start flying in daylight. Tonopah residents have reported seeing the F-117A in flight for several years.

DOC.HEAD: Israeli Troops Kill Six In Raid North Of Security Zone
DOC.TEXT: Troops killed six pro-Iranian guerrillas in a raid north of Israel's self-proclaimed security zone in southern Lebanon, the army said Saturday. No Israeli casualties were reported in the raid. It was Israel's first incursion north of the security zone in four months. The military command said a force of infantryman from the elite Givati brigade attacked a group of militiamen from the radical Moslem fundamentalist Hezbollah, or Party of God movement, in the area of Ein Al-Tineh village three miles northeast of the security zone. Lebanese police said the raid began with four Israeli helicopter gunships firing 12 air-to-ground missiles into the village Friday night, killing six. A police spokesman said Israeli gunships struck ``minutes'' after Hezbollah guerrillas returned to the village from a parade they staged in a nearby town to mark ``International Jerusalem Day.'' Hezbollah released a statement saying the air raid came after its fighters clashed with Israeli soldiers on the northern edge of the security zone. Israeli military officials said the Givati troops attacked the Hezbollah fighters at night in a hilly area controlled by the pro-Iranian militiamen. The army said the soldiers fatally shot six guerrillas. They said the uniformed guerrillas were carrying assault rifles, hand grenades and other military equipment. The officials said the pro-Iranian militiamen have bases in the area for training and launching raids on the Israeli army, its southern Lebanese allies and the security zone enclave. The soldiers returned to the security zone Saturday morning, the army said. Hezbollah has carried out numerous raids on the enclave, a 6- to 10-mile-wide buffer strip along the Israeli border. The area is patrolled by Israeli troops and about 2,000 fighters of the South Lebanon Army, a mostly Christian, Israeli-trained militia. Israel carved out the zone in 1985, when it withdrew the bulk of its troops from southern Lebanon following a three-year occupation. The last Israeli attack north of the zone was Dec. 26, when paratroopers backed by tanks killed several guerrillas belonging to the Lebanese Communist Party. The latest raid came a day after Israeli warplanes twice attacked a tunnel complex used by Syrian-backed Palestinian guerrillas above the coastal town of Naameh south of Beirut. Two people were wounded. The Israeli air force has carried out at least 11 strikes in Lebanon this year, killing 10 people and wounding 31.

DOC.HEAD: Scientists Say Alaska Volcano Follows Stable Pattern
DOC.TEXT: Mount Redoubt exploded Saturday morning with perhaps its smallest blast to date, scientists said, but the eruption is significant because it is part of an unusually stable pattern. Geologist Steve Brantley, with the Alaska Volcano Observatory, said the eruption at 6:11 a.m. ADT, sent steam and ash about 25,000 feet into the air. The volcano is about 110 miles southwest of Anchorage. Light winds were not expected to carry ash to Anchorage. Redoubt's recurring stirrings happen about once every six or nine days and are regular enough that the observatory now issues warnings, predicting when the next blast will occur. It's been right _ or nearly right _ at least four times since December. Saturday's eruption happened just six hours earlier than predicted. Brantley said scientists had set the time window from noon Saturday to noon Tuesday. ``Mount St. Helens never exhibited this kind of regular, eruptive activity,'' Brantley said, referring to the destructive volcano in Washington state. ``Kilauea Volcano (on the island of Hawaii) did produce many eruptive episodes, several dozen that occurred at varying intervals,'' he said. ``But there wasn't such a fixed pattern.'' Lava from Kilauea destroyed three houses Friday and at least one on Saturday. Brantley says Redoubt does not always give telltale warning signs, such as heightened earthquakes at its base or discernible swelling. Instead, scientists are adding up the number of explosions over a certain period and basing their predictions on the average number of days between explosions. ``It's interesting that it's in this pattern,'' Brantley said. ``Volcanoes do not usually do this.'' He said geologists were 70 percent certain that an explosion would occur sometime after noon Saturday. Redoubt erupted less than 14 hours after a light earthquake shook the Denali National Park area, some 300 miles north of the volcano. There were no immediate reports of damage. Brantley said the two geologic events were unrelated.

DOC.HEAD: Former Ohio Governor, Senator Dead at 94
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to CORRECT that Lausche lost election in 1922 sted won, CORRECT that he served two terms in Senate sted three. Pick up 7th graf, `Although a Democrat...
DOC.TEXT: Frank J. Lausche, a conservative Democrat who served five terms as Ohio governor and two as a U.S. senator, died Saturday of heart complications. He was 94. Lausche died about 1:30 p.m. at the Slovene Home for the Aged, said his sister-in-law, Antonia Lausche. He had been at the home since Feb. 22. Lausche's long political career ended in 1968 with his defeat _ due mostly to a long-running feud with organized labor _ in the Democratic primary for re-election to a third term in the U.S. Senate. He was the only Ohio governor to be elected five times. ``He had a beautiful, wonderful life. We're sorry he didn't live long enough to see Slovenia become an independent country,'' said Mrs. Lausche. ``They're part of Yugoslavia right now, but they're fighting for independence.'' Lausche lost his first two races _ for the Ohio House in 1922 and the Ohio Senate in 1924. In 1932, he was appointed judge of the Cleveland Municipal Court. In 1941, he was elected mayor of Cleveland, a post he held until his election in 1944 to the first of five terms as governor. Although a Democrat, Lausche earned a reputation as an independent who often ignored party positions and consistently proved popular among independents and Republican voters. Lausche was born Nov. 14, 1895, in Cleveland, one of 10 children of Slovenian immigrants. Lausche's father and oldest brother died when he was 12, forcing him to help support the family. He got a job lighting gas-powered street lights for $2 a week. After service in the Army and stints with minor-league baseball teams, Lausche yielded to a long-held desire to become a lawyer. He attended night classes and got his law degree at age 25, ranking second in his class. Lausche is survived by a sister, Josephine Lausche Welf, 95, who lives at the Slovene Home, and three sisters-in-law. His wife, Jane, died in 1981.

DOC.HEAD: First American Killed In WWII Honored 50 Years Later
DOC.TEXT: Americans and Norwegians on Saturday honored a young army captain who became the first U.S. soldier to die in World War II when he was killed in a German air raid. Capt. Robert M. Losey died April 21, 1940 at age 31 in the central Norwegian village of Dombaas. He was on a mission to help American civilians flee the April 1940 German invasion of Norway. U.S. and Norwegian officials and war veterans joined 400 people for the ceremony in the village memorial park, laying a wreath on an eight-foot-high stone monument marking his death. ``Capt. Losey's sacrifice was followed by the battle deaths of 292,131 Americans later in the war,'' said Loret Ruppe, U.S. ambassador to Norway. ``Just as Captain Losey is now forever linked to Dombaas, the United States and Norway are forever linked in friendship and remembrance.'' A native of Andrews, Iowa, Losey was killed when German bombs exploded near a mountain tunnel where he had sought shelter. The attack came nearly 20 months before the Japanese attacked Pearl Harbor, which drew the United States into the war. A 1929 U.S. Military Academy graduate, Losey was buried at West Point. Losey was an army air attache and aide to Florence Harriman, the U.S. minister, or senior diplomat, in Norway. They were to lead the evacuation of American personnel from Oslo to neutral Sweden. Losey, arriving from Finland, joined Mrs. Harriman near the Swedish border and volunteered to go to Dombaas, an important railroad and highway junction 150 miles north of Oslo. Losey felt the trip was too dangerous to risk a senior diplomat. Dombass, a mountain village, was bombed heavily by the Germans after an unsuccessful paratroop attack.
