During an air raid, Losey moved closer to the entrance to the entrance of the tunnel he was in to observe the attack. One bomb exploded near the entrance, killing Losey and several British soldiers. Mrs. Harriman, who eventually made it to Stockholm, later said the news of Losey's death ``was a horrible shock.'' In the early days of the war, she wrote her ``sense of loss in the world was centered in that one young American.''

DOC.HEAD: Badly Damages Headquarters of National Electric Utility
DOC.TEXT: Fire badly the national electric company's administration building Saturday, one day after some of its officials were arrested for fraud, the News Agency of Nigeria reported. The agency said minister of mines, power and steel, Mura Iman, suspected arson, saying the fire ``smacks of sabotage.'' Several National Electric Power Authority employees were arrested at the scene. The building caught fire before dawn and was still burning late Saturday, the agency said. ``I feel terrible and emotional about this incident, coming at a time when the country's economy is at its lowest ebb,'' Iman said. Few details were available concerning the electric company officials detained for fraud. The government has alleged that many customers received electricity without paying. The fire is the latest in a series of accidents at government facilities in this West African nation, including fires at the national oil and phone companies. Nigeria, an OPEC member, suffered economic problems when petroleum prices fell in the early 1980s. Widespread corruption also has been blamed.

DOC.HEAD: Report: U.S. and Peru Agree on Details of Anti-Drug Military Aid Package
DOC.TEXT: The United States is beginning a $35 million new military aid program to expand the drug war in Peru by helping the Peruvian government fight leftist guerrillas who protect coca growers and traffickers, according to a published report. The New York Times quoted a top U.S. official in Lima as saying the United States will build a military training base in the heart of the coca-growing region to train and equip six battalions, to provide river patrol boats and to refurbish 20 ground attack jets. The official emphasized that _ in accordance with agreements reached at the Feb. 15 drug summit in Cartagena, Colombia _ the U.S. military would be limited to a training role. The report in Sunday's editions notes that the $35 million figure for military aid was first mentioned last fall, but that final approval was withheld pending agreement on how the money would be spent. The Times said U.S. Ambassador Thomas Quainton has been authorized to sign an agreement with Peru's Defense Minister, Julio Velazquez Giaccarini, that would allow money in the military aid package to start flowing. In Washington, State Department spokesman Adam Shub said he was unable to determine Saturday night whether a final agreement had been reached, or to provide details in it. However, he noted that increased military aid for Peru and other Andean nations has long been contemplated as part a $2.2 billion, five-year package proposed by President Bush and that discussions on details have been under way with the affected countries for several months. Bush proposed $68 million for anti-drug efforts in Peru for fiscal 1990 and Congress approved $47 million. The $35 million military aid component detailed in the Times report apparently is part of the overall $47 million package.

DOC.HEAD: Every Day Earth Day in Earth, Texas
With AM-Earth Day, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Every day is Earth Day in this tiny cattle and farming community in west Texas. But the 1,250 folks who live here, called Earthlings, are not sparing the chance to capitalize on the 20th anniversary Sunday of the national observance of Earth Day. ``This is the opportunity that we have been waiting for,'' said Noel Pittman, the town's Earth Day chairwoman. ``This day was made for Earth, Texas.'' When Earthlings say there is something in the air, they usually mean dust, tumbleweed or the pungent stench of cattle herds just east of town. But this weekend they are talking about excitement. Not since a Dairy Queen commercial was taped in Earth two years ago has there been such a buzz among the locals, Ms. Pittman said. ``The Dairy Queen commercial put us on the map, at least in Texas,'' she said. ``Most everyone from Earth was in the commercial and people still talk about it. But we are hoping Earth Day will be even bigger.'' To ensure a large turnout from natives and surrounding towns, the Chamber of Commerce held Earth Day activities on Saturday. City officials acknowledge that many of the people attending the outdoor ceremony came simply to mix with neighbors in some place other than the bank or Dairy Queen. ``I am sure there are some people here that have no idea what Earth Day is or what it means,'' said Ms. Pittman. ``But maybe the activities will help make them more aware. If not, they will have a great time greeting folks.'' The post office is capitalizing on Earth Day by issuing a commemorative postmark. Since Earth is the only town in the United States with that name, it is the only place where an Earth Day pictorial postmark can be found, said postmaster Don Hallett. The postmark, which is inked across stamps as a void, features a tree outlined in green with ``April 22, 1990, Earth'' scripted in the branches. Mayor Raiford Daniel said he would love to see Earth become the national headquarters for future Earth Day celebrations. ``This could be the beginning of something big,'' Daniel said. ``That is what we are hoping for. If the rest of the country decides that we should be the focal point for Earth Day activities, all they have to do is call. We will be here.''

DOC.HEAD: Veteran Newsman Covered Civil Rights Movement, Space Age
DOC.TEXT: Nicholas C. Chriss, a veteran reporter who covered the civil rights movement, the construction and demolition of the Berlin Wall, the space program and three presidential campaigns, died Saturday of a heart attack. He was 62. During the 1950s, Chriss covered the emergence of the civil rights movement, beginning with the Rev. Martin Luther King's rise to leadership at Montgomery, Ala. In 1956, when Rosa Parks took her historic first ride seated at the front of a Montgomery bus, Chriss accompanied her in his capacity as a United Press International correspondent. He also covered King's assassination in Memphis in 1968. When the Communists erected the Berlin Wall in 1961, Chriss was there, and he returned there last December as a reporter for the Houston Chronicle when the wall began coming down. He joined the Chronicle in September 1979. Chriss reported on the presidential campaigns of George McGovern, George Wallace and Ronald Reagan. He also covered the space program throughout the Mercury, Gemini and Apollo eras, and reported on the 1986 Challenger disaster. In recent years, he made two trips to the Soviet Union reporting on the Soviet space program. He also traveled to Eastern Europe in recent months to cover the emergence of pro-democracy movements. Chronicle Editor Jack Loftis said, ``I will miss him as a professional journalist and as a good friend.'' A native of Painesville, Ohio, Chriss entered the Army upon graduation during World War II, and was stationed in the Aleutian Islands. After the war, he attended the University of Missouri, graduating in 1952 with bachelor of arts degrees in journalism and in German literature and language. His first newspaper job was with the Northeast Mississippi Daily Journal at Tupelo. He went on to work for UPI at Atlanta, London and Frankfurt, Germany. He was the Houston bureau chief for the Los Angeles Times before going to work for the Chronicle. Chriss served as the first president of the Atlanta Press Club after its organization in the 1960s and as president of Press Club of Houston for the 1977-78 term. In addition to his wife, Jutta Hausen, a mathematics professor at the University of Houston, he is survived by a son, a sister and two daughters, including Catherine Chriss, a general assignment reporter for the Chronicle.

DOC.HEAD: Precede NEW YORK
U.S. to Train Peru's Army in Guerrilla Warfare at New Base
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with U.S. confirmation, details. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: The United States plans to build a training base where U.S. soldiers will instruct the Peruvian army in jungle warfare to fight leftist rebels, a U.S. Embassy official said Saturday. The new base will be built in the coca-rich Upper Huallaga valley as part of a $35 million U.S. military aid package. The aid is one of several U.S. measures as part of President Bush's strategy announced in September to fight the flow of drugs from Andean nations. ``We've been building the pipeline and now its starting to flow,'' said a U.S. Embassy spokesman. For security reasons, he spoke on condition his name not be used. Bush asked Congress for $2.2 billion over five years to help Colombia, Bolivia and Peru fight drug trafficking. The package apparently will come from $47 million approved for fiscal 1990 by Congress for anti-drug efforts in Peru. Plans call for U.S. military personnel to train five Peruvian army battalions and one navy battalion that currently operate in the Huallaga valley, the spokesman said. He gave no figure for the number of U.S. personnel to be involved. The base is to be built near the anti-drug base at Santa Lucia, 250 miles north of Lima in the jungle, he said. That base has been the staging ground for interdiction operations involving Peruvian police and U.S. drug agents against smugglers in the valley. The base was attacked April 7 be a large column of Shining Path guerrillas. No one on the base was wounded, but a number of the rebels were believed killed. The pre-dawn attack was repelled by two U.S. helicopters armed with M-60 machine guns and flown by American contract pilots. It was the first time any of the 10 State Department UH-1H helicopters on loan to Peru for drug operations were directly involved in a battle with the rebels. The spokesman said the two bases will be able to support each other in case of rebel attack. ``We think that this will increase the capacity to deal with large subversive movements in the area,'' he said. The $35 million will also pay for weapons, communications equipment and uniforms for the six battalions, which will be rotated through the base in small groups, the official said. ``They will be provided basic counterinsurgency training to improve field effectiveness and efficiency in dealing with Sendero Luminoso in the valley,'' the spokesman said. ``Sendero Luminoso'' is the Spanish name for the Shining Path rebels, a Maoist-inspired group that operates in league with drug traffickers in the Upper Huallaga valley. U.S. officials have said the U.S.-sponsored drug fight has been ineffective in Peru because of the lack of security in the valley. The Bush Administration has insisted development aid for the area, such as crop substitution programs, be predicated on improved security against leftist guerrillas. Other aspects of the new program call for the United States to provide river boats to the Peruvian navy to use in patrolling the extensive river systems in Peru's eastern jungles. Much of the chemicals used in the cocaine-making process come into the country from Colombia and Brazil by way of the many Amazon tributaries along the borders. They are also used to carry the drug out of the country. The program also calls for the United States to refurbish about 20 A-37 attack jets belonging to the Peruvian air force. They will be used to provide air support in the fight against the Shining Path. The spokesman said the training base would be built and operating within a few months. He said plans for three other bases being discussed by U.S. and Peruvian officials. The announcement of the new program comes as Peruvians await the second round of presidential elections between Mario Vargas Llosa and Alberto Fujimori. Both candidates have said they would allow U.S. military personnel to come to Peru for training purposes. About a dozen Green Berets are training Peruvian police in jungle warfare at a base in Mazamari, 180 miles east of Lima.

DOC.HEAD: The Likely Candidate for Author of Shakespeare's Plays? _ Try Shakespeare
DOC.TEXT: After years of sophisticated, computerized studies, a group of scholars trying to find out who really wrote Shakespeare's plays have settled on a likely candidate _ Shakespeare. Students and faculty at Claremont McKenna College's Shakespeare Project presented those findings Saturday, said college spokesman Robert Daseler. But one mustn't leap to the conclusion that ``All's Well That Ends Well'' or even that the three-year project turned out to be ``Much Ado About Nothing.'' For the head of the Shakespeare Project, Ward Elliott, still is unconvinced that William Shakespeare knew of what he wrote, said Daseler. He is only willing to concede that after three years of study, just about all other prominent Elizabethan writers that other scholars once thought were the real writers of Shakespeare's plays really weren't. And that leaves as the only serious contender, well, Shakespeare. Or maybe a fairly obscure Elizabethan poet named Fulke Greyville. Or perhaps even Queen Elizabeth I. But apparently not Christopher Marlowe or Francis Bacon _ two prominent Elizabethans that many scholars have long argued may have used Shakespeare's name as a nom de plume. For nearly two centuries, English scholars have debated whether someone with Shakespeare's education _ about that of a modern-day high school graduate _ could have written plays that showed such a precise knowledge of falconry, geography, court manners and several foreign languages, to say nothing of such a stunning command of the English language. ``Wouldn't somebody who was better educated, who had gone on to Oxford and studied Greek and all these other things have been more likely to have written those plays,'' asked Daseler. That's what Ward, a political science professor, Robert Valenza, a mathematics professor, and several students sought to find out. Key to their research, Daseler said, was a field of mathematics and computer technology called signal processing that organizations like the Central Intelligence Agency use to analyze data. ``Using the signal processing method, Valenza and three to four students working with him analyzed Shakespeare's work in terms of some of the key words that Shakespeare used frequently,'' Daseler said. ``They analyzed 52 that seemed to have more than a random importance to Shakespeare.'' Among the words were grief, ground, heaven, hope, lovers, desire, death tears, praise, secret and voice. The researchers compared the way Shakespeare used the words to the way other writers, including Marlowe, Bacon and Greyville, used them. In all, the researchers put more than 3 million words, including 884,000 written by Shakespeare, into computer data banks for their battery of tests. What they found was that the works of Bacon and Marlowe weren't that similar to the works of Shakespeare, Daseler said. Nor were the works of John Donne, Edmund Spenser, Michael Drayton or Edward deVere, the 175th earl of Oxford, all of whom have been suspected of being the real writer of Shakespeare's plays. ``Greyville might qualify,'' Daseler said. ``His work showed a great deal of consistency with regard to Shakespeare's. Queen Elizabeth I also showed a little bit of consistency.'' But the general conclusion of most of the scholars was that Shakespeare wrote the plays. ``Valenza now says he believes Shakespeare wrote Shakespeare,'' Daseler said. ``Ward Elliott, who has been heading this study up for three years, still believes they're going to find somebody else,'' Daseler added. ``But he does admit that they have eliminated all the existing claimants.''

DOC.HEAD: Army Withdrawing From Neutral Zones, Strikes Continue
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with six grafs to UPDATE with parliament leader elected. Picks up 5th graf pvs, `The Defense...'
DOC.TEXT: Sandinista army troops began clearing out of five neutral zones Saturday, making way for Contra rebels who have promised to disarm. U.N. observers were moving into the five security zones to monitor the military withdrawal and the rebel demobilization. Also Saturday, the 14-party coalition of President-elect Violeta Barrios de Chamorro elected conservative Miriam Arguello as the head of the new National Assembly. Ms. Arguello, a 63-year-old lawyer who had been jailed by the Sandinistas after a 1988 opposition political rally. She defeated Alfredo Cesar, a close Chamorro adviser, in a 28-23 vote by deputies from Mrs. Chamorro's 14-party coalition, the United National Opposition. The election was seen a defeat to Mrs. Chamorro. Earlier, outgoing President Daniel Ortega bade farewell to the old Sandinista-dominated assembly, saying the Sandinistas will put the interests of the nation above those of the party. Voters weary of war and poverty put an end to more than a decade of rule by the leftist Sandinistas in the Feb. 25 general elections. Mrs. Chamorro's victory paved the way for the cease-fire and demobilization accord. The Defense Ministry claimed the Contras had violated the cease-fire by hijacking a truck in a remote mining region Thursday but said Sandinista troops were withdrawing anyway. ``The Sandinista army has begun retiring from the security zones to allow the members of the resistance to enter them,'' a ministry spokesman, Capt. Carlos Lara, said Saturday. The withdrawal operation was launched Thursday, the day a permanent cease-fire in Nicaragua's 9-year-old civil war began, he said. The peace accord calls for the Contras to begin disarming April 25, the day conservative President-elect Violeta Barrios de Chamorro takes office. The deadline for total demobilization is June 10. The bulk of the rebel army, estimated at between 9,000 and 12,000 fighters, has returned to Nicaragua from Honduran base camps in the past few months. Scattered strikes by Sandinista workers continued Saturday despite public appeals by Ortega and lame-duck Interior Minister Tomas Borge to end the walkouts. Labor leaders say they are conducting a two-pronged campaign aimed at pressuring the Contras into fulfilling their promise to disarm and at winning wage concessions from the new government. Bank workers, who walked out Friday, were expected to return to work Monday, the Sandinista party newspaper Barricada said, while telephone workers remained out. The pro-Sandinista media also reported strikes by miners on the Atlantic Coast, teachers in some provinces, Ministry of Construction and Transport workers and a variety of other government workers. Despite the skepticism of the Sandinista rank-and-file, party officials seemed confident the demobilization would go according to schedule. The chief spokesman for the Defense Ministry, Lt. Col. Rosa Pasos, said that the ministry had ``abundant information that the Contras are heading for the security zones, ready to demobilize.'' The first U.N. peacekeeping troops were to arrive Sunday in Nicaragua from Honduras, where they oversaw the demobilization of the small contingent of Contras who remained in Honduras after the elections. The troops, all Venezuelan soldiers, were scheduled to deploy in the northernmost of the five security zones on Monday, said U.N. spokeswoman Angelica Hunt. A total of 700 peacekeepers will be deployed by next Saturday, said Ms. Hunt, who spoke in a telephone interview from Honduras. The return to Nicaragua of thousands of armed guerrillas had provoked a crisis that threatened the peaceful transfer of power to Mrs. Chamorro, who is favored by Washington. The Sandinistas finally gave up on their demand that the Contras disarm by inauguration day and the Contras backed off their demand for the army to demobilize. The Sandinistas came to power in the July 1979 popular uprising that toppled the rightist government of Anastasio Somoza and ended 40 years of pro-U.S., Somoza family rule.

DOC.HEAD: Small Aftershock Hits Near Watsonville
DOC.TEXT: A small earthquake struck Saturday in an area hard-hit by October's killer quake, but there were no immediate reports of damage or injuries. The temblor, which struck at 7 p.m., measured 3.5 on the Richter scale and was centered in the southern end of the Loma Prieta aftershock zone, said Pat Jorgenson, a spokeswoman for the U.S. Geological Survey in Menlo Park. Loma Prieta was at the center of the 7.1-magnitude quake that struck the San Francisco Bay area in Oct. 17, killing 67 people and doing $7 billion in property damage. ``Just yet another of the continuing series of aftershocks,'' said Jorgenson. A dispatcher for the Watsonville Police Department said she received several calls from residents who wanted to know if they'd just felt an earthquake, but no one reported damage or injuries. ``It was a rolling,'' she said. ``It seemed like it lasted forever.'' Watsonville is 70 miles south of San Francisco, just inland from Monterey Bay. A 3.5-magnitude quake is capable of causing slight damage in the immediate area.

DOC.HEAD: Bomb Explodes, Kills Salvadoran Professor
DOC.TEXT: An economics professor was killed Saturday after a bomb exploded in his car as he was preparing to leave the University of El Salvador, police reported. Randolfo Tejada, who also was the director of the Salvadoran Institute for Rehabilitation of the Disabled, died in surgery after the explosion and fire, a police spokesman said. He spoke on condition of anonymity. No suspects have been identified in the bombing, and no group has claimed responsibility. Academics and intellectuals have often been targeted by right-wing extremists in El Salvador's decade-long civil war. At least 71,000 people, mostly civilians, have been killed in the fighting between leftist guerrillas and a succession of U.S.-backed governments. Police said Tejada was getting into his car at the university's economics school after teaching a class when the bomb went off, wounding him and setting fire to his car. Police said they believe the explosive device was placed in Tejada's car while he was teaching the class. Tejada was rushed to the Salvadoran Social Security Institute Hospital, where he died.

DOC.HEAD: Len Cariou Plays Justice Douglas
DOC.NOTE: Eds: No PMs Planned.
DOC.TEXT: Biography written as a book can be more comprehensive than biography done as theater, which tends to hit the high spots but does, literally, give flesh to the subject. An example of theatrical biography, titled ``Mountain,'' is now running at the Lucille Lortel Theater off-Broadway. In it, actor Len Cariou plays the late Justice William O. Douglas. It's a one-man show with a chorus of two. Heather Summerhayes and John C. Vennema become people in Douglas' life and speak the criticisms of conservatives against the liberal who was on the Supreme Court from 1939 to 1980. In ``Mountain,'' one gets a feel of what was important to the man: that constitutional rights not be taken from people, no matter what their race, politics or wrongdoing, that freedom includes the right of privacy, and that wilderness areas be protected forever from development. The play, by Douglas Scott, makes Douglas a full-blooded person and is careful to show faults, not letting him be right all the time. As the play begins, one's heart sinks. It's stagey and anecdotes sound like too-cute party pieces. The ending isn't satisfactory, either, getting overheated as Douglas rails extensively. But recounted aspects of Douglas' life pull one into the play. According to ``Mountain,'' Douglas was President Roosevelt's first choice for vice president in 1944. And Cariou is touching acting Douglas as a boy and later going from Washington state to New York by train. He states Douglas' convictions compellingly. The focus, wisely, isn't on Douglas' private life. His first wife is shown as a shy person, his second, less clearly, as personable, his third and fourth not detailed at all. John Henry Davis directed. K & D Productions, Margery Klain and Robert G. Donnalley Jr. produced in asociation with Lucille Lortel.

DOC.HEAD: Britain Offers Again to Restore Relations with Albania
With AM-UN-Albania
DOC.TEXT: Britain on Friday repeated a 10-year-old offer to restore diplomatic relations with Albania. The statement from the Foreign Office came a day after Albanian leader Ramiz Alia urged the Soviet Union and the United States to restore ties with the Eastern European nation. ``There have recently been increasing signs that Albania wishes to play a fuller part in the international community,'' the Foreign Office said. ``We also note that Mr. Alia, in his remarks, makes no reference to Britain's generous offer 10 years ago, to restore diplomatic relations without pre-conditions. We hope the change in Albania's general tone will lead them to look at our offer,'' the Foreign Office said. In recent weeks, Albania has made several recent moves to increase ties with the West, including the re-establishment of telephone communications with the United States and several other Western nations. It was announced Friday that U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar will visit Albania, the last bastion of hard-line Communism in Eastern Europe, in mid-May. Relations with Britain were broken in 1946 after two Royal Navy vessels struck mines and sank in the Corfu Channel, near Albania's coast. Albania refused to pay compensation and Albanian gold held in the Bank of England was impounded.

DOC.HEAD: Kennedy Winter White House Won't Be a Landmark
DOC.TEXT: The Kennedy family quietly won its fight Friday to prevent preservationists from designating as a town landmark the $3 million home that once served as a winter White House. The Palm Beach Landmarks Preservation Commission listened to a report on the historical and architectural value of the seaside estate, called ``La Guerida,'' but all seven members were silent when chairman James Sullivan asked for a motion to make the report a part of the record. A request for any other motions also met with silence, removing the matter from the commission agenda. Although commission members felt strongly that the home should become a landmark, Sullivan said ``the Kennedy family's intransigence'' _ and the threat of a costly legal battle _ doomed the proposal. ``I think the commission did the right thing,'' he said. ``We can't act as Don Quixotes, fighting windmills.'' Attorneys for the estate's owner, 99-year-old Rose Kennedy, said nothing during Friday's meeting. But in an April 2 letter, they argued the commission could not legally declare the property a landmark because the Town Council denied it that status 10 years ago. In 1980, the council unanimously rejected the landmark commission's recommendation to declare the Mediterranean revival style mansion a landmark after an attorney for the family argued that the landmark ordinance violated Mrs. Kennedy's right to due process. The Kennedy family has said it wants to maintain complete control over the property. The letter also said the home did not qualify as a landmark, citing a consultant's report in 1980 that declared the mansion _ built by Addison Mizner in 1925 _ as being ``certainly Mizner at his poorest.'' Commission members, however, said it should become a landmark because of its association with President John F. Kennedy, who held Cabinet meetings and played touch football with family members on the beach three decades ago. Owners of landmark homes are required to get permission from the commission before making structural or cosmetic changes. They also may be pressed to renovate if the commission determines the property needs work. Palm Beach has designated historical status to about 130 homes, including billionaire Donald Trump's Mar-a-Lago. Of the homes that have been deemed landmarks since the ordinance passed in 1979, only a handful of owners have objected, Sullivan said. Those owners said the landmark requirements violate their rights and could make homes more difficult to sell. The Kennedy home was built for Redman Wanamaker of the Philadelphia department store chain. Members of the family, including Sen. Ted Kennedy, D-Mass., still visit the estate, but Mrs. Kennedy no longer spends winters there because of failing health.

DOC.HEAD: New York No. 1 in Nation in Robberies; Detroit No. 2
DOC.TEXT: New York City has become the robbery capital of the United States, far outdistancing Detroit, which previously led the nation, according to recently reported FBI figures compiled by the Police Department. New York's rate of robberies in 1989 was 1,271 for every 100,000 in population, police said. Detroit's figure was 1,095 and Washington, D.C., came in third with 1,055. The total number of robberies in New York last year amounted to 93,377, or one every six minutes, an increase of nearly 8 percent over the previous year. Not surprisingly, the number of people who want guns, bulletproof vests and bodyguards also increased, officials said. Rounding out the top 10 in per-capita robberies were Baltimore, 1,043; New Orleans, 1,013; Boston, 1,011; Dallas, 928; Los Angeles, 913; Cleveland, 743, and San Francisco, 664. To compile the rankings, the Police Department used preliminary national crime figures for 1989 released by the FBI three weeks ago. The FBI's final, official figures are due in August. In other major crime categories, Washington was first in murder, and New York, after the greatest number of slayings in its history, was ninth on a per capita basis, police said. New York City last ranked No. 1 for robberies in 1981, when more than 107,000 were reported, said Police Commissioner Lee Brown. Police said that during the time the number of robberies increased, the number of applications for gun permits went to 6,397, up 10 percent for the year. If the trend continues, the number will increase another 15 percent in 1990. Stephen D'Andrilli, a security consultant whose company specializes in obtaining gun permits for a fee that can run up to $4,000, said Friday that business has gone up 22 percent in the past six months. ``People come in and tell me `I've got to get a permit now. I'm not going to wait around and be victimized,''' D'Andrilli said. About 15,000 non-official New York City residents are licensed to carry guns, along with nearly 12,000 retired police officers, the department said. An additional 24,000 residents have permits to keep guns in their homes or businesses. D'Andrilli said that since January, his company, Guardian Group International, has also doubled its sale of bulletproof vests. Customers also are interested in bulletproof versions of street clothes like leather jackets, raincoats and even furs, he said.

DOC.HEAD: State Asks Court to Shut Down Church's Bomb Shelters
DOC.TEXT: State attorneys on Friday asked a judge to prevent a religious sect that believes a nuclear holocaust is imminent from occupying a large complex of bomb shelters near Yellowstone National Park. The Department of Health and Environmental Sciences filed a complaint in Livingston that said continued construction at the site could increase the chance of more pollution in the aftermath of a 31,000-gallon fuel spill. The agency also requested that the Church Universal and Triumphant be fined $50,000 for allegedly violating state water quality laws when the fuel leaked from three underground storage tanks at the fallout shelter site near Corwin Springs. In addition, the state asked that plans for all water and sewage systems serving bomb shelters on church property be submitted to the department for review. District Judge Byron Robb took no action on the complaint. State health officials said earlier they would seek an injunction to block further construction on the fallout shelter complex, which can house about 750 people near Corwin Springs. An estimated 30 smaller underground shelters have been built at a nearby subdivision. The bomb shelters reflect the church members' belief that nuclear war or some other global catastrophe is imminent. The fuel spills were discovered last week and some of the contamination made its way to nearby Mol Heron Creek, a pristine spawning ground for cutthroat trout. Additional spills were reported last weekend. Earlier this week, the department issued an order requiring the church to empty and excavate all 35 tanks buried at the Mol Heron site. The tanks had a total capacity of 634,500 gallons. Friday's complaint seeks a temporary restraining order to block further construction on the Mol Heron shelters and to prevent the church from occupying the facilities until the state completes an environmental review of the project. Steve Pilcher, chief of the state Water Quality Bureau, has said such a review could take six to 12 months. Named as defendants in the complaint were the church; Elizabeth Clare Prophet, church president and spiritual leader; Ed Francis, her husband and church vice president; and several residents of the church-owned subdivision of Glastonbury. Church spokesman Murray Steinman said the sect would cooperate with the state fully.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Finds Man Who Threatened Johnny Carson Unfit for Trial
DOC.TEXT: A Milwaukee man charged with threatening to kill late-night talk show host Johnny Carson is mentally unfit to stand trial, a judge has ruled. Superior Court Judge Charles Lee on Thursday ordered Ken Orville Gause to return to court May 11 for a commitment hearing. Gause will be held in a state mental health facility until he can understand the charges against him. Gause, 37, was charged with five felony counts of making terrorist threats and five counts of sending threatening letters. Authorities said Gause had threatened to kill the host of ``The Tonight Show'' unless Carson paid him $5 million, which Gause claimed he was owed. Security officers were alerted to watch for Gause after he wrote of his intended arrival, and he was arrested last December in the lobby of NBC Studios in Burbank. At the time of his arrest, Gause allegedly was armed with a sock weighted with sand.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Swept From Motorcyle As Flooding Continues
DOC.TEXT: An elderly woman drowned in flood waters, and 30,000 people in Outback areas remained isolated as heavy rain continued across much of eastern Australia, police said Saturday. Ngari Roberts, 64, drowned at Mudgee in central west New South Wales state when her motorcycle was swept downstream as she tried to cross a swollen creek. Her body was discovered late Friday by her husband. The town of Charleville, in western Queensland state, was underwater and officials said an estimated 4,000 people, many waiting on the roofs of the flooded homes, would have to be removed by helicopter and boat. Queensland state premier Wayne Goss declared the central and western areas of his state a disater area and promised financial aid for victinms of the flooding, caused by three weeks of heavy rain. Meteorologists said the rain was the heaviest in 40 years in the region, which is normally dry and dusty. Dozens of small communities remained cut off as the Royal Australian Air Force continued to drop food and supplies to isolated rural towns. A number of usually placid rivers were overflowing, killing thousands of sheep and cattle. Residents of the New South Wales town of Nyngan worked through the night to sandbag the banks of the Bogan River and prevent it from flooding the town center. Some of the 90 passengers in a train surrounded by flood waters near the town of Longreach were evacuated Friday and other passengers were to be airlifted Saturday.

DOC.HEAD: General Who Led Panama Invasion Gets Commando Forces
DOC.TEXT: The general who led the U.S. invasion of Panama last December has been named chief of U.S. Special Operations Command. Army Lt. Gen. Carl W. Stiner take over at MacDill Air Force Base in Tampa on May 24, President Bush announced Thursday. Stiner will oversee an estimated 35,000 operations troops stationed across the country, including Navy Sea-Air-Land (SEAL) commandos, Army Green Berets and Rangers, and the counterterrorist Delta Force. The command reports to the Joint Chiefs of Staff and the secretary of defense. The general, who will be promoted to four-star rank, replaces retiring Army Gen. James J. Lindsay. Lindsay ran the command since its formation in April 1987. Stiner, a 53-year-old Tennessee native, was chief of staff for the Rapid Deployment Joint Task Force at MacDill from 1980-1982. In October 1988, he took command of the 18th Airborne Corps and Fort Bragg, N.C. The corps is comprised of the 82nd Airborne Division at Bragg, the 101st Airborne Division at Fort Campbell, Ky., and other support elements. The Rapid Deployment Joint Task Force at MacDill was formed in response to the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan and the Iranian revolution. The small headquarters evolved into U.S. Central Command, which is also based at MacDill and coordinates military activity in the Middle East. Stiner's latest assignment was commander of the Dec. 20 invasion of Panama under the direction of Gen. Maxwell Thurman, head of the U.S. Southern Command. Dubbed Operation Just Cause, the venture led to the extradition of Panamanian leader Manuel Noriega to face federal drug charges in the United States.

President Bush is giving Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev a few more days to loosen the economic noose the Kremlin is tightening around breakaway Lithuania before the United States moves to respond. As the vacationing Bush planned to spend today bonefishing here in the Everglades, the White House put Moscow on notice Friday to expect an American response early next week unless Gorbachev eases the Soviet blockade of oil, gas and other materials. Bush himself said nothing during political speeches Friday in Birmingham, Ala., and Orlando, Fla., about the crisis threatening a setback for U.S.-Soviet relations. Asked as he toured Orlando's Sea World why he needed more time to frame a response, Bush said only, ``There's a lot of consultations going on right now.''

The largest securities fraud case in Wall Street history will end next week if a federal judge approves a reported plea-bargain agreement by former junk-bond financier Michael Milken. After a year of maintaining his innocence, Milken agreed Friday to plead guilty to six felonies related to securities fraud and pay $600 million in penalties, sources said. In exchange, the government would drop the most serious charges against Milken. The former head of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.'s high-yield bond department _ who parlayed risky securities into a multibillion-dollar business and fueled the takeover mania of the 1980s _ had been named with two others in a 98-count federal fraud and racketeering indictment last year. Prosecutors last month threatened to submit an expanded indictment Friday unless an agreement was reached.

Researchers say they've found a new link between genetics and AIDS that could help explain why some people become sick soon after exposure while others stave off serious illness for years. In a study of 5,000 infected men from Baltimore, Chicago, Los Angeles and Pittsburgh, those with a particular genetic background tended to have a more rapid decline after being exposed to the AIDS-causing virus, the researchers said Friday. ``It has been a point of considerable interest because the effects of AIDS differ so widely,'' said Dr. June Osborn of the National Commission on AIDS. ``The key finding is that there may be genetic differences that you inherit that once you're infected with HIV, it increases your vulnerability to develop severe diseases,'' said Dr. Charles Rinaldo Jr., an assistant professor of pathology at the University of Pittsburgh.

The Soviet Union's economy turned in an ``abysmal'' performance last year and faces the likelihood of continued inflation and shortages despite President Mikhail Gorbachev's reform efforts, according to a U.S. intelligence analysis. ``Soviet economic problems reached near-crisis proportions in 1989 as severe consumer goods shortages, inflation and rising social and ethnic violence left Gorbachev searching for ways to put his economic program back on track,'' said the report to Congress. ``The combination of inflation and shortages made daily life miserable for all but the most privileged elements of society,'' said the joint Central Intelligence Agency-Defense Intelligence Agency report. CIA Deputy Director for Intelligence John L. Helgerson told the Joint Economic Committee on Friday that the Soviet economic performance was ``abysmal in 1989, the worst since Gorbachev took over'' in 1985.

DOC.HEAD: USA Network's `Not a Penny More, Not a Penny Less' _ Penniless?
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to insert dropped word; PICKS UP 3rd graf, ``The show's ... penny less.'''
DOC.TEXT: When the Brits make something for the telly, they either do it very, very well or teddibly, teddibly badly. When the BBC co-produces with U.S. studios, apparently, it comes out looking like a highbrow ``Love Boat.'' The USA Network's comedy-adventure miniseries Tuesday and Wednesday, ``Not a Penny More, Not a Penny Less,'' requires a greater suspension of disbelief than counting on the return of the tooth fairy when you lose your dentures. The show's premise is that four intelligent, honest men suckered by a crooked financier can combine their talents to scam their money back from him _ but ``not a penny more, not a penny less.'' Ed Asner plays the crook. His victims are Ed Begley Jr. as an American mathematician, Brian Protheroe as a titled British twit, Nicholas Jones as a Harley Street surgeon, and Francois-Eric Gendron as a London art gallery owner. If you can believe that these clever, successful men can be swindled, then the rest of ``Penny'' will generally live up to your expectations. There are some very good things about this collaboration of the BBC with Paramount Television Ltd.-Revcom, most notably the actors and, of them, most notably the Eds. Asner is excellent as the mercilessly corrupt, lonely financier Harvey Metcalf. He subtly makes himself into a sympathetic character. Begley's loopy comic style fits in well. He's the funniest in the ensemble. Jenny Agutter, who grows lovelier with time, is Begley's paramour, and the very attractive Maryam D'Abo provides a love interest for the viscount. Protheroe and Jones have some good bits as well, easily shifting emotional gears to cope with the very worst thing about this miniseries: Sherman Yellen's flawed adaptation of Jeffrey Archer's flawed first novel. Yellen's exposition is awful. He asks an actor playing a man awakened by a long-distance call to say, ``It's the middle of the night here in England.'' And then there's this: ``But remember, Harvey Metcalfe is ruthless and unpredictable.'' And this: ``You know what I think? I think you're all a bunch of suckers.'' It's a tribute to the cast that they energize this enervated material. The miniscams are remarkably improbable, but they fly so smoothly under Clive Donner's sleek direction that you find yourself sitting back and looking at the scenery, which includes London, Monte Carlo and Oxford. It's easier to understand ``Penny'' if you know that Archer wrote it after nearly bankrupting himself. He invested heavily in a Canadian company that went belly up, with three of its directors going to prison for fraud. Owing nearly half a million quid, Archer resigned from the House of Commons and couldn't get a job, so he wrote ``Not a Penny More, Not a Penny Less'' and launched a very successful career as a novelist and playwright. In 1990, his revenge fantasy is on cable TV. For anyone but Anglophiles and Archerphiles, it may be a bad investment.

Elsewhere in television ... DEPT. OF HEAD 'EM UP, MOVE 'EM OUT: ``Today'' co-host Deborah Norville's journey to Nicaragua airs today with an interview of President-elect Violeta Chamorro. Tuesday, she interviews departing President Daniel Ortega. Next month, travel agents for two networks will be busy. ABC's ``Good Morning America'' will broadcast live from England, Scotland and Ireland May 7-11 and May 14-18. ``CBS This Morning'' will originate from the French Riviera and the Italian cities of Florence and Pisa May 7-11. NBC's ``Today,'' which last week canceled plans to see Mexico in May, is staying stateside. It will be in Boston on May 14 and 15, then will broadcast live the rest of that week from various locations right here in Fun City. This travelling is being done during the May ratings ``sweeps,'' whose results are used by stations to set local advertising rates, and perpetuates network hopes that absence makes the heart grow fonder.

DOC.HEAD: Four Years After Chernobyl: Thousands Still Living a Nuclear Nightmare
DOC.TEXT: Smiling children skip along dirt paths, kicking up radioactive dust. They throw stones in their radioactive playground, then go home for contaminated meat and milk. Since cesium, strontium and plutonium descended on their rooftops, gardens, farms and schools four years ago, the people of this Byelorussian village and of scores more in the Ukraine and Russia have been prisoners of Chernobyl. They are surrounded and continously bombarded by an enemy they cannot see, smell or hear. They say their government and the world have all but forgotten them. In Bartolomeyevka, another village, a warm and hearty woman named Tatiana T. Kharshunova said: ``They did this to us, and we had to live here. Not just for a month or two but four years. No one paid attention to us.'' She and her neighbors grow potatoes and barley in their gardens, even though the radiation level is 40 curies, nearly three times the danger level. They can recite the figures like scientists, but do not seem fully aware of the threat. ``I'm as strong as a horse,'' Irina Y. Kovoleva said. She looked down at her 14-month-old grandson in her arms and added: ``He's strong, too.'' The boy and his parents were scheduled to be evacuated the next day. ``I'll cry when they leave,'' the grandmother said. ``The cemetery is nearby, so I'll die and go there.'' Nadezhda N. Dmitrochenko of the local governing council said she tries to explain the dangers of radiation, but ``people still don't know what this is. ... It doesn't glow and it doesn't whistle.'' On April 26, 1986, an explosion and fire destroyed one of four reactors at the Chernobyl nuclear power plant in the Ukraine, 125 miles southwest of Noviye Gromyki. As the children of the village played on a sunny April day four years later, chickens and cats darted among the green and brown wooden huts. The only sounds were chickens clucking, dogs barking and the distant roar of tractors plowing contaminated fields in the vast, fertile plain traversed by a creek. The official death toll from Chernobyl remains at 31, but a Soviet newspaper said last fall it had risen to 250. Scientists still predict thousands of deaths will be traceable to the accident. After years of passivity, the people affected are speaking out. Residents of Gomel, the provincial capital, plan a strike and demonstration Thursday, the anniversary, to protest official handling of what the government newspaper Izvestia called ``the greatest technological catastrophe'' in world history. Citizens of Kiev, the Ukrainian capital 80 miles south of Chernobyl, also plan demonstratons. A telethon to raise money for victims is scheduled in Moscow. Protesters demand that officials who concealed the extent of the danger and delayed evacuating contaminated areas be brought to trial. They want medical care for victims and supplies of radiation-free food. About 70 percent of the Chernobyl radiation fell on Byelorussia and contaminated one-fifth of the arable land, an area twice the size of Massachusetts, where 2.2 million people live. Immediately after the accident, about 25,000 Byelorussians were evacuated, but only last year did officials admit the full scope of the contamination and decide to resettle more than 100,000 more. The resettlement will take five years, and people eat and breathe nuclear poison in the meantime. The program appears poorly run. Some evacuees are being resettled on land that also is contaminated and the government is building new homes, schools and offices in areas that are being evacuated. Most families with young children have been moved out of Noviye Gromyki since resettlement began Jan. 1. Those still waiting feel abandoned and frightened. They cannot move on their own because housing must be found for them. ``We sit and cry,'' said Claudia A. Kostochka, 75, who was on a bench with two other women, sobbing. ``They won't take us. We're pensioners.'' ``I lived almost a whole century here, raised a son and daughter here. Two weeks ago they closed our store, so we're eating cabbage and cucumber preserves from last year. We don't know whether it's dangerous or not, but we have to eat.'' A farmer said the milk from his cows was too radioactive to drink, so he sells it to the government, which makes it into butter. He said the butter was supposed to be safe. Many others interviewed said they drank the milk because there was no alternative. As many more said they did not bother to have their home produce checked at a local radiation laboratory. Soil and dust carry radioactive particles. The only paved surfaces in Noviye Gromyki are one street and the grade school playground at No. 13 Lenin Street. Winds blow dust from the dirt roads and fields onto the asphalt and the people, and into their homes. Residents are warned not to gather firewood from the highly radioactive forests nearby. Burning it makes their stoves into what specialists have called ``mini-reactors.'' Villagers are supposed to wash frequently, but they are allowed only one bar of soap a month, the same as anyone else. Soap is rationed in most of the country. Each household gets 30 rubles a month from the government to buy uncontaminated food, but it is hard to find. Thirty rubles are worth $49 at the official exchange rate, but much less in reality. In Vetka, a few miles south of Novoyi Gromyki, children are fed ``clean'' meals at High School No. 1 and the crumbling cement floors are washed several times a day. Outside, their protection against radiation consists of paved playground and a 6-inch-high concrete barrier to keep them off the sidewalk where contaminated dirt falls from the roof. Students are supposed to rinse their shoes in a pan of water at the school entrance, but many don't. Several students said they ignored warnings and rode mopeds in the forest. They complained of headaches and exhaustion, which they blamed on fallout. To the list of ailments the Chernobyl generation suffers, school principal Nikolai N. Shatilo added bloody noses, swollen thyroid glands and vision loss. The radiation level at High School No. 1 is two to three times normal. ``We can't provide normal conditions in school,'' he said. ``There's only one thing to do: take them to a clean zone. We must save the children. They are our future.'' One student said she was bitter because no one seemed to care, not even the doctors who examine her class twice a year. A 16-year-old boy said: ``We're sick and tired of all the checkups. What are they for? All they do is keep saying everything's normal.''

DOC.HEAD: Waste, Coverup, Health Problems Four Years After Accident
With Soviet-Chernobyl
DOC.TEXT: Construction workers erect new buildings in this Byelorussian village even as residents prepare to flee because radiation from the Chernobyl accident endangers their lives. Poor organization is wasting millions of rubles. One agency continues working on construction projects planned before the reactor explosion and fire April 26, 1986, while others evacuate residents of the same village. Criticism of how the disaster was handled began early. The government came under attack at home and abroad because the accident was not reported for two days, after the reactor had sent up a huge cloud of radiation that eventually worked its way around the world. Politicians elected under more liberal policies introduced since 1986 say full information about radiation levels and health problems was kept secret. The government lifted secrecy restrictions on such information last year. As politicians learned more, they pressed for, and won, evacuations of some of the estimated 4 million people still living on irradiated land. Byelorussian writer Ales Adamovich said the alleged coverup, and official claims that no radiation sickness was diagnosed in contaminated areas, amounted to a conspiracy. ``The explosion immediately made very many people at many levels guilty, said Adamovich, a member of the national parliament. ``The reflex of underestimating the scope of the disaster worked in all of them because, if the scope is greater, their guilt is greater.'' A Ukrainian lawmaker said doctors joined the coverup, refusing to register illnesses and deaths as Chernobyl-related and blaming ``radiophobia'' instead. ``They lied,'' said Yuri N. Scherbak, chairman of a parliamentary committee on Chernobyl. ``They said there would be no effects. They said all is good, all is perfect; and now we are beginning gradually, and probably not fully yet, to learn the truth, that not everything is so good.'' Medical reports show leukemia, thyroid gland malfunctions, cancer and anemia are spreading, especially among children. No nationwide figures were available, but an unreleased report obtained by The Associated Press shows worsening health problems among children in the Vetka region. In 1986, there were five cases of aplastic anemia, marked by low counts of platelets needed for clotting and of white blood cells to fight infection. By last year, the number was 114. Cases of iron-deficiency anemia rose in the same period from 134 to 341 and cases of swollen thyroid glands doubled, from 763 in 1986 to 1,508 in 1989. Debate has begun over what radiation level is safe. The government contends a person can be exposed safely to 35 REMs over his life, But specialists testified before Scherbak's committee that the standard does not account for long-term effects of small radiation doses. Virtually all American nuclear power plants limit exposure to 5 REMs a year, according to the U.S. Council for Energy Awareness, an industry group. Aside from human costs, Chernobyl is taking a huge toll on the Soviet budget. New Chernobyl cleanup estimates are 30 times the original figure of 8 billion rubles ($13 billion at the official rate of exchange). Scherbak said surveys by the three republics affected indicate the cost could reach 250 billion rubles ($405 billion) in the next decade. In Vetka, a new communications center and three apartment houses are being built. For whom? ``I asked a party secretary once, and he said we must think about future generations. But basically, it's mismanagement, an inability to plan,'' said Vetka councilman Oleg S. Gromyko. Corruption also takes a toll. The Soviet prosecutor's office has reported ``criminal disregard for the rules of radiation safety, distortions in reported data on medical aid, embezzlements, as well as violations of the rules of paying compensation.'' Press reports said some officials used Chernobyl cleanup money for a sea cruise. Izvestia, the government newspaper, reported in October that contaminated meat was mixed with ``clean'' meat at a packing plant and made into sausage.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Tuesday AMs, April 24

DOC.HEAD: Jackson State Shootings Remembered 20 Years Later
LaserPhoto NY300 of April 20
DOC.TEXT: Gene Young is 39 and a professor at Jackson State University. But give him an instant, and he is 19 again, a student on the same campus, and gripped by fear. He hears again repeated rifle blasts shattering the shirt-sleeve-mild night air. He remembers the screaming and crying. He can see the broken glass, and the blood. And Young remembers first word that a Jackson State College student had been killed as police in riot gear fired on a cluster of students gathered in front of a women's dormitory to protest the Vietnam war and the deaths 10 days earlier of four Kent State University students. A high school student who was crossing the campus was also fatally wounded. Classes were dismissed, commencement was canceled and most students left for home, but Young, a Jackson native, stayed on the inner-city campus several days. ``I felt something had to be done,'' he recalled in an interview. What Young did was convince city high school students they should boycott classes until after Phillip L. Gibbs, 21, and James Earl Green, 17, were buried. Young said he is still trying to figure out what happened. ``To this day, I don't know what could have precipitated that kind of violence,'' said Young, a professor of speech and dramatic arts. The night of May 14, 1970, was the third in a row of campus demonstrations and off-campus disturbances at mostly black Jackson State. Students were agitated and upset about the shootings at Kent State, which occurred when National Guardsmen fired on a crowd of anti-war demonstrators. Students also were fed up with the racial epithets shouted from cars by white West Jackson residents who drove straight through the Jackson State campus on busy Lynch Street to reach downtown. ``The atmosphere was very charged,'' recalled John A. Peoples Jr., president of Jackson State from 1967 to 1984. ``But I had, from the very beginning, given the students a lot of freedom.'' He and Young blamed racial intolerance for the shootings. The city's and state's white officials ``never wanted black students to demonstrate,'' Peoples asserted. Young concurred. ``Mississippi went to a great extent to show how they would keep niggers in line if they were disorderly,'' he said. Young also believes the Jackson State shootings would largely have been ignored if not for what happened at Kent State. ``We know the history of blacks being victimized by whites in Mississippi,'' he said. ``Had the incident not occurred a week after Kent State, it would have been all but forgotten. ``Over the years that has been borne out. People remember Kent State, but they don't remember Jackson State.'' The night Gibbs and Green were killed, 22 police officers in full riot gear advanced on the students milling outside the Alexander Residence Center. Some reports counted 75 to 100 students in front of the dormitory. Police said the number was closer to 400. A voice on a bullhorn ordered students to disperse. Then the shooting began. In 25 seconds, Gibbs and Green were killed and seven others had been wounded. An FBI report counted 275 holes in the west wing of yellow-brick Alexander Hall; 21 were believed caused by automatic weapons, 250 or more by shotgun buckshot. Every window on the street side of the five-story building was blown out. ``Their intent was not just to disperse the crowd, but to bring death and destruction,'' Young said. ``It amazes me that no more people were killed.'' That night's demonstrations had begun after students were drawn outside to watch firefighters douse a burning dump truck on an adjacent street. City and state officers were called to the scene after firefighters were pelted with rocks and bottles, thrown, some say, by neighborhood residents. ``Whatever the students started, the `corner boys' took up,'' Peoples said. ``At night, you couldn't tell the corner boys from the students.'' Officers claimed they opened fire after a sniper shot from a dormitory window and a Highway Patrol officer was hit by an object thrown from the crowd. To that, Young commented, ``The elusive sniper always amazes me, how he gets around the world.'' And students suggested at the time that what police took to be a gunshot might have been the sound of a soft drink bottle smashing on a sidewalk after it was dropped from a dorm window by a student who saw the advancing officers. Families of the dead and injured sued the city of Jackson and the state of Mississippi, but a federal appeals court ruled in 1974 that damages could not be awarded because it was impossible to determine who was to blame. However, the court did say that ``the barrage of gunfire far exceeded the response that was appropriate.'' The President's Commission on Campus Unrest said police had fired blindly into the students and no evidence was found of any sniper. The commission said the blame lay jointly with public officials, students and college administratiors. ``I didn't think anyone would be punished for it in the first place,'' Nureen Gibbs Ray, sister of Phillip Gibbs, said from her home in Ripley. ``They said there was an investigation, but I don't think there was ever anything concrete.'' Gibbs was a junior pre-law student. He had a pregnant wife and child back home in Ripley. His wife has since remarried, changed her children's last name, and lives in Arizona. Green was a track star at Jim Hill High School. He was crossing the Jackson campus after getting off work. Ray said Gibbs had called her that night to let her know about the disturbances on campus but said he and their sister, Mary, also a Jackson State student, would be leaving for home soon. The siblings' parents both were dead. ``His car already was packed. He had gone up to get our sister because they were coming home,'' Ray said. Mary, she said, lives in Chicago and doesn't like to talk about that night. Dr. Roland Colom, a Columbus dentist, attended junior high with Gibbs and was his roomate at Jackson State. ``It was really strange for me to hear that he was out there (amid the demonstrators) because I was out there the night before and tried to get him to go out and he wouldn't,'' Colom said. Jackson State has grown from 3,700 students in 1970 to more than 7,150 today, 93 percent of them black. Lynch Street, the thoroughfare that once split the campus, is closed, replaced by a plaza in front of the Alexander complex. After several years of commemorating the shootings, the ceremonies stopped. But Young is head of a committee planning a special 20th anniversary program next month. Young said he's satisfied that race relations in Mississippi have improved, but he doesn't believe the state has ever repented for the shootings. ``No one has ever apologized,'' he said. ``In that regard, Mississippi still bears the guilt of that incident.''

DOC.HEAD: Chernobyl at a Glance
With Soviet-Chernobyl
DOC.TEXT: Here is a brief review of the Chernobyl nuclear accident and its aftermath:

THE ACCIDENT _ On April 26, 1986, a fire started in one of the four 1,000-megawatt reactors of the nuclear power station at Chernobyl, 80 miles north of Kiev, captial of the Ukraine. A core meltdown and explosion followed, sending huge quantities of radiation into the atmosphere. The Soviets did not report the accident until two days later, after Scandinavian complaints of unsually high radiation levels.

EVACUATION _ About 116,000 people were evacuated from contaminated parts of the Ukraine and Byelorussia, most from a 9-mile radius of the plant. A pass is required to enter the area. Last year, the government decided to evacuate 85 more villages in Byelorussia, 31 in Russia and 14 in the Ukraine.

DEATHS _ Two people were killed in the accident and 29 are officially reported to have died of radiation sickness later. Yuri Scherbak, a Ukrainian member of the national parliament, and others say up to 250 have died. An official report commissioned in 1986 estimated 5,300 people would die over 70 years from cancer resulting from radiation exposure.

COST _ Current estimates of cleanup costs are 30 times the original $8 billion rubles ($13 billion at the official exchange rate). Surveys by the three republics affected indicate the cost may reach 250 billion rubles ($405 billion) over the next decade.

PLANS FOR CHERNOBYL _ The Ukrainian legislature decided this year that the plant, whose other three reactors are still functioning, should be closed by 1995. Specialists say shutting it down may take up to 10 years.

DOC.HEAD: Arbor Day: Begun on Nebraska's Treeless Plain 118 Years Ago
An AP Extra
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto, AP Graphic
DOC.TEXT: Earth Day turned 20 this month in a national frenzy of environmental excess, observed for weeks in song, dance, meditation, exultation and exhortation. On its heels comes Arbor Day. Remember Arbor Day? A tradition started in 1872, it is one of the oldest formalized conservation observances in the world. Its occasion has resulted in the planting of millions of trees in this country through 10 generations. ``God also said, `I give you all plants that bear seed everywhere on Earth, and every tree bearing fruit which yields seed; they shall be yours for food.''' The author of Genesis knew the importance of trees. But not since the legend of Johnny Appleseed tagged after John Chapman, a Massachusetts farmer who gave up the plow to sow orchards from the Allegheny Mountains to Indiana after the Revolution, has tree planting become so trendy. ``A tree planted today can enrich the lives of generations yet unborn,'' President Bush said March 22 when he planted an eastern red bud on the White House lawn. ``So let us plant the trees and nurture them so that America will remain America the beautiful for generations to come.'' Bush then mused that John Quincy Adams planted am elm on the White House grounds in 1826. That Andrew Jackson's magnolia is among the first to bloom each spring. That Woodrow Wilson's family picnicked amid a grove of bay trees. Franklin D. Roosevelt planted a little-leaf linden for Britain's King George VI, and Herbert Hoover and Dwight Eisenhower, both Midwesterners, left their arboreal legacy in oaks. Bush's grandchildren now swing on Ike's sturdy tree. Bush, who wants to plant a tree in every state, last April personally turned the dirt for an offspring of the Adams elm on the grounds of the North Dakota capitol in Bismarck. But before the presidential spade tapped down the roots, horticulturalists had to take emergency action against gypsy moth larvae that had taken a free ride from Washington amid the 12-foot sapling's branches. The president's North Dakota tree is now thriving, according to S.F. ``Buckshot'' Hoffner, executive director of the North Dakota Centennial Commission. The elms Bush planted in South Dakota and Montana for those states' centennials last year are also budding. On April 3, Bush planted another elm in Indianapolis and dedicated it to the comatose Ryan White, the teen-ager with AIDS who died five days later. But Bush is not tackling his goal single-handedly. In his 1990 budget, he asked Congress for $175 million to plant 1 billion trees. He has called on fellow citizens to plant 10 billion trees by the beginning of the century. In time, he said, those trees would annually absorb 13 million tons of carbon dioxide, 5 percent of nationwide emissions. Global ReLeaf, a project of the American Forestry Association, plans to plant 100 million trees in the United States by 1992. A private U.S.-Soviet venture plans to plant fruit trees along the coast of Nicaragua. Scrambling to get on the bandwagon, corporations are lining up to help the U.S. Forest Service with its National Tree Planting Initiative. Texaco, for one, has pledged $1 million to nurture new woods being planted this year by volunteers in Houston, New Orleans and Denver. Scientists say woodlands restoration comes none too soon. Over centuries, agriculture has done in nearly half of the Earth's original forestland. Every year, tropical rain forests the size of Tennessee disappear under the machete and the bulldozer. Experts say football field-sized stands of trees are mowed down somewhere in the world every 3 seconds. Arbor Day, as with most great causes, began as one person's vision and became an official holiday long before ecology was a buzz word. In 1854, Julius Sterling Morton, son of a wealthy New York merchant, left the cultured East with his bride of a few hours and headed for the Nebraska Territory. They settled on a treeless 160-acre homestead outside Nebraska City, 40 miles south of Omaha on the Missouri River. Just 3 percent of the vast Territory was wooded. Fierce prairie fires and roaming buffalo made trees so scarce they became landmarks, such as ``travel two days until you get to the tree.'' It is claimed that Lone Tree, Neb., was named for a single huge cottonwood on the Ox Bow Trail. Nebraska-born author Willa Cather in ``My Antonia'' described the Czech farm girl, Antonia, showing a friend her farm north of Red Cloud: ``As we walked through the apple orchard ... Antonia kept stopping to tell me about one tree or another. `I love them as if they were people,' she said rubbing her hand over the bark. `There wasn't a tree here when we first came. We planted every one and used to carry water for them, too ...' There was the deepest peace in that orchard.'' J. Sterling Morton resolved to change the landscape. He and his wife, Carrie, planted their own apple orchard. At the state fair in 1869, Morton and 22 other men organized the Nebraska State Horticultural Society. On Jan. 4, 1872, Morton presented his ``Fruit Address'' to his colleagues, urging them to plant trees: ``Orchards are missionaries of culture and refinement. They make the people among whom they grow a better and more thoughtful people. If every farmer in Nebraska will ... cultivate an orchard and a flower garden, together with a few forest trees, this will become mentally and morally the best agricultural state, the grandest community of producers in the American union.'' And it was done. The Nebraska Board of Agriculture declared April 10 that year to be Arbor Day. On that first observance, more than 1 million trees were planted in Nebraska. Astonishingly, as many as 100 million trees were planted annually in that prairie state from 1885 to 1890. By 1900, Arbor Day was celebrated in every state and the idea had spread overseas. As the tree-planting ritual became a fixture in the American school year, Morton declared, ``Other holidays repose upon the past; Arbor Day proposes for the future.''

DOC.TEXT: Today National Arbor Day is the last Friday in April, although many states plan observances to coincide with the planting season: South Carolina's Arbor Day is the first Friday in December, while Alaska deems the third Monday in May auspicious. Exactly 100 years after Morton first exhorted his colleagues about planting more trees, John Rosenow _ born, fittingly, in Elmwood, Neb. _ was asked by then-Gov. James J. Exon to plan the state's Arbor Day centennial. Rosenow, the new tourism director, was only 21 and fresh from the University of Nebraska when he accepted the task. He started the National Arbor Day Foundation with $10,000 and a staff of one _ himself. Today, almost 900,000 members make the foundation second only to the National Wildlife Federation as the nation's largest environmental organization. Members pay $10 to join, $15 annual dues thereafter, and receive, free of charge, 10 seedlings from 6 to 12 inches, in varieties suited to climate. More than 40 million trees have been given away since 1972. Rosenow, now 40, the foundation's executive director since 1979, has spent half his life guiding it into an international environmental force. He has a theory on its success: ``The magic of planting a tree and caring for it is something each and every person can do to make a difference. It empowers people the same way a spark can light a bonfire.'' ``Often that experience comes in childhood,'' he said, ``and it can touch off a tremendous, latent desire in people to make a positive contribution to the world they live in.'' When Christ walked the Earth, many forest-dwellers believed gods lived in trees. The Gauls worshiped oak. Sacred trees guarded entrances to Chinese villages. Egyptians left offerings of raisins to sycamores. American Indians believed each tree had its own spirit. ``When you think about tree rings, you have to have sense of reverence,'' said Rosenow. ``A 4,000-year-old sequoia may be one-third as old as civilization itself.'' Tree-huggers everywhere know the ditty by Joyce Kilmer: ``I think that I shall never see A poem lovely as a tree ... Poems are made by fools like me, But only God can make a tree.'' Recite it on Arbor Day as you dig the hole. And then commit this, a poem entitled ``An Arbor Day Tree,'' author unknown, to memory: ``Dear Little tree that we plant today, What will you be when we're old and gray? The saving bank of the squirrel and mouse, For the robin and wren an apartment house. The dressing room of the butterfly's ball, The locust's and katydid's concert hall. The schoolboy's ladder in pleasant June, The schoolgirl's tent in the July moon. And my leaves shall whisper right merrily A tale of children who planted me.''

DOC.HEAD: Analysts: Bush No More Dependent on Polls than Predecessors Were
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, to hear some Democrats tell it, doesn't make a move without checking public opinion polls first _ and even then he acts timidly. Republicans, along with a number of political analysts, counter that Bush is getting a bum rap on the issue. Even a few Democrats say the same. ``I don't think he can be accused of governing by the polls any more than any other modern president,'' said Democrat Stuart Eizenstat, domestic affairs adviser to former President Jimmy Carter. All presidents should be responsive to public moods, Eizenstat said. ``A president, after all, is not a dictator.'' Political scientist Larry Sabato of the University of Virginia, said, ``I think (Bush) is more contemptuous of polls than either (Ronald Reagan or Carter), less likely to trust them or to use them in decision-making.'' Thomas Cronin, presidential scholar at Colorado College, said, ``I think he reads them, just as any good president should. To say he follows them constantly and is tied to them is wrong.'' And John Sears, a Republican political consultant, said, ``By general nature, Bush is cautious. I don't think that's because of something he read in the polls.'' Yet, even those who defend Bush say the president should risk his high ratings occasionally to take a bold stand on a tough issue, such as the federal deficit. ``The best use of presidential popularity is to achieve something now rather than to husband it, because it could all disappear overnight,'' Sabato said. ``An activist president would be putting this to work,'' Cronin said. ``But Bush is a cautious president and moves more slowly. ... I wish he would be leading more.'' On the other hand, Sears said, ``No president is going to get accused of making a terrible blunder by not doing very much.'' Bush's supposed obsession with polls got a lot of attention when House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, in a speech recently, attacked the president as timid and unimaginative. ``The maxim of the Bush presidency seems to be: Do polls, risk nothing,'' Gephardt said. He said Bush is running a government ``of the polls, by the polls and for the polls.'' In response, Bush said he's learned not to trust polls and doesn't shape his decisions by them. ``That's not the way I try to call the shots on the policy,'' he said. Robert Teeter, who conducts polls for the White House, called Gephardt's accusation ``bunk.'' He said Bush is interested in the results but ``is not a great poll fanatic.'' ``There was no decision where we went out and did a poll to shed some light on what we should do,'' he said. In the Reagan White House, a national sampling of public opinion was conducted at least once a month and more frequently during times of crisis, said Tom Griscom, who was Reagan's communications chief. Teeter said he conducted only three or four polls for Bush last year, usually at ``good summing-up times.'' They are done under the auspices of the Republican National Committee. Teeter said he occasionally tags White House-related questions onto other polls he does for the GOP. One polling source said such questions are added to surveys every month. The RNC also plays a big role in helping the White House track public moods, following all public polls, such as those done by the media, as well as surveys taken by GOP organizations and candidates throughout the country. A lot of the information is funneled to the White House. ``We share a lot of it with the political office over there'' at the White House, said RNC spokesman B. J. Cooper. Teeter said Democrats, in criticizing Bush, are trying to suggest he has no personal convictions, lacks ideas and is not a strong leader. ``I don't know why it's wrong in a democracy to pay attention to what the people want you to do,'' Teeter said. To the dismay of Democrats, Bush, after 14 months in office, has the longest running set of high poll ratings of any president in a quarter century. Bush's popularity shot up to 80 percent in January after the invasion of Panama. Since then, it has tapered off to the high 60s and low 70s _ still a lofty rating. ``It's peace, prosperity and the collapse of communism,'' said political scientist Sabato. Gephardt has been prodding Bush to risk some of his popularity, ``to summon the nation to meet new challenges on the horizon.'' Other Democrats have issued similar challenges. Even the GOP's Sears said, ``I don't think they're missing the mark.'' ``If you look below the first level of the polls, people perhaps don't think he's active enough,'' Sears said. ``In politics, it's always a matter of `Compared to what?' There is no other individual, no reaction by the opposition party, to fill in, `What's the alternative?''' ``Where is the Democratic Party? Out to lunch,'' complained Duke University political scientist James David Barber. Referring to Bush's high ratings, Eizenstat said, ``I think he's just sitting on it.'' How does that help Bush? ``It gets him re-elected,'' Eizenstat said.
